PREFACE
   This code of the Village of Bedford Park, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 23-1732, passed October 5, 2023.
Ordinances of the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions
of this code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith.
Consult the Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular
provision of the code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio

ADOPTING ORDINANCE
AN ORDINANCE ENACTING THE REVISED, CODIFIED AND AMENDED GENERAL ORDINANCES OF
THE VILLAGE OF BEDFORD PARK, COUNTY OF COOK AND STATE OF ILLINOIS
   WHEREAS, numerous changes and additions have been made in the general
ordinances of the village of Bedford Park, county of Cook and state of
Illinois, since the formation of the village; and
   WHEREAS It is deemed necessary that such ordinances be revised, that defects
and omissions in the same be corrected, that amendments and additions thereto
should be enacted, and that they should be enacted in a form codified and
arranged in appropriate titles, chapters, and sections.
   THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE
VILLAGE OF BEDFORD PARK, COUNTY OF COOK AND STATE OF ILLINOIS, that the
following ordinance be and the same is hereby adopted as the code of the
general ordinances for the village:
AN ORDINANCE IN REGARD TO THE PUBLICATION OF THE GENERAL ORDINANCES OF THE
VILLAGE OF BEDFORD PARK, COUNTY OF COOK AND STATE OF ILLINOIS
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE VILLAGE OF BEDFORD
PARK, COUNTY OF COOK AND STATE OF ILLINOIS:
   SECTION 1: That the general ordinances of the village of Bedford Park, as
codified, revised and consolidated, and as passed by the president and board of
trustees of said village on the 30th day of April, A.D. 1965, be, and the same
are hereby ordered to be printed and published, in a bound volume, to be
entitled "Village Code of Bedford Park, Illinois, 1965".
   SECTION 2: That said village code shall be so printed and published that the
book will show on its face by means of appropriate words on its title page or
otherwise that said code has been so published by authority of the president
and board of trustees.
Passed:   April 30, A.D. 1965
Approved:   April 30, A.D. 1965
President of the Board of Trustees of the Village of Bedford Park, County of
Cook and State of Illinois
ATTEST:
Village Clerk

TITLE I
ADMINISTRATIVE
CHAPTER 1
VILLAGE CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Construction Of Words
1-1-5: Interpretations
1-1-6: Code Of Ethics (Rep. by Ord. 04-1156, 5-6-2004)
1-1-7: Statute References
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the governing body this code is hereby declared to be and
shall hereafter constitute the official village code of the village of Bedford
Park. Any reference made to the number of any section contained herein shall be
understood to refer to the position of the same under its appropriate chapter
and title heading, and to the general penalty clause relating thereto, as well
as to the section itself, when reference is made to this code by title in any
legal document. (1965 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This code, hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in all administrative tribunals of this
state as the ordinances of the village of general and permanent effect. (1965
Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this code shall set forth the title, chapter and section
number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute a
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the
amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to Sterling
Codifiers, Inc., and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for
insertion in its proper place in each copy of this code. Each such replacement
page shall be properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy
of the code upon passage of said ordinance or otherwise as deemed necessary by
the village board. (Ord. 95-927, 3-30-1995)
1-1-4: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this code importing the plural number is
used in describing or referring to any matters, parties, or persons, any single
matter, party, or person shall be deemed to be included, although distributive
words may not have been used.
When any subject matter, party or person is referred to in this code by words
importing the singular number only, or the masculine gender, several matters,
parties, or persons and females as well as males and bodies corporate shall be
deemed to be included; provided, that these rules of construction shall not be
applied to any section of this code which contains any express provision
excluding such construction or where the subject matter or content may be
repugnant thereto. (1965 Code)
1-1-5: INTERPRETATIONS:
In the determination of the provisions of each section of this code the
following rules shall be observed:
   (A)   Intent To Defraud: Whenever an intent to defraud is required in order
to constitute an offense, it shall be sufficient if an intent appears to
defraud any person.
   (B)   Liability Of Employers And Agents: When the provisions of any section
of this code prohibit the commission of an act, not only the person actually
doing the prohibited act or omitting the directed act, but also the employer
and all other persons concerned with or in aiding or abetting the said person
shall be guilty of the offense described and liable to the penalty set forth.
(1965 Code)
1-1-6: CODE OF ETHICS 1 :
(Rep. by Ord. 04-1156, 5-6-2004)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 20 of this title.
1-1-7: STATUTE REFERENCES:
   (A)   This code is amended by deleting any reference to an Illinois Revised
Statute and inserting, in lieu thereof, the appropriate section of the Illinois
Compiled Statutes.
   (B)   Village officials are hereby directed and authorized to take the
necessary steps to ensure that subsection (A) of this section is effectuated.
(Ord. 94-910, 10-20-1994)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the village passed prior to the adoption of this code
are hereby repealed, except such as are referred to herein as being still in
force or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to
the saving clauses contained in the following section), from which are excluded
the following ordinances which are not hereby repealed; tax levy ordinances;
appropriation ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations;
franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or
corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances establishing, naming or
vacating streets, alleys or other public places; improvement ordinances; bond
ordinances; ordinances relating to elections; ordinances relating to the
transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the village; and all special
ordinances. (1965 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other
public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public
utilities shall be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this code or by virtue
of the preceding section, excepting as this code may contain provisions for
such matters, in which case this code shall be considered as amending such
ordinance or ordinances in respect of such provisions only. (1965 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance,
whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty,
forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense
or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes
effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the
ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable. If
any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new
ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied
to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect.
This section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or
implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions
upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this or the preceding section shall be construed as
abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of
the village herein repealed; or as discontinuing, abating, modifying or
altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any
person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the village under any
ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the adoption of this
code. (1965 Code)

BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:

1-3-19: Standing Committees
1-3-20: Jurisdiction Of Committees

1-3-1: MEETINGS:
   (A)   Regular And Special Meetings: The regular meetings of the board of
trustees shall be held on the first and third Thursday in each month at the
hour of seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. at the village boardroom, unless otherwise
ordered by resolution of any regular meeting of the board of trustees; and
special meetings may be held at any time on call for the same by the president
or any three (3) or more trustees; such call shall be in writing, duly signed,
and shall be presented to the clerk, who shall proceed immediately to prepare
notices of the same, and shall cause them to be served on the president and
members of the board of trustees by leaving a copy of such notice at the
residence of each member or personally delivering the same to each of said
members, at least forty eight (48) hours before time of meeting; such notices
shall describe in brief the nature or objects of the call. (Ord. 95-925, 3-30-
1995; amd. Ord. 15-1485, 9-3-2015)
   (B)   Electronic Attendance: Every ordinance or resolution shall be reduced
to writing and presented to the mayor and board of trustees before a vote is to
be taken. Any meeting of the board of trustees at which a quorum of the board
is physically present may be attended by a trustee by means of audio or video
means under the following conditions:
      1.   The trustee cannot physically be present at a village board meeting
due to personal illness, employment or village related matters, or family
emergencies.
      2.   The trustee desiring to attend the village board meeting by audio or
video means must notify the village clerk in advance.
      3.   The trustee's voice, on an audio conference, after being duly
identified, shall be broadcast to the public at the meeting.
      4.   The trustee shall state the reason for not being physically present
at the meeting.
      5.   The village board minutes shall reflect compliance with these rules
and regulations. (Ord. 15-1485, 9-3-2015)
1-3-2: ORDER OF BUSINESS:
The following order of business shall be adhered to in all meetings of the
board unless suspended by the unanimous consent of members present:
First: At the hour selected for the meeting, the clerk, or someone appointed to
fill his place, shall proceed to call the roll of members, mark the absentees
and announce whether a quorum be present. Upon the appearance of a quorum the
board shall be called to order, the president taking the chair if present, and
the board appointing a temporary chairman if he should be absent. If a quorum
does not appear, the Board shall not thereby stand adjourned unless by a vote
of the members present. When a quorum is present the Board shall proceed to the
business before it, which shall be conducted in the following order.
Second: Reading and approval of minutes of former meeting or meetings.
Third: Reading of communications, petitions and reference or disposition
thereof.
Fourth: Reading, considering and disposing of bills and claims against the
Village.
Fifth: Reports of standing committees and officers and action on such reports.
Sixth: Reports of special committees and action thereof.
Seventh: Presentation of resolutions and ordinances and disposition thereof.
Eighth: Unfinished business and passage of ordinances or resolutions previously
considered.
Ninth: New business; fixing time for adjournment.
Tenth: Adjournment.
All questions relating to the priority of business shall be decided by the
Chair without debate, subject to appeal. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940; amd. Ord. 125, 2-
19-1959)
1-3-3: DUTIES AND PRIVILEGES OF THE PRESIDENT:
   (A)   The Chief Executive Officer of the Village shall be a citizen of the
United States, a qualified elector and shall reside within the corporate limits
of the Village. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940; amd. Ord. 125, 2-19-1959)
   (B)   The President shall, before he enters upon the duties of his office,
execute a bond to the Village in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00)
with sureties to be approved by the Board of Trustees as conditioned by law.
(Ord. 96-988, 12-19-1996)
   (C)   If a vacancy occurs in the Office of the President by reason of
resignation, failure to elect or qualify, death, permanent physical or mental
disability, conviction of a disqualifying crime, abandonment of office, or
removal from office or by removal of his residence from the Village, the most
senior Trustee shall be the Acting President until the election of a new
President as provided by the General Election Law. In the event said senior
Trustee is unable or unwilling to serve in the capacity of Acting President,
then the next senior Trustee will be the Acting President until an election is
held pursuant to the general election law. The Acting President shall perform
the duties and possess all the rights and powers of the President until a
successor has been elected. (Ord. 95-961, 10-5-1995)
   (D)   If the Village President is temporarily absent, but a vacancy in the
office has not been created, the most senior Trustee shall be designated as the
President Pro Tem. The President Pro Tem shall have all the powers and duties
of the office until the return of the Village President but shall not be
entitled to vote as the President Pro Tem and as Trustee. (Ord. 05-1179, 6-27-
2005)
   (E)   If the President, at any time during the term of his office, shall
remove from the limits of the Village so that he is no longer a bona fide
resident and legal voter, his office shall thereby become vacant.
   (F)   The President shall preside at all meetings of the Board of Trustees,
but shall not vote, except in case of a tie, when he shall cast the deciding
vote.
   (G)   The President shall be ex officio member of all standing and appointed
committees and of special committees appointed from time to time, and if
present at such meetings, at his option, he may preside.
   (H)   The President shall exercise within the corporate limits of the
Village the powers conferred upon Sheriffs in the State to suppress disorder
and keep the peace.
   (I)   The President may in his discretion release any person imprisoned for
violation of any provision of this Code and shall report such release, giving
his reasons therefor, to the Board of Trustees at its next regular meeting
thereafter.
   (J)   The President shall have power, when necessary, to call on every male
inhabitant over the age of eighteen (18) years to aid in enforcing the laws, in
suppressing riots and other disorderly conduct or for the purpose of carrying
into effect the laws and, subject to the authority of the Governor of the
State, as Commander in Chief of the militia, the President may call out the
militia to aid in suppressing riots and other disorderly conduct within the
corporate limits of the Village.
   (K)   The President shall sign all commissions and permits granted by the
authority of the Board of Trustees and grant all licenses and may revoke the
said licenses, except as otherwise provided by law, or ordinance, and he shall
perform such other acts as may be required by law or ordinance.
   (L)   He shall supervise the conduct of all officers of the Village, examine
the grounds of all reasonable complaints made against any of them, and cause
all their violations of duty and other neglects to be properly punished or
reported to the proper tribunal for correction.
   (M)   He shall appoint, by and with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees, all officers whose appointment is not, by the laws of the State or
the ordinances of the Village, otherwise provided for, and whenever any vacancy
shall occur in any office which by law or ordinance he is empowered to fill, he
shall, within thirty (30) days after the happening of such vacancy, communicate
to said Board the name of this appointee to such office; and pending the
concurrence of the Board of Trustees in such appointment, the President may
appoint some suitable person to discharge the duties of such office.
   (N)   He shall have the right to veto under State law, all ordinances,
resolutions and orders passed by the Board of Trustees; the Trustees, by a two-
thirds (2/3) vote of all the members elected, may pass said ordinances,
resolutions or orders over the veto of the President 1 .
   (O)   He shall be and is hereby authorized to sign in behalf of the Village
all instruments necessary to the prompt prosecution or defense of any or all
actions brought by or against said Village, including bonds for injunction.
   (P)   The presiding officer shall preserve order and decorum and may speak
to points of order in preference of other members rising from his seat for that
purpose, and shall decide all questions of order, subject to an appeal to the
Village Board, on which appeal no member shall speak more than once without the
unanimous consent of the Board.
   (Q)   While the presiding officer is putting the question, or while business
is being transacted, no member shall walk across or out of the Village Board
room, except by consent of the Board.
   (R)   Every member, previous to his speaking, making a motion or seconding
the same, shall rise from his seat and address himself to the presiding officer
and say "Mr. President" but shall not proceed with his remarks until recognized
and named by the Chair.
   (S)   When two (2) or more members rise at once, the presiding officer shall
name the one who is first to speak.
   (T)   In case of any disturbance or disorderly conduct, the presiding
officer shall have the power to require the room to be cleared if necessary.
(Ord. 1, 6-20-1940; amd. Ord. 95-961, 10-5-1995)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-11-19.
1-3-4: DUTIES AND PRIVILEGES OF MEMBERS:
   (A)   When a member wishes to present a communication, petition order,
resolution or other original matter, he shall rise in his place and briefly
state its nature before presenting the same.
   (B)   No member, without leave of the Board, shall speak more than once upon
the same subject, until every member desirous of speaking shall have spoken;
and no member shall speak longer than five (5) minutes at any one time except
by consent of the Board. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-5: CALL TO ORDER:
A member called to order by the Chair shall immediately sit down, unless
permitted to explain; if there be no appeal, the decision of the Chair shall be
conclusive, but if the member appeals from the decision of the Chair, the Board
shall decide on the question. While a member is speaking, no member shall hold
any private discourse. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-6: VOTE REQUIRED:
   (A)   Voting; Exceptions: Every member who shall be present when a question
is stated from the Chair shall vote thereon, unless excused by the Board, or
unless he is directly interested in the question, in which case he shall not
vote. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940; amd. Ord. 16-1515, 9-8-2016)
   (B)   Voting By Audio/Video Means: Every ordinance or resolution shall be
reduced to writing and presented to the Mayor and Board of Trustees before a
vote is to be taken. Any meeting of the Board of Trustees at which a quorum of
the Board is physically present may be attended by a Trustee by means of audio
or video means under the following conditions:
      1.   The Trustee cannot physically be present at a Village Board meeting
due to personal illness, employment or Village related matters, or family
emergencies.
      2.   The Trustee desiring to attend the Village Board meeting by audio or
video means must notify the Village Clerk in advance.
      3.   The Trustee's voice, on an audio conference, after being duly
identified, shall be broadcasted to the public at the meeting.
      4.   The Trustee shall state the reason for not being physically present
at the meeting.
      5.   The Village Board minutes shall reflect compliance with these rules
and regulations. (Ord. 16-1515, 9-8-2016)
1-3-7: ATTENDANCE:
No member shall be allowed to leave the Board while in session, unless excused
by the presiding officer. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-8: MOTIONS AND RESOLUTIONS:
   (A)   Any matter before the Board may be set down as a special order of
business at a certain time if two-thirds (2/3) of the Trustees present vote in
the affirmative, but not otherwise.
   (B)   No motion shall be put or debated unless it be seconded. When a motion
is seconded, it shall be stated by the presiding officer before debate, and
every such motion shall be reduced to writing and the proposer of the motion
shall be entitled to the floor.
   (C)   After a motion or resolution is stated by the presiding officer, it
shall be deemed to be in possession of the Board, but may be withdrawn at any
time before decision or amendment by unanimous consent of the Board.
   (D)   If the question under consideration contains several distinct
propositions, any member may have the same divided when the contents permit.
   (E)   In all cases where a resolution or motion is entered on the minutes of
the board, the names of the members moving and seconding the same shall be
entered also.
   (F)   All resolutions and amendments of rules or ordinances before being
presented shall be reduced to writing and handed to the clerk and read by him.
   (G)   If any member requires it, and upon the passage of all ordinances or
upon the proposal to expend any monies or create a liability, the yeas and nays
shall be taken and entered upon the minutes; but the yeas and nays shall not be
taken unless called for previous to any vote on the question and except as
above recited. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-9: PRECEDENCE OF QUESTIONS:
   (A)   When a blank is to be filled and different sums or times proposed, the
question shall be taken first on the lesser sum or the longest time.
   (B)   When a question is under debate, the only motion in order shall be: 1)
to adjourn to a day certain; 2) to adjourn; 3) to lay on the table; 4) the
previous question; 5) to refer; 6) to amend; 7) to substitute; 8) to postpone
indefinitely or to a certain day. Numbers 2, 3, and 4 to be decided without
debate. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-10: ADJOURNMENT:
   (A)   A motion to adjourn the board shall always be in order except:
      1.   When a member is in possession of the floor;
      2.   While the yeas and nays are being called;
      3.   When the members are voting;
      4.   When adjournment was the last preceding motion; and
      5.   When it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken.
   (B)   A motion simply to adjourn cannot be amended or debated, but a motion
to adjourn to a time named may be and is open to debate. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-11: PREVIOUS QUESTIONS:
When the previous question is moved and seconded, it shall be put in this form:
"Shall the main question now be put?" If this is carried, all further
amendments and all further motions and debates shall be excluded and the
question put without delay upon the pending amendments in proper order, and
then upon the main question. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-12: TO LAY ON THE TABLE:
A motion to simply lay a question on the table is not debatable, but a motion
to lay on the table and publish, or any other condition, is subject to
amendment and debate.
A motion to take a subject matter from the table may be proposed at the same
meeting, provided two-thirds (2/3) of the trustees present vote therefor. (Ord.
1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-13: INDEFINITE POSTPONEMENT:
When a motion is postponed indefinitely, it shall not be again taken up at the
same meeting. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-14: TO REFER:
A motion to refer to a standing committee shall take precedence of a similar
motion for a special committee. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-15: TO AMEND:
   (A)   A motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but one to amend an
amendment to an amendment shall not be entertained.
   (B)   An amendment modifying the intention of a motion shall be in order,
but an amendment relating to a different subject shall not be in order.
   (C)   On an amendment to "strike out and insert", the paragraph to be
amended shall first be read as it stands,then the words proposed to be stricken
out, and then those to be inserted, and finally, the paragraph as it will stand
if so amended shall be read. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-16: TO SUBSTITUTE:
A substitute for an original proposition in debate may be entertained when
further amendment is not admissible, and if accepted by the mover of such
original proposition, or by the board by vote, it shall entirely supersede such
original proposition, and cut off all amendments appertaining thereto. (Ord. 1,
6-20-1940)
1-3-17: RECONSIDERATION:
   (A)   A vote or question may be reconsidered at any time during the same
meeting, or at the first regular meeting held thereafter. A motion for
reconsideration being once made and decided in the negative, shall not be
renewed, nor shall a vote to reconsider be reconsidered.
   (B)   No vote of the board of trustees shall be reconsidered or rescinded at
a special meeting, unless at such special meeting there be present as large a
number of trustees as were present when such vote was taken.
   (C)   A motion to reconsider must be made and seconded by members who voted
in the majority.
Provided, however, that where a motion is lost by reason of not receiving a
two-thirds (2/3) vote required for its passage, a motion to reconsider may be
made and seconded by those voting in the minority. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-18: PRECEDENCE OF BUSINESS:
The board shall at all adjourned regular meetings resume business at the same
order in which it was engaged immediately preceding the last adjournment, with
the exception of orders numbers 1, 2, 3 and 4, which shall be called and
disposed of before resuming business, as herein provided. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-19: STANDING COMMITTEES:
All standing committees shall be appointed by the president at or before the
second regular meeting in each municipal year, or as soon thereafter as may be
practical, and whenever any vacancy shall occur. Special committees shall also
be appointed by the president, unless otherwise ordered by the board.
There shall be seven (7) standing committees, consisting of three (3) members
each, and the president shall be ex officio a member and chairman of each of
the said committees, which are as follows:
   (A)   Committee on finance.
   (B)   Committee on police.
   (C)   Committee on public works.
   (D)   Committee on public relations.
   (E)   Committee on policy.
   (F)   Committee on fire.
   (G)   Committee on water. (Ord. 553, 5-1968; amd. Ord. 07-1237, 7-19-2007)
1-3-20: JURISDICTION OF COMMITTEES:
   (A)   Unless in case of emergency, committee meetings shall be called at
least forty eight (48) hours prior to the time of meeting, and each member
shall attend promptly at the hour stated in the notice, or, if unable so to do,
shall notify the chairman of the committee to that effect.
   (B)   All ordinances, petitions, resolutions, orders and communications to
the board may be referred to appropriate committees to be announced by the
chair, but such ordinances, petitions, resolutions or orders and communications
may be acted on without such reference. (Ord. 95-926, 3-30-1995)
1-3-21: REPORTS OF COMMITTEES:
Standing and special committees to whom references are made shall in all cases
report at least once in each month, unless further time be granted by a vote of
the board, the state or facts with their opinion thereon, signed by the members
concurring therein. Minority reports may be received at the same time with
majority reports.
All reports of committees, if in writing, shall be addressed "to the president
and board of trustees".
They shall briefly describe the matter referred and the conclusion shall be
summed up in the form of an ordinance, order, resolution, recommendation, or
some other distinct proposition. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-22: GENERAL PROVISION:
   (A)   Any ordinance may be finally passed by the board at the same meeting
at which such ordinance is introduced, except objection is made to such action
as specified in the statutes of Illinois, and in such cases of objection said
ordinances shall be laid over until the next regular meeting unless such
objections are withdrawn.
   (B)   The yeas and nays shall be taken upon the passage of all ordinances,
and on all propositions to create any liability against the village, or for the
expenditure or appropriation of any money, and a concurrence of a majority of
all the members elected shall be necessary to the passage of any such ordinance
or proposition. It shall require three-fourths (3/4) of all the members elected
to sell any village property.
   (C)   All bills against the village shall be referred to the proper
committee; such committee shall examine such bills and approve the same in
writing; and the same shall then be ready for payment upon the finance
committee approving the same and the requisite vote of the board, but not
otherwise. This rule shall apply to all bills and expenses incurred by the
village. Any bill or bills adversely reported by the above committee shall be,
on the request of any two (2) trustees, referred to a special committee before
the same is disallowed, and in all cases receipts must be taken for money paid
out, and a proper voucher of bill shall accompany each account presented. (Ord.
1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-23: SUSPENSION OF RULES:
These rules may be temporarily suspended by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the
trustees present, but shall not be repealed, altered or amended unless notice
thereof shall have been given in writing, and the alteration or amendment
submitted at least one meeting prior thereto, and two-thirds (2/3) of all the
trustees entitled by law to be elected shall concur therein. (Ord. 1, 6-20-
1940)
1-3-24: CENSURE:
   (A)   Any member acting or appearing in a disgraceful manner, or who uses
opprobrious or insulting language to or about any member of the board of
trustees, or who does not obey the order of the chair, shall be on motion
censured by a majority vote of the members present.
   (B)   No person not a member of the village board shall address the board
without the consent of a majority of the members present.
   (C)   The rules of parliamentary practice comprised in "Robert's Rules Of
Order" shall govern the board in all cases to which they are applicable, and in
which they are not inconsistent with the standing rules of the board.
   (D)   A quorum shall be the presence of at least four (4) members of the
board duly qualified and acting. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
1-3-25: SALARY:
Each member of the board of trustees shall receive as compensation an amount
designated in section
1-16-1 of this title for each meeting of the board of trustees actually
attended by him. (Ord. 125, 2-19-1959)
1-3-26: CLERK:
   (A)   The village clerk shall, before entering upon the duties of his
office, execute to the village a bond in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) with sureties to be approved by the board of trustees, conditioned
as provided by law. (Ord. 125, 2-19-1959)
   (B)   In addition to the duties now imposed upon that officer by law, he
shall affix the corporate seal to all papers which shall require it. He shall
also sign and issue all licenses and permits, as so ordered by the president,
board of trustees or other proper officer of the village, and collect the fees
therefor. He shall sign, seal and number all bonds issued by the village, and
keep a true and correct account of the same.
   (C)   All petitions, remonstrances, bids, bills or other communications,
addressed to the president or board of trustees, shall be received by the clerk
and read by him, at the meeting of the board of trustees next succeeding their
receipt by him, unless otherwise ordered by the board of trustees.
   (D)   He shall without delay deliver to the officers of the village and to
the proper committees of the board of trustees, all resolutions and
communications referred to such officers or committees, by the board of
trustees.
   (E)   He shall without delay deliver to the president, all ordinances or
resolutions under his charge which may require approval or action by the
president, with all the papers relating to same.
   (F)   All applications for licenses to be issued by the village shall be
made to the clerk, who shall have power to hear and grant applications
therefor, and each and every license authorized or required shall be issued by
the clerk upon the proper application therefor and the payment to him of the
amount of the license fee as provided in this code.
   (G)   It shall also be the duty of the clerk to keep strict, accurate and
detailed accounts of all monies and funds of the village, as well as of all the
receipts, expenses, outlays, disbursements and expenditures thereof, the same
to be so systematized and arranged under their proper title or heading, that
each separate fund and account will plainly and clearly show its own particular
debit and credit, as well as to or from whom, when and on what account, the
same was received or paid out.
   (H)   He shall also keep or cause to be kept correct books, showing all
monies by him collected and on what account, the exact conditions or the
particular funds or appropriations of said village, and all unexpended balances
thereof, the indebtedness of said village in detail, whether bonded or
otherwise, and generally the exact financial condition of the village so far as
practicable. The books so kept shall be in such form as the board of trustees
may from time to time prescribe by resolution or ordinance.
   (I)   The clerk shall prepare and keep a record of all ordinances passed by
the village board in a book to be known as "ordinance record", in which shall
be transcribed a correct copy of all ordinances and at the foot of the record
of each ordinance so recorded the clerk shall make a memorandum of the date of
the passage and of the publication or posting of such ordinance, which record
and memorandum or a certified copy thereof shall be prima facie evidence of the
passage and legal publication or posting of such ordinance for all purposes
whatsoever.
   (J)   He shall keep a full record of all licenses granted, transferred or
revoked by authority of the board of trustees, with the date that the same were
granted, transferred or revoked (and if revoked, the cause therefor), with the
number thereof, and full name and residence of the applicants for such
licenses, in a book to be kept by him for that purpose, and, where bonds are
required, the names of the bondsmen or sureties.
   (K)   It shall be the duty of the clerk within five (5) days after the
result of any election is declared or appointment made, to notify all persons
elected or appointed to any village office, or their election or appointment,
and unless such persons shall respectively qualify in ten (10) days after such
notice, the office shall become vacant.
   (L)   He shall attend all meetings of the board of trustees and keep a full
record of all proceedings in the journal; keep all records received, mark and
properly file all papers coming to his office belonging to the village, and
execute such orders as he may receive from the board of trustees. He shall
also, after they are passed, cause all ordinances of the village, imposing any
fine, penalty, imprisonment or forfeiture, or making any appropriation, to be
published or posted as the board of trustees shall designate in accordance with
the state statutes.
   (M)   He shall prepare and deliver all licenses and bonds on receipt of the
required sums of money therefor, countersign all warrants and deliver the same
when called for, taking a proper receipt for the same, and generally do and
perform such other duties as may be required of him by the board of trustees
and the provisions of this code.
   (N)   He shall be the custodian and keeper of the corporate seal and of all
the books, records, ordinances and papers of the village except as otherwise
provided by law or ordinance 1 .
   (O)   It shall be the duty of the clerk, within the time prescribed by law,
in each year, to file with the county clerk of Cook County, Illinois, a
certified copy of an ordinance in which the total amount of appropriations for
all corporate purposes of the village legally made, are levied and assessed.
(Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
   (P)   The clerk's job shall be a full time position, compensable by such sum
or sums per annum as the board of trustees of the village shall appropriate
from time to time to be paid in monthly installments. The clerk shall
faithfully perform all duties imposed upon him by ordinance, statute, or order
of the president and board of trustees in conformance with existing statutes
and duties imposed by this ordinance. (Ord. 87-783, 8-27-1987)
   (Q)   The said clerk shall pay into the treasury of the village all fees
collected by him, and also all fees and compensation paid to him by any person
for his services as such clerk for certified copies of documents or otherwise
or in the discharge of the duties hereinbefore mentioned, and he shall make
such payments to the village treasurer of such fees and all other monies of the
village received or collected by him. The said clerk shall also report to the
board of trustees at each regular meeting, the amount of all monies received
and turned over by him, showing by whom and for what purpose the respective
amounts were paid to him. (Ord. 1, 6-20-1940)
   (R)   The clerk shall be registrar of vital statistics for the municipality.
A report of all births, still births, and deaths shall be made to the local
registrar of vital statistics, which report shall contain all information
required by the "act to provide for the registration of all births, still
births, and deaths in the state of Illinois, and to repeal an act herein
named", approved June 22, 1915 as amended.
   (S)   The local registrar shall keep a record showing all births, still
births, and deaths occurring within the municipality, which record shall
include all information required to be kept by the act hereinabove described.
(Ord. 48, 9-2-1943)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-10-7.
1-3-27: DEPUTY CLERK:
There is hereby created the office of deputy clerk whose function shall be to
perform all the duties and assume the responsibilities of said village clerk at
such time or times as he may be temporarily incapacitated or while absent from
the place where his office is maintained. Said deputy clerk shall also have the
power and duty to execute all documents required by any law to be executed by
the village clerk, and to affix the seal of the village thereto wherever
required. In signing any document, said deputy clerk shall sign the name of the
village clerk followed by the word "by" and the deputy clerk's own name and the
words "deputy clerk". (Res., 12-17-1964)
CHAPTER 4
OATHS; BONDS
SECTION:
1-4-1: Oath
1-4-2: Officer's Oath Required
1-4-3: Bond Required
1-4-1: OATH:
The oath of office for all elective and appointive officers of the village
shall be in the following form:
I,                   , do solemnly swear that I will support the Constitution
of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and that I
will faithfully discharge the duties of (office) of the Village of Bedford
Park, in the County of Cook and State of Illinois, according to the best of my
ability.
(Ord. 2, 6-20-1940)
1-4-2: OFFICER'S OATH REQUIRED:
All elective and appointive officers shall take and subscribe to said oath
before assuming the duties of their office. (Ord. 2, 6-20-1940)
1-4-3: BOND REQUIRED:
Before entering upon the duties of his or her office or position, each of the
following designated officers and employees of the village shall execute and
post a bond in favor of and running to the village in the sum set forth after
such public office or position, with surety or sureties to be approved by the
president and board of trustees, conditioned upon the faithful and legal
performance of the duties of such officer or employee giving the bond:
Board of trustees                   $50,000.00 commercial crime policy
Deputy village clerk                50,000.00 commercial crime policy
Fire chief                          50,000.00 commercial crime policy
Police chief                        50,000.00 commercial crime policy
Police officers                     50,000.00 commercial crime policy
President of the board of trustees  50,000.00 commercial crime policy
Public works superintendent         50,000.00 commercial crime policy
Village administrator               10,000.00 surety bond
Village clerk                       50,000.00 commercial crime policy
Village treasurer                   50,000.00 public official bond
Water department supervisor         50,000.00 commercial crime policy
 
(Ord. 95-929, 3-30-1995)
CHAPTER 5
TREASURER-COLLECTOR
SECTION:
1-5-1: Qualifications
1-5-2: Bond
1-5-3: Guidance
1-5-4: Receiving And Paying Warrants And Bonds
1-5-5: Account Of Each Fund
1-5-6: Special Assessment Accounts
1-5-7: Transfer Of Money From One Fund To Another
1-5-8: Must Render Account Each Month
1-5-9: Canceled Warrants
1-5-10: Deliver Books And Money To Successor
1-5-11: Keep Books At Village Hall
1-5-12: Balance Books Each Month
1-5-13: Semiannual Interest
1-5-14: Interest Received
1-5-15: Depositories
1-5-16: Keep Clerk's Bond
1-5-17: Duties
1-5-1: QUALIFICATIONS:
The village treasurer shall be appointed by the village president with the
advice and consent of the village board on an annual basis. The treasurer shall
also assume the responsibility of the village collector with no additional
compensation. (Ord. 11-1354, 6-2-2011)
1-5-2: BOND:
The treasurer, before entering upon the duties of his office, shall execute
bond with good and sufficient sureties, to be approved by the board and in such
amount as the board shall determine, in a sum not less than ten percent (10%)
of the highest amount of taxes and special assessments received by him or his
predecessors during any fiscal year in the preceding five (5) fiscal years nor
less than one and one-half (11/2) times the largest amount which the corporate
authorities estimate will be in his custody at any one time. In no event shall
the bond be less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) conditioned to the
faithful discharge of the duties of his office, which bond shall be payable to
the village and filed in the office of the clerk. (Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
1-5-3: GUIDANCE:
In the performance of his duties as treasurer and collector as herein provided,
he shall in all respects and at all times take cognizance of and be governed by
the statutes of the state of Illinois relating to the duties of treasurer and
collector in cities and villages and the ordinances of the village. (Ord. 5, 6-
20-1940)
1-5-4: RECEIVING AND PAYING WARRANTS AND BONDS:
He shall keep a true and accurate account of all monies paid into the treasury,
and from whom and on what account received; he shall only pay out such sums of
money as may be ordered by the president and board of trustees, and only on
warrants therefor signed by the president and clerk, and bonds and interest
coupons regularly and duly issued by the village. (Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
1-5-5: ACCOUNT OF EACH FUND:
The books which must be kept by the treasurer shall at all times show the exact
condition of the monies under his control, of each account and appropriation,
and of all receipts and disbursements, and such books, together with all other
belongings of the village, and in his custody, shall be by him handed over to
his successor. The treasurer shall upon receipt of all monies, enter and
apportion the same to the credit of the several accounts upon which such monies
are paid stating from whom they are received. He shall keep a separate account
with each fund or appropriation, stating at the head of each account the amount
so appropriated, and giving the several debits and credits belonging thereto.
(Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
1-5-6: SPECIAL ASSESSMENT ACCOUNTS:
He shall also keep an account of each special assessment, and each installment
thereof, under its general description and number and said account shall show
at its head the amount assessed for public benefits and also that for special
benefits. All monies received on any special assessment shall be held by the
treasurer as a special fund and placed to the credit of the particular
installment upon which it has been paid and shall be applied to the payment of
bonds or warrants payable out of said installment when collected according to
the terms thereof, and said money shall be used for no other purpose whatever,
provided that when a particular installment of any assessment has been fully
paid and all warrants or bonds, payable out of said installment, have been
canceled and paid according to the tenor thereafter, then, any surplus
remaining in the installment, after the retirement of all bonds and warrants
payable out of said installment, shall be credited pro rata among the remaining
installments of such assessment; and provided further that when all the
installments of such assessment have been collected and all warrants and bonds
payable out of said assessment, or any installment thereof, have been fully
paid and canceled, any surplus remaining shall be rebated pro rata to the
persons assessed for the improvement for which said assessment has been levied,
and it shall be the duty of the treasurer to report said surplus, whenever any
such surplus may exist after retiring and paying all bonds and warrants payable
out of any assessment. (Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
1-5-7: TRANSFER OF MONEY FROM ONE FUND TO ANOTHER:
No money shall be paid by the treasurer upon any warrant, bond or coupon,
except from the monies belonging to the particular fund or appropriation upon
which said warrant shall have been drawn, nor shall money be transferred by the
treasurer from one fund to another after it has been received by him; nor
appropriated to any other purpose than that for which it has been collected or
paid, except by authority of the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 5, 6-
20-1940)
1-5-8: MUST RENDER ACCOUNT EACH MONTH:
The treasurer shall, at the end of each and every month, and more often, if
required, render an account to the president and board of trustees under oath,
showing his receipts and disbursements in detail during the month, and the
state and condition of every account not closed in his books, the whole to be a
balance sheet, and a complete abstract of the financial affairs of the village.
He shall also annually, by January 30 of each year make out and file with the
clerk a full and detailed account of all such receipts and expenditures, and of
all his transactions as such treasurer during the preceding fiscal year, and
shall show in such account the state of the treasury at the close of the fiscal
year; and publish the same in a newspaper published in the village, and in case
there is no newspaper published in said village, then by posting a copy thereof
in a conspicuous place in the clerk's office. (Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
1-5-9: CANCELED WARRANTS:
The treasurer shall cancel all warrants paid out and redeemed by him, and, upon
the rendition of any monthly report, he shall, when requested, cause the same
to be accompanied by all warrants, duplicate receipts in detail, for all money
received, and such other vouchers as will fully and entirely cover his
transactions during the period of such report. (Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
1-5-10: DELIVER BOOKS AND MONEY TO SUCCESSOR:
Whenever his term of office shall expire, whether caused by resignation,
removal from the village or removal from office by the president and board of
trustees, the appointment of a successor, or other cause, it shall be the duty
of such treasurer or person at once to deliver to his successor in office, or
such other person as may be specially designated by resolution of the president
and board of trustees, all monies, property, books and effects of every
description in his possession, belonging to said village or appertaining to his
office, and shall also at once account for any pay over to such successor or
other person so designated all monies that he shall be accountable for and owe
to said village in his capacity as treasurer. Any person who, having acted as
treasurer, shall, on the expiration of his term of office in any of the ways
above mentioned, violate any provisions of this code, shall be liable for all
damages caused thereby and shall further forfeit and pay said village a penalty
of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred
dollars ($200.00). (Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
1-5-11: KEEP BOOKS AT VILLAGE HALL:
He shall keep all books, papers, vouchers, warrants, documents, and other
written instruments appertaining to his office, in the village hall, all of
which shall be open to inspection of the president or board of trustees at any
time. (Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
1-5-12: BALANCE BOOKS EACH MONTH:
The books of account herein provided to be kept by such treasurer shall be by
him properly balanced at least once in each month, in such manner that the
same, when so balanced, shall show the true status and condition of each and
every account therein. (Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
1-5-13: SEMIANNUAL INTEREST:
The treasurer shall, upon the demand of the legal owner of any final judgment
heretofore rendered or which may hereafter be rendered against the tillage, pay
the legal and statutory interest thereon semiannually in the months of January
and July in each year until such judgment is paid, or until payment thereof is
tendered by the village. (Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
1-5-14: INTEREST RECEIVED:
The treasurer shall credit the village with all interest received by him, or
paid to him by any bank or banks, or person or persons having any funds of the
village on deposit, or otherwise. (Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
1-5-15: DEPOSITORIES:
Banks and savings and loan associations meeting the requirements set forth in
the criteria are hereby designated as financial institutions in which village
monies may be invested pursuant to Illinois statutes as amended; and that
monies of this village may be deposited or invested therein from time to time,
at the discretion of the treasurer, or intermediary serving as agent of the
treasurer, acting on behalf of this village; and that the treasurer may, from
time to time, acquire guarantees, in addition to federal insurance, for prompt
return of invested and deposited monies; and that a current copy of the
criteria be placed in the minutes of the meeting at which this ordinance was
adopted; and that notice of modifications made to the criteria from time to
time by the treasurer be provided to the board when made. (Ord. 90-823, 7-5-
1990)
1-5-16: KEEP CLERK'S BOND:
The treasurer shall safely keep the official bond of the clerk and deputy
clerk. (Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
1-5-17: DUTIES:
He shall perform all duties required of him by any provision of this code.
(Ord. 5, 6-20-1940)
CHAPTER 6
FISCAL YEAR
SECTION:
1-6-1: Fiscal Year
1-6-1: FISCAL YEAR:
The fiscal year of the village shall begin on January 1 of each year and end on
December 31 of that year. (Ord. 94-901, 2-3-1994)
CHAPTER 7
SEAL

1-7-1: Created

1-7-3: Form Of Seal
1-7-1: CREATED:
There shall be and there is hereby created a village seal. (Ord. 3, 6-20-1940)
1-7-2: USE OF SEAL:
The seal shall be used as is prescribed by law for the authentication of all
documents and papers as may be required by the laws of the state and the
provisions of this code. (Ord. 3, 6-20-1940)
1-7-3: FORM OF SEAL:
The outline and form of said seal shall be as follows:
(Ord. 526, 8-5-1966)
CHAPTER 8
ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-8-1: Office Created
1-8-2: Duties
1-8-3: Reports
1-8-4: Opinions
1-8-5: Books; Records
1-8-6: Bond
1-8-7: Compensation
1-8-1: OFFICE CREATED:
There is hereby created an office of the village to be known as village
attorney, whose term of office shall be for one year, and he to hold his office
until his successor is appointed and qualified. Such officer shall be appointed
by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees and he
may be a nonresident 1 . (Ord. 6, 6-20-1940)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-5.
1-8-2: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the attorney to give the necessary attention to all
suits or judicial proceedings in which the village is a party or directly
interested. He shall appear as the attorney in behalf of any officer of the
village in any suit, prosecution or other judicial proceeding brought by or
against such officer in his official character, and as the case may require,
shall prosecute or defend to the termination thereof. (Ord. 6, 6-20-1940)
1-8-3: REPORTS:
He shall attend the meetings of the board of trustees, and on or before its
first meeting each year, make a report in writing to the said board, duly
verified by his oath, if required, of all suits, prosecutions or actions
prosecuted or defended by him during the preceding year, of the names of the
parties thereof, of the title of the courts in which they were commenced, of
their progress and final disposition, and other information concerning the
legal interests of the village which he may deem necessary or proper, and
perform such services as may be required of him by the president. (Ord. 6, 6-
20-1940)
1-8-4: OPINIONS:
He shall give his legal opinions in writing to the board of trustees, or
committees thereof, or the president, when requested, on legal questions
arising under or concerning any legal questions and subjects in which the
village shall be legally interested. (Ord. 6, 6-20-1940)
1-8-5: BOOKS; RECORDS:
He shall keep in proper books provided for the purpose a docket of all suits
prosecuted or defended by him in which shall be briefly entered all steps taken
in each case, and such books and records shall be the property of the village.
(Ord. 6, 6-20-1940)
1-8-6: BOND:
He shall execute a bond with sureties satisfactory to the board of trustees in
the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for the faithful discharge of his
duties. (Ord. 125, 2-19-1959)
1-8-7: COMPENSATION:
For his compensation his duties shall be to attend meetings, draft general
ordinances for the village and furnish counsel and advice to the president and
board of trustees and the officers of the village as designated in chapter 16
of this title, and he shall be allowed further compensation and reasonable fee
for the trial of any lawsuits in court, where the village or any of its
officers in their official capacity are parties, and also a reasonable
compensation for attendance upon the board of local improvements, and the
making of special assessments, and the conducting of the legal proceedings in
the county, or in other courts of Cook County, to levy assessments, pay the
costs of such improvements and the drafting of contracts, records and
proceedings in and about such special assessments, in addition to such yearly
compensation above specified and which shall be fixed by the president and
board of trustees. (1965 Code)
CHAPTER 9
VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
SECTION:
1-9-1: Creation Of Office
1-9-2: Appointment To Office
1-9-3: Removal From Office
1-9-4: Duties Of Office
1-9-5: Employee Matters
1-9-6: Surety Bond
1-9-7: Compensation
1-9-1: CREATION OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created the office of village administrator for the village.
(Ord. 95-928, 3-30-1995)
1-9-2: APPOINTMENT TO OFFICE:
The village administrator shall be appointed by the president with the advice
and consent of the board of trustees. Said appointment shall be based upon his/
her executive and administrative qualifications with special reference to
actual experience in or knowledge of accepted practice in respect to the duties
of the office of village administrator. (Ord. 00-1045, 2-17-2000)
1-9-3: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The administrator's position shall be reviewed on an annual basis by the
village president and board of trustees. (Ord. 05-1183, 8-17-2005)
1-9-4: DUTIES OF OFFICE:
The administrator's powers and duties shall be determined by the village
president. The administrator shall be responsible to the president and board of
trustees for the proper administration of his/her duties. The village
administrator may be required to do the following: (Ord. 01-1092, 10-4-2001)
   (A)   The administrator shall have the expertise and knowledge to monitor
the operation of each village department and to oversee the daily
administrative affairs of the village including direct supervision of all
departments. However, the administrator shall not have the authority to hire or
terminate any employees without the president's and village board's approval.
(Ord. 05-1183, 8-17-2005)
   (B)   Upon direction by the village president and board of trustees, he or
she shall prepare personnel policies and practices including, but not limited
to, pay schedules, job descriptions, vacation and sick leave policies, leave of
absence policies, and any other personnel related matters.
   (C)   Upon receiving instructions from the village president and board of
trustees, the administrator shall prepare the annual budget with department
supervisors annually and submit it to the village president and board of
trustees, together with a message describing the important features and be
responsible for its administration after the adoption.
   (D)   Cooperate with auditor on annual basis in the preparation of the
appropriation ordinance for the village president's and board of trustees'
review.
   (E)   Submit to the village president and board of trustees, as of the end
of the fiscal year, a complete review on the finances and administrative
activities of the village for the preceding year.
   (F)   Keep the village president and board of trustees fully advised of the
financial condition and future needs of the village, and make such
recommendations as may be deemed desirable.
   (G)   Recommend to the village president and board of trustees, from time to
time, adoption of such measures as the administrator may deem necessary or
expedient for the health, safety or welfare of the community or for the
improvement of administrative services.
   (H)   Attend all regular meetings of the village board unless excused
therefrom. Prepare and submit all departmental reports to the chairmen of the
respective departments. (Ord. 01-1092, 10-4-2001)
   (I)   The village administrator shall be the general purchasing agent of the
village and shall make purchases for all departments except where specific
provisions are contrary to the provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes,
village policy, village ordinance or a directive from the village board. The
administrator shall make all purchases of supplies, materials and equipment
authorized by the village board in the manner prescribed for and subject to the
limits as imposed by village policy.
   (J)   Take the necessary steps to ensure that all laws, village ordinances
and policies are duly enforced.
   (K)   Investigate and monitor, with the village president's and board of
trustees' approval, the affairs of any department or division under the
administrator's jurisdiction concerning the administration of the government of
the village and in regard to service maintained by the public utilities in the
village and to ensure that all franchises, permits and privileges granted by
the village are faithfully observed. (Ord. 05-1183, 8-17-2005)
   (L)   Devote his or her entire time to the discharge of the official duties
of the office.
   (M)   Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the village
president and the village board, not inconsistent with the village ordinances.
   (N)   Keep a current inventory showing all real and personal property of the
village and its location and be responsible for the care and custody of all
such property, including equipment, buildings and all other valuable property
which is not by law assigned to some other officer or body for care and
control.
   (O)   Coordinate efforts with the village clerk regarding the publication of
all notices, ordinances and other documents required by law to be published and
prepared or cause to be prepared all reports which the village or any of the
officials thereof are required by law to prepare.
   (P)   Apprise the village president and board of trustees of all requests
and comments dealing with village related matters.
   (Q)   Attend disciplinary, zoning, or public hearings, if required to do so
by the board of trustees.
   (R)   Upon the village president's and board of trustees' directive, the
administrator shall act as a liaison on behalf of the village at hearings,
meetings, social functions or other related matters.
   (S)   Negotiate labor agreements and contracts, be knowledgeable of labor
contracts and assist, when necessary, individual departments with contractual
matters including grievance procedures. (Ord. 01-1092, 10-4-2001)
   (T)   Promote employee relations by meeting with employees and supervisors
as needed to discuss issues, policies, and village board decisions with the
intent to prevent rumors and misinformation. (Ord. 05-1183, 8-17-2005)
1-9-5: EMPLOYEE MATTERS:
Except for the purpose of inquiry, the village board and its members shall deal
with the village employees first through the village administrator. (Ord. 95-
928, 3-30-1995)
1-9-6: SURETY BOND:
The village administrator will cooperate with the village in procuring a surety
bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) to be approved by the
village board, said bond to be conditioned on the faithful performance of the
duties of the office. The premium for the bond shall be paid by the village.
(Ord. 95-928, 3-30-1995)
1-9-7: COMPENSATION:
The village administrator shall receive compensation as the village president
and board of trustees shall deem appropriate and evidenced by the adoption of
an ordinance, resolution or motion. (Ord. 00-1045, 2-17-2000)
CHAPTER 10
DEPOSITORIES
SECTION:
1-10-1: Depository
1-10-2: Deposits
1-10-3: Signatures
1-10-1: DEPOSITORY:
The village treasurer shall consult with and obtain the approval of the
president and board of trustees as to the designation of the village depository
bank/banks. A list of the depository bank/banks shall be maintained in the
office of the village treasurer. Said list shall be reviewed by the village
treasurer and president and board of trustees on an annual basis. (Ord. 00-
1046, 2-17-2000)
1-10-2: DEPOSITS:
The treasurer of the village is hereby directed to deposit from time to time
all monies coming into his possession, control, charge or custody belonging to
the village or in which it has any interest. (1965 Code)
1-10-3: SIGNATURES:
All warrants drawn upon the municipal treasurer must be signed by the president
and countersigned by the clerk, or the treasurer in all instances where all
three (3) of said officers are available, all warrants shall be signed by each
of said officers. The clerk shall be and he is hereby directed and instructed
to advise all depositories of village funds of the requirements in the number
of signatures required on all warrants so drawn against the treasurer, as
aforesaid. Such warrant shall state the particular fund and the appropriation
to which the warrant is chargeable and the person to whom payable. (1965 Code)
CHAPTER 11
OFFICIAL TIME
SECTION:
1-11-1: Official Time
1-11-1: OFFICIAL TIME:
From and after two o'clock (2:00) A.M. June 21, 1940, Central Standard Time
shall be the official time within the village for the transaction of all
business: except that from two o'clock (2:00) A.M. on Sunday, June 23, 1940,
and from two o'clock (2:00) A.M. on the last Sunday in April in 1941, and in
each year thereafter, official time for the village shall be advanced one hour,
and at two o'clock (2:00) A.M. on the last Sunday of October in each year such
official time shall be retarded one hour and said official time be returned to
Central Standard Time. All legal or official proceedings of the board of
trustees and all official business of the village shall be regulated as to time
in accordance with the provisions of this section; and when, by ordinance,
resolution or action of any municipal officer or body, an act must be performed
at or within a prescribed time, it shall be performed according to the official
time as herein prescribed. When the words "daylight saving" or "daylight saving
time" are used in any official document or contract it shall be understood to
have reference to the time herein fixed for the period from the last Sunday in
April to the last Sunday in October. (Ord. 10, 7-2-1940)
CHAPTER 12
ELECTIONS
SECTION:
1-12-1: Notice Of Election
1-12-2: Supplies For Election
1-12-3: Ballot Boxes
1-12-4: Booths
1-12-5: Time Polls Open
1-12-6: Contest Of Election
1-12-7: Board To Hear Protest
1-12-8: Method Of Contest
1-12-9: Statement Of Contest
1-12-10: Time And Place Of Hearing
1-12-11: Filing Of Proofs
1-12-12: Testimony On Allegation Only
1-12-13: Determination By Board
1-12-14: Special Election
1-12-15: Inspection Of Ballots
1-12-16: Election To Fill Vacancy
1-12-1: NOTICE OF ELECTION:
Biennially, notice of election shall be published at least once not more than
thirty (30) nor less than fifteen (15) days in advance of the election in one
or more newspapers published in the village, or, if no newspaper is published
therein, then in one or more newspapers with a general circulation within the
village. The board of trustees shall: a) appoint five (5) judges of election at
each balloting place, b) canvass the returns thereof, and c) cause the results
to be entered upon the records of the village. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-12-2: SUPPLIES FOR ELECTION:
The clerk shall provide, at the expense of the village, proper blanks, poll
books, cards of instruction, ballots and other necessary election blanks for
such voting precinct or district in the village, and cause a suitable number
thereof to be delivered to the judges of election. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-12-3: BALLOT BOXES:
The clerk, under the direction of the board of trustees, shall provide a
sufficient number of ballot boxes with secure locks and keys, at the expense of
the village, for the several precincts and districts. There shall be an opening
in the lid of each box not larger than is sufficient to admit a single, closed
ballot to be inserted therein at one time, through which all ballots voted
shall be put into the box. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-12-4: BOOTHS:
The clerk, under the direction of the board of trustees, shall provide for each
polling place a sufficient number of booths furnished with the supplies and
conveniences, and constructed and arranged, as required by law. (Ord. 56, 11-
15-1945)
1-12-5: TIME POLLS OPEN:
At all elections hereafter held in the village, the polls shall be opened at
six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and be closed at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. of the same
day. (Ord. 95-923, 3-30-1995)
1-12-6: CONTEST OF ELECTION:
The election of any trustee may be contested by any elector of the village
voting at the election contested, and the proceedings shall be in accordance
with the general laws of this state relating to the mode of contesting the
elections of county officers, so far as the same may be applicable and not
inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter hereinafter set out. (Ord. 56,
11-15-1945)
1-12-7: BOARD TO HEAR PROTEST:
The president and board of trustees shall be the tribunal before which said
contest shall be heard, and its decision shall be final. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-12-8: METHOD OF CONTEST:
When any elector shall desire to contest the right of another to hold the
office of trustee, he shall within fifteen (15) days after the election file
with the clerk a statement in writing, briefly setting forth the points on
which he will contest the election, which statement shall be verified by
affidavit, and contest in no other way shall be entertained or considered.
(Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-12-9: STATEMENT OF CONTEST:
Upon filing such statement said contestant shall also serve a copy thereof upon
the person whose election he intends to contest, and in case such trustee whose
election is sought to be contested is absent from the village, or cannot be
found, then he shall serve the same by leaving a copy of such statement in the
respondent's usual place of residence with a person thereon above the age of
twelve (12) years, and shall make due verified proof of the service of such
copy, and file the same with the clerk, and after the filing of said statement
and proof of service, as aforesaid, the respondent shall have five (5) days
thereafter to demur to or otherwise object to the sufficiency of the grounds
alleged for contest, and the president and board of trustees may allow the
contestant to amend his statement once. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-12-10: TIME AND PLACE OF HEARING:
Upon the president and board of trustees' finding that said statement of
reasons for contest being sufficient in law to authorize the opening of the
ballots or the taking of the testimony, or of both, it shall be the duty of the
president and board of trustees, upon the application of either party, to fix a
time and place for the taking of the testimony of the witnesses, and each party
shall have the right to proceed and take the testimony of his witnesses, and in
the case either party cannot procure the personal attendance before the
president and board of trustees shall fix a time and place for the taking of
the depositions of such witness or witnesses, and when either party may proceed
to take the testimony of such nonresident witness, the same shall be taken
under the order, as aforesaid, in the manner as provided for the taking of
depositions to be used in cases of chancery before any judge, master in
chancery, justice of the peace, or notary public, to continue such hearing of
the testimony of such witness or witnesses from day to day thereafter until the
same shall have been completed and the testimony taken. The testimony of any
such witness or witnesses not residing within the corporate limits of the said
village and whose attendance cannot be procured must be shown to the president
and board of trustees to be material and the inability to procure the personal
attendance of such witness before any such party shall have the right to have
the testimony by deposition of such witness taken. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-12-11: FILING OF PROOFS:
In all cases of contested elections where any proofs are taken by deposition,
as aforesaid, the same shall be taken and filed with the clerk, as herein
provided, within thirty (30) days from the day fixed by the president and board
of trustees for the taking of the same; provided that the president and board
of trustees may, from time to time upon sufficient cause, extend the time for
the taking and filing of such proofs. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-12-12: TESTIMONY ON ALLEGATION ONLY:
No testimony shall be taken or produced on the hearing before the president and
board of trustees except upon the points set forth in the statement required to
be filed with the clerk and served upon the respondent. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-12-13: DETERMINATION BY BOARD:
When all the evidence shall have been taken and the testimony heard, the
president and board of trustees shall sit and consider the said evidence,
giving reasonable time to each to be heard in argument upon the same, of, by or
through counsel, and then the said president and board of trustees shall decide
according to the right of the matter, and shall declare as elected the person
who shall appear by the evidence to have been elected, and the president and
board of trustees may require all of the testimony not heard by it and all of
the proofs or documents taken and given in evidence to be read in open meeting.
(Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-12-14: SPECIAL ELECTION:
Whenever it shall appear in any case that the person receiving the highest
number of votes for trustee is ineligible to the office because of any legal
disqualification, it shall for that reason be the duty of the president and
board of trustees to declare such election null and void, and immediately call
a special election to fill said office and the vacancy. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-12-15: INSPECTION OF BALLOTS:
In all cases of contested election the parties shall have the right to have the
package or packages of ballots which have been returned to the clerk, as
required by law, opened in open session of the president and board of trustees,
and in the presence of the officer having the custody thereof, and to have such
ballots then and there counted by a committee of three (3) persons appointed
for that purpose, provided a good and sufficient statement of the points of
contest have been filed, as hereinbefore specified. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-12-16: ELECTION TO FILL VACANCY:
Whenever a vacancy in the office of president occurs during his term, the
vacancy shall be filled for the remainder of the term at the next election of
trustees. During the period from the time that the vacancy occurs until a
president is elected, and has qualified, the vacancy may be filled by the
election of an acting president by the board of trustees. Whenever a vacancy in
the office of a trustee occurs during his term, the vacancy shall be filled for
the remainder of the term at the next election of trustees. During the period
from the time that the vacancy occurs until a trustee is elected, and
qualified, the vacancy may be filled by the appointment of a trustee by the
president and remaining trustees, voting jointly 1 . (1965 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/5-2-14, 5/5-2-15.
CHAPTER 13
DEPARTMENT OF ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES
SECTION:
1-13-1: Department Established
1-13-2: General Supervision And Control
1-13-3: Appointments
1-13-4: Duties Of Department
1-13-5: To Obey Orders
1-13-6: Village Clerk-Deputy Village Clerk
1-13-7: Clerk Typist-Bookkeeper
1-13-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a department of administrative services which shall
consist of village clerk, deputy village clerk, clerk typist-bookkeeper, the
administrative offices of the president and board of trustees, treasurer,
superintendent of public works, building coordinator, water department
superintendent, and such clerical personnel as may from time to time be
appointed. (Ord. 95-924, 3-30-1995)
1-13-2: GENERAL SUPERVISION AND CONTROL:
The president shall have general supervision and control of the department of
administrative services with the assistance of the board of trustees, and shall
see that all employees of the administrative services department are faithful
in the discharge of their duties, and from time to time shall take such
measures as he may deem expedient to provide the type and quality of
performance to the best interest of the village. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-13-3: APPOINTMENTS:
The president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall
appoint all members of the administrative services, who shall hold their office
for the time specified in the appointment, not to extend beyond the termination
of the current municipal year. In case of emergency the president shall have
the full power to appoint such required help as may be necessary on a temporary
basis without the consent of the board of trustees. The president shall have
the power to remove any administrative services employee whenever in his
opinion the interests of the village require such removal, subject to the
approval of the board of trustees. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-13-4: DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT:
It shall be the function and duty of the department of administrative services
to perform all clerical service functions related to the office of the village
clerk as decreed by law, the offices of the village treasurer, building
coordinator, superintendent of public works, police department, fire
department, water department superintendent, and health department; maintain
personnel records; perform all payroll department functions; and provide the
necessary secretarial and clerical services for the president and board of
trustees in the conduct of village business. The village board, in its sole
discretion, shall have the authority to conduct or direct all appropriate
preemployment testing of applicants seeking employment with the village. (Ord.
95-921, 3-30-1995)
1-13-5: TO OBEY ORDERS:
Any administrative services employee who shall neglect or refuse to perform the
duties assigned them shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to
the discipline of the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 56, 11-15-1945)
1-13-6: VILLAGE CLERK-DEPUTY VILLAGE CLERK:
The village clerk-deputy village clerk shall have charge of all office
procedures required in performing the duties as outlined in section
1-13-4 of this chapter.
The deputy village clerk shall be subordinate to the village clerk and shall
assist him in the performance of his duties as required or directed.
The village clerk-deputy village clerk shall be responsible for maintaining
personnel records and files on all employees.
The village clerk shall have direct supervision of the clerk typists and such
office personnel as may be assigned from time to time to assist in the conduct
of village business. In the absence of the village clerk, the Deputy village
clerk shall then have the direct supervision of said clerk typists and other
office personnel.
In addition to the above outlined duties, the village clerk- deputy village
clerk may be delegated other related assignments, from time to time, by the
president and board of trustees. (Ord. 95-922, 3-30-1995)
1-13-7: CLERK TYPIST-BOOKKEEPER:
It is the responsibility of the clerk typist-bookkeeper to assist the village
clerk-deputy village clerk in the conduct of village business as outlined in
section
1-13-4 of this chapter.
The clerk typist-bookkeeper shall be subordinate to the village clerk-deputy
village clerk and shall perform assigned duties as directed. (Ord. 95-920, 3-
30-1995)
CHAPTER 14
HEALTH COMMISSIONER
SECTION:
1-14-1: Office Created
1-14-2: Duties
1-14-3: Jurisdiction
1-14-1: OFFICE CREATED:
There is hereby created an office of the municipal government to be known as
health commissioner whose term of office shall be for one year, and he to hold
his office until his successor is appointed and qualified. Such officer shall
be appointed by the president, with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees, and he may be a nonresident of the village. (Ord. 51, 2-15-1945)
