retaliatory action such as reprimand, discharge, suspension, demotion, or
denial of promotion or transfer that occurs in retaliation for an employee who
does any of the following:
   (A)   Discloses or threatens to disclose to a supervisor or to a public body
an activity, policy, or practice of any officer, member, State agency, or other
State employee that the State employee reasonably believes is in violation of a
law, rule, or regulation,
   (B)   Provides information to or testifies before any public body conducting
an investigation, hearing, or inquiry into any violation of a law, rule, or
regulation by any officer, member, State agency or other State employee, or
   (C)   Assists or participates in a proceeding to enforce the provisions of
the State Officials and Employees Ethics Act.
Pursuant to the Whistleblower Act 2 , an employer may not retaliate against an
employee who discloses information in a court, an administrative hearing, or
before a legislative commission or committee, or in any other proceeding, where
the employee has reasonable cause to believe that the information discloses a
violation of a State or Federal law, rule, or regulation. In addition, an
employer may not retaliate against an employee for disclosing information to a
government or law enforcement agency, where the employee has reasonable cause
to believe that the information discloses a violation of a State or Federal
law, rule, or regulation 3 .
According to the Illinois Human Rights Act 4 , it is a civil rights violation
for a person, or for two (2) or more people to conspire, to retaliate against a
person because he/she has opposed that which he/she reasonably and in good
faith believes to be sexual harassment in employment, because he/she has made a
charge, filed a complaint, testified, assisted, or participated in an
investigation, proceeding, or hearing under the Illinois Human Rights Act.
An employee who is suddenly transferred to a lower paying job or passed over
for a promotion after filing a complaint with IDHR or EEOC, may file a
retaliation charge - due within one hundred eighty (180) days (IDHR) or three
hundred (300) days (EEOC) of the alleged retaliation. (Ord. 17-1550, 12-7-2017,
eff. 12-7-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 430/15-10.
2 2. 740 ILCS 174/15(a).
3 3. 740 ILCS 174/15(b).
4 4. 775 ILCS 5/6-101.
1-26-5: CONSEQUENCES OF A VIOLATION OF THE PROHIBITION ON SEXUAL HARASSMENT:
In addition to any and all other discipline that may be applicable pursuant to
Municipal policies, employment agreements, procedures, employee handbooks and/
or collective bargaining agreement, any person who violates this chapter or the
Prohibition on Sexual Harassment contained in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/
5-65, may be subject to a fine of up to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per
offense, applicable discipline or discharge by the Municipality and any
applicable fines and penalties established pursuant to local ordinance, State
law or Federal law. Each violation may constitute a separate offense. Any
discipline imposed by the Municipality shall be separate and distinct from any
penalty imposed by an ethics commission and any fines or penalties imposed by a
court of law or a State or Federal agency. (Ord. 17-1550, 12-7-2017, eff. 12-7-
2017)
1-26-6: CONSEQUENCES FOR KNOWINGLY MAKING A FALSE REPORT:
A false report is a report of sexual harassment made by an accuser using the
sexual harassment report to accomplish some end other than stopping sexual
harassment or retaliation for reporting sexual harassment. A false report is
not a report made in good faith which cannot be proven. Given the seriousness
of the consequences for the accused, a false or frivolous report is a severe
offense that can itself result in disciplinary action. Any person who
intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of
this chapter shall be subject to discipline or discharge pursuant to applicable
Municipal policies, employment agreements, procedures, employee handbooks and/
or collective bargaining agreements.
In addition, any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a
violation of any provision of the State Officials and Employees Ethics Act to
an ethics commission, an inspector general, the State Police, a State's
Attorney, the Attorney General, or any other law enforcement official is guilty
of a Class A misdemeanor. An ethics commission may levy an administrative fine
of up to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) against any person who intentionally
makes a false, frivolous or bad faith allegation. (Ord. 17-1550, 12-7-2017,
eff. 12-7-2017)

BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS

CHAPTER 2
EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER AGENCY
SECTION:
2-2-1: Establishment; Composition
2-2-2: Coordinator
2-2-3: Interpretation Of Chapter
2-2-4: Functions And Duties
2-2-5: Mobile Support Team
2-2-6: Mutual Aid Agreements
2-2-7: Emergency Action
2-2-8: Compensation
2-2-9: Reimbursement By State
2-2-10: Volunteers
2-2-11: Integration Of Village Officers And Employees
2-2-12: Purchases And Expenditures
2-2-13: Oath
2-2-14: Office Space
2-2-15: Appropriations; Levy Of Taxes
2-2-16: Credentials Of Authority
2-2-17: Violations
2-2-1: ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION:
   (A)   There is hereby established in and for the village an emergency
services and disaster agency (ESDA), to prevent, minimize, repair and alleviate
injury or damage resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage or
other hostile action, or from natural or manmade disaster, in accordance with
the Illinois emergency services and disaster act of 1975.
   (B)   The agency shall consist of the coordinator and such additional
members as may be appointed by the village president. (Ord. 86-777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-2: COORDINATOR:
   (A)   The coordinator of the emergency services and disaster agency of the
village shall be appointed by the village president by and with the advice and
consent of the village board on an annual basis.
   (B)   The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization,
administration, training, operation and supervision of the agency, subject to
the direction and control of the village president and village board, as
provided by statute.
   (C)   The coordinator shall represent the village on all matters pertaining
to emergency services. During periods of emergency, as defined by law for
agency purposes, the coordinator shall coordinate the actions of all village
officers and employees.
   (D)   The coordinator is hereby authorized to require the assistance of any
and all able bodied residences for protection of the public welfare during
periods of emergency.
   (E)   The coordinator is hereby authorized to delegate his or her authority
as he or she deems fit.
   (F)   In the event of the absence, resignation or death of the coordinator
or his or her inability to serve, the village president, or any person
designated by him or her, shall be and act as coordinator until a new
appointment is made as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 86-777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-3: INTERPRETATION OF CHAPTER:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to be a modification of the
executive authority of the village board under the various provisions of state
law giving the village president certain emergency powers. Rather, it is the
express intent of this chapter to assign such emergency authority that is now
existent or subsequently granted or extended by law or the emergency services
and disaster agency of the village. (Ord. 86-777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-4: FUNCTIONS AND DUTIES:
The emergency services and disaster agency of the village shall perform such
functions within the village as are prescribed in and by the state emergency
services and disaster agency plan and program prepared by the governor and in
and by such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the
governor, and, in addition, shall perform such duties outside the corporate
limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other
political subdivision, municipality or quasi-municipality entered into as
provided by the state emergency services and disaster agency act of 1975. (Ord.
86-777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-5: MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM:
   (A)   Any member of the village emergency services and disaster agency may
be designated as a member of a mobile support team created by the director of
the state emergency services and disaster agency as provided by law.
   (B)   The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the
coordinator of the village ESDA.
   (C)   Any member of a mobile support team who is a village employee or
officer shall, while serving on call to duty by the governor or the state
director, receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and
immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a
paid officer or employee of the village shall, while so serving, receive, from
the state, reasonable compensation as provided by law. (Ord. 86-777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-6: MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS:
The coordinator of the emergency services and disaster agency of the village
may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other villages or political
subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be effective until it
has been approved by the village president and village board and by the state
director of the emergency services and disaster agency. (Ord. 86-777, 10-2-
1986)
2-2-7: EMERGENCY ACTION:
If the governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists due to actual enemy
attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the state of a major
disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or a manmade or
natural disaster, the village emergency services and disaster agency shall
cooperate fully with the state emergency services and disaster agency and with
the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. (Ord. 86-
777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-8: COMPENSATION:
Members of the emergency services and disaster agency of the village who are
paid employees or officers of the village, if called for training by the state
director of the emergency services and disaster agency, shall receive, for the
time spent in such training, the same rate of pay as is attached to the
position held. Members who are not village employees or officers shall receive
for such training time such compensation as may be established by the village
president and the board of trustees. (Ord. 86-777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-9: REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE:
The village treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund any
reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training
members of the emergency services and disaster agency of the village as
prescribed by the state director of emergency services and disaster agency,
compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team
while serving outside the village in response to a call by the governor or the
state director of the agency, as provided by law, and any other reimbursement
made by the state incident to agency activities as provided by law. (Ord. 86-
777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-10: VOLUNTEERS:
All persons other than village president appointments and employees of the
village, volunteering for service pursuant to this chapter, shall serve without
compensation. While engaged in such service, they shall have the same
immunities as persons and employees of the village performing similar duties.
(Ord. 86-777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-11: INTEGRATION OF VILLAGE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
Appointed officers and employees of the village shall be integrated under such
division of the emergency services and disaster agency of the village as the
village president and the coordinator deem necessary and expedient, and such
officers and employees are hereby directed and authorized to comply with
directives issued under this chapter. (Ord. 86-777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-12: PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES:
   (A)   The village president and village board may, on recommendation of the
coordinator or on their own motion, authorize the coordinator to engage in the
purchase of contracts necessary to place the village in a position to
effectively combat any disaster resulting from the explosion of any nuclear or
other bomb or missile and to protect the public health and safety, protect
property and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of such a
disaster or in the case of a manmade or natural disaster.
   (B)   In the event of an enemy caused or other disaster, the coordinator is
authorized, on behalf of the village, to procure such services, supplies,
equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the
exigency, without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally
prescribed by law pertaining to village contracts or obligations, as authorized
by the state ESDA act of 1975, provided that if the village board meets at such
time, the coordinator shall act subject to the directions and restrictions
imposed by the village board. (Ord. 86-777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-13: OATH:
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the emergency services and
disaster agency of the village shall, before entering upon his or her duties,
subscribe to the following oath, in writing, which shall be filed with the
coordinator:
I,                      do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and
defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United
States and the institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private,
against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely,
without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and
faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do
further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I now, nor have I ever
been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the
overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or
violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Village of
Bedford Park Emergency Services and Disaster Agency, I will not advocate nor
become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the
overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or
violence.
(Ord. 86-777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-14: OFFICE SPACE:
The village president and village board are hereby authorized to designate
space in a village building or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the village
president, for the office of the emergency services and disaster agency of the
village. (Ord. 86-777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-15: APPROPRIATIONS; LEVY OF TAXES:
The village president and village board may make an appropriation for emergency
services and disaster agency purposes in the manner provided by law and may
levy, in addition, for agency purposes only, a tax not to exceed five cents
($0.05) per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of the assessed value of all taxable
property in addition to all other taxes, as provided by the state ESDA act of
1975. However, that amount collectible under such levy shall in no event exceed
twenty five cents ($0.25) per capita. (Ord. 86-777, 10-2-1986)
2-2-16: CREDENTIALS OF AUTHORITY:
Credentials of authority in a manner and form to be determined by the
coordinator may be issued to emergency services and disaster agency officers
and personnel. The village president and the village clerk are hereby
authorized to affix the seal of the village on such credentials. (Ord. 86-777,
10-2-1986)
2-2-17: VIOLATIONS:
During an emergency, as determined by law, no person shall:
   (A)   Wilfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the emergency
services and disaster agency of the village in any enforcement of any lawful
rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter or in the performance of any
duty imposed upon him or her by virtue of this chapter;
   (B)   Do any act prohibited by any lawful rule or regulation issued pursuant
to this chapter if such act is of a kind that will give assistance to the
enemy, imperil the life or property of any inhabitant of the village or
prevent, hinder or delay the defense or protection thereof; or
   (C)   Wear, carry or display without authority any mark or identification
specified by the agency.
Persons violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to general
penalties for violation of this code. (Ord. 86-777, 10-2-1986)
CHAPTER 3
PLAN COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-3-1: Commission Created
2-3-2: Membership
2-3-3: Terms
2-3-4: Organization
2-3-5: Powers
2-3-6: Village Limits
2-3-7: Records
2-3-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
A plan commission is hereby created under the authority of an act of the
general assembly of the state of Illinois, entitled: "an act in relation to
plan commissions in cities, villages and incorporated towns", approved June 24,
1921, and in force July 1, 1921 1 . (Ord. 18, 7-18-1940)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-13-1.
2-3-2: MEMBERSHIP:
Said plan commission shall consist of members including the president and other
members chosen from the board of trustees, the citizens and property owners of
said village by the president with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees. (Ord. 18, 7-18-1940)
2-3-3: TERMS:
Of the members appointed other than the president of the board of trustees,
four (4) shall be appointed for a term of one year, four (4) for a term of two
(2) years, and four (4) for a term of three (3) years. The terms of all members
of the plan commission thereafter appointed shall be three (3) years. All
vacancies occurring in such plan commission shall be filled by appointment for
the remainder of the unexpired term in the same manner as original
appointments. (Ord. 18, 7-18-1940)
2-3-4: ORGANIZATION:
As soon as possible after their appointment the members of said plan commission
shall organize by the election of the chairman, vice chairman, secretary and
such other officers as may in their judgment be necessary. All the members and
officers of said plan commission shall serve as such without compensation,
except that if the board of trustees deem advisable the secretary may receive
such compensation as may be fixed from time to time by the board of trustees
and provided for in the appropriation ordinance. If said plan commission shall
deem it advisable to secure technical advice or service, it may do so upon
authority from the village and appropriation by the board therefor. (Ord. 18,
7-18-1940)
2-3-5: POWERS:
Said plan commission shall have the power:
   (A)   To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees a comprehensive plan
of public improvements looking to the present and future development of the
village, which plan shall be known as the official plan of the village. Such
plan shall include reasonable requirements in reference to streets, alleys and
public grounds in unsubdivided lands within the corporate limits and in
contiguous territory outside of and distant not more than one and one-half (11/
2) miles from such limits, and not included in any municipality. Such
requirements to be effective whenever such lands shall be subdivided after the
adoption of such plan.
   (B)   To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees from time to time
such changes in the plan as may be deemed necessary by the board of trustees or
by the plan commission, provided, however, that such changes shall not affect
the general principles of the plan as adopted.
   (C)   To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees from time to time
plans for specific improvements in pursuance of such official plan.
   (D)   To give aid to the officials of the village charged with the direction
of projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, to further the
making of such improvements, and generally to promote the realization of the
official plan.
   (E)   To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by this
chapter, as may be conferred by the board of trustees. (Ord. 18, 7-18-1940)
2-3-6: VILLAGE LIMITS:
No map or plat of any subdivision presented for record, affecting land within
the corporate limits of the village and in contiguous territory outside of and
distant not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles from such limits, and not
included in any city, village or incorporated town, after the adoption of the
official plan, shall be entitled to record or shall be valid unless the
subdivision thereon shown, shall provide for streets, alleys and public grounds
in conformity with any requirements applicable thereto, on such official plan.
(Ord. 18, 7-18-1940)
2-3-7: RECORDS:
The plan commission shall keep written records of its proceedings which shall
be open to inspection by the board of trustees at all times. (Ord. 18, 7-18-
1940)
CHAPTER 4
EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM BOARD (911)

CHAPTER 5
FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE TAX BOARD
SECTION:
2-5-1: Election Of Officers
2-5-2: Terms Of Office
2-5-3: Vacancy
2-5-4: Election Procedure
2-5-5: Powers, Duties And Responsibilities
2-5-6: Quorum; Meetings
2-5-1: ELECTION OF OFFICERS:
The foreign fire insurance tax board shall consist of five (5) elected
officers. The elected officers shall include a chairman, secretary, treasurer
and two (2) trustees. Each elected officer shall be a full time,
nonprobationary, member of the village fire department. (Ord. 97-1004, 12-11-
1997)
2-5-2: TERMS OF OFFICE:
Each member of the board elected to an office on the foreign fire insurance tax
board shall serve a term of two (2) years. (Ord. 97-1004, 12-11-1997)
2-5-3: VACANCY:
A vacancy shall be declared if any of the following events occur:
   (A)   The elected officer resigns from the office;
   (B)   The elected officer retires from the fire department;
   (C)   The elected officer is discharged from employment of the village.
A vacancy on the board shall be filled by election in accordance with section
2-5-1 of this chapter and any election procedures established by the board. The
election of the new officer shall take place no later than thirty (30) days
after the vacancy has occurred. The newly elected member shall assume office
immediately upon completion of the election. (Ord. 97-1004, 12-11-1997)
2-5-4: ELECTION PROCEDURE:
Within thirty (30) days from the adoption of this chapter, an election of
officers for the board shall take place. A list of the newly elected officers
shall be submitted to the village clerk. Upon the election of the initial
officers who are to serve on the board, they shall develop rules and
regulations pertaining to the election of all future boards. All such rules and
regulations with respect to the election process shall be posted throughout the
department at least thirty (30) days prior to any election. In the event of a
conflict between the terms of this chapter and any election procedures adopted
by the board, the terms of this chapter shall prevail. All subsequent elections
shall take place no later than thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the
board members' terms of office. (Ord. 97-1004, 12-11-1997)
2-5-5: POWERS, DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The initial foreign fire insurance tax board and all subsequent boards shall
adhere to the following duties and responsibilities:
   (A)   The board shall make all needful rules and regulations with respect to
the foreign fire insurance tax board and/or the management of monies
appropriated to the board.
   (B)   The board shall develop and maintain a listing of those items that the
board feels are appropriate expenditures pursuant of 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-10-2.
   (C)   The funds of the board shall be annually reviewed as part of the
village audit. The audit shall verify that purchases by the board are for the
maintenance, use and benefit of the village fire department.
   (D)   The treasurer of the board shall give a sufficient bond to the
village. This bond shall be approved by the President. The bond shall be
conditioned upon the faithful performance by the treasurer of his duties under
the state statutes, ordinance, and the rules and regulations adopted by the
board.
   (E)   The treasurer of the board shall receive funds appropriated by the
village and shall pay out money and/or otherwise make expenditures upon the
order of the board. Any expenditures made by the treasurer, pursuant to the
order of the board shall be solely for the maintenance, use and benefit of the
fire department.
   (F)   The board shall establish a list of items and/or services from which
it shall select items and/or services to be purchased for the maintenance, use
and benefit of the fire department. The list shall be furnished to the village
board fire committee. The list shall be updated from time to time as the board
shall determine, but no less than annually on January 1 of each year. The first
such list shall be created or revised by April 1, 1998.
   (G)   Prior to the purchase of any item(s) and/or service from the list
which the board intends to place within any fire station(s), the board shall
submit a written statement to the village board fire committee stating the
descriptions of the items and/or services and the proposed locations within any
fire station(s). The village board fire committee has the right to refuse to
allow any such item(s) and/or service(s) into any fire station(s). If the
village board fire committee decides to allow any such item(s) and/or service
into any fire station, the village board fire committee shall also have the
right to refuse the board's proposed physical location of any such item(s) or
rendering of service in any fire station. In the event the board requests, in
writing, a basis for the village board fire committee's decision, such a
response to the request must be submitted to the board within thirty (30) days
of receipt of the request. Upon the purchase of any approved items, title to
same shall be placed in the name of the village.
   (H)   Any proposed purchase in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00)
shall be let for bid in accordance with section
1-19-1 of this code.
   (I)   The officers of the board shall not be entitled to any compensation of
any kind for their services and/or time.
   (J)   Meetings of the board shall not take place or be scheduled during the
officers' working hours of employment. (Ord. 97-1004, 12-11-1997)
2-5-6: QUORUM; MEETINGS:
The board shall strictly comply with the provisions of the open meetings act.
Minutes of all meetings shall be kept by the secretary and shall be open for
public review. The minutes shall be filed with the village clerk. No meeting
shall be held without a quorum being present. Three (3) members of the board
shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. (Ord. 98-1011, 5-7-
1998)
CHAPTER 6
BEAUTIFICATION ADVISORY COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-6-1: Committee Created
2-6-2: Membership
2-6-3: Guidelines For Operation
2-6-4: Duties
2-6-1: COMMITTEE CREATED:
The beautification advisory committee ("BAC") is hereby created. (Ord. 05-1176,
6-2-2005)
2-6-2: MEMBERSHIP:
   (A)   All appointments to the BAC shall be made by the president with the
advice and consent of the board of trustees.
   (B)   The appointments to the committee shall be for a period of one year
with said appointments being made by the president by March 1 of each
succeeding year.
   (C)   The membership of the committee shall consist of seven (7) residents.
(Ord. 05-1176, 6-2-2005)
2-6-3: GUIDELINES FOR OPERATION:
   (A)   All committee meetings shall be open to the public and subject to the
open meetings act.
   (B)   Regular meetings shall be monthly on a day determined by the majority
vote of the committee members.
   (C)   The chairperson of the committee shall be named by a majority vote of
its committee members.
   (D)   The committee shall have the authority to establish its own rules of
procedure as long as they are not inconsistent with this chapter.
   (E)   All committee members shall serve without compensation.
   (F)   Neither the committee as a whole or a committee member personally
shall incur any expense without prior village board approval. (Ord. 05-1176, 6-
2-2005)
2-6-4: DUTIES:
   (A)   Review, discuss and recommend appropriate action pertaining to the
maintenance, upkeep and preservation of village owned property.
   (B)   Ensure recommendations to promote managed growth in the industrial and
commercial section of the village.
   (C)   Review and advise the corporate authorities as to proposed action
which would enhance the residential district of the village.
   (D)   Any and all recommendations shall be forwarded to the president and
village board for its consideration.
   (E)   Any other duties as prescribed by the village board. (Ord. 05-1176, 6-
2-2005)

CHAPTER 8
SENIOR CITIZENS' COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-8-1: Senior Citizens' Committee Established
2-8-2: Purpose
2-8-3: Guidelines For Operation
2-8-4: Compensation
2-8-1: SENIOR CITIZENS' COMMITTEE ESTABLISHED:
A senior citizens' committee is hereby established and shall consist of five
(5) residents with one of these residents being appointed as the chairperson.
The appointments to this committee shall be made by the village president with
the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The appointments shall be made
on an annual basis. (Ord. 09-1288, 1-20-2009)
2-8-2: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the committee shall be to act as a liaison between the senior
citizens and the village elected authorities in order to communicate the senior
citizens' opinions, needs, desires and interests. (Ord. 09-1288, 1-20-2009)
2-8-3: GUIDELINES FOR OPERATION:
The committee shall follow the rules and regulations described below:
   (A)   All committee meetings shall be open to the public;
   (B)   All regular meetings shall occur on a quarterly basis;
   (C)   The committee shall make written recommendations to the village
president and board of trustees as to how to continue to serve the needs of the
senior citizens;
   (D)   No committee member shall have the authority to incur any expense
without the approval of the village president and board of trustees; and
   (E)   The committee shall have the authority to establish its own rules of
procedure as long as they are not inconsistent with the terms set forth herein.
(Ord. 09-1288, 1-20-2009)
2-8-4: COMPENSATION:
The chairperson will receive the total sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
per year as compensation. Said payment will be paid in equal monthly
installments. (Ord. 09-1288, 1-20-2009)
TITLE III
PUBLIC WORKS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
(Rep. by Ord. 584, 8-20-1970)
CHAPTER 1A
DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
SECTION:
3-1A-1: Department Established
3-1A-2: General Supervision And Control
3-1A-3: Appointments
3-1A-4: Duties Of Department
3-1A-5: To Obey Orders
3-1A-6: Superintendent Of Public Works
3-1A-7: Waterworks Supervisor (Rep. by Ord. 732, 8-18-1983)
3-1A-8: Personnel
3-1A-9: General Labor
3-1A-10: Electrical Inspector
3-1A-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established the department of public works, which shall consist
of the superintendent of public works, working foreman and mechanic, general
labor and such other employees as may from time to time be required. (Ord. 732,
8-18-1983)
3-1A-2: GENERAL SUPERVISION AND CONTROL:
The department shall be under the control and supervision of the superintendent
of public works. He shall be responsible to the president of the village for
the efficient operation of the department. (Ord. 706, 1-15-1981)
3-1A-3: APPOINTMENTS:
   (A)   The village president, with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees, shall appoint all employees of the department of public works.
   (B)   The procedure for handling such appointments shall be in conformance
with the provisions set forth in title I, chapter 18, "Personnel", of this
code, which ordinance is incorporated herein and made a part hereof by
reference. (Ord. 706, 1-15-1981)
3-1A-4: DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT:
It shall be the function and duties of the public works department to maintain
all public streets, alleys and sidewalks in the village; be responsible for
inspection of existing public utilities, excepting water facilities, and any
new public utility which may be authorized in the future, and which are located
within the limits of, but not owned by, the village; maintain all public
property and buildings; altogether with all other machinery and equipment
whatsoever used directly or indirectly in the conduct of and owned by the
village; be responsible for street cleaning; and snow and ice removal; be
responsible for engineering, specifications and surveying functions on all new
public improvements, and changes and alterations of present public works
facilities; and maintain garbage removal services for village residents. (Ord.
732, 8-18-1983)
3-1A-5: TO OBEY ORDERS:
Any public works employee who shall neglect or refuse to perform the duties
assigned them shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to
the discipline of the president and board of trustees upon review of his case.
(Ord. 706, 1-15-1981)
3-1A-6: SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS:
He shall have general supervision and maintenance of the pavements of streets
and alleys and supervision of sidewalk inspection and supervision and
maintenance of all other public improvements, trees and parkways.
He shall have general supervision of changes in and inspection of existing
public utilities and also new public utilities, excepting water facilities,
which may be authorized in the future and which are located or to be located
within the limits of, but not owned by, the village.
He shall have general supervision of all public property and buildings,
together with all other machinery and equipment of the operation of the public
works department.
He shall have general supervision and direction of the street department
pertaining to repairs, maintenance and cleaning of same and shall handle all
complaints on garbage removal and be responsible for the satisfactory
performance of the contracted scavenger service.
He shall have direct supervision and maintenance of all village owned sewers.
As directed by the president and board of trustees, he shall direct all work
awarded to outside contractors and be responsible for their performance in
keeping with the plans and specifications agreed upon.
He shall, in addition to the above outlined duties, perform such other duties
as may be delegated to him from time to time by the president and board of
trustees of the village.
The superintendent of public works is hereby authorized to establish and
execute all necessary regulations and procedures within the department to
effectively administer his responsibilities regarding members of the
department, dealing with promotions, layoffs, demotions, dismissals, wage
increases and other personnel policies and procedures. This authorization shall
be in conformance to the provisions contained in said personnel ordinance.
(Ord. 755, 1-17-1985)
3-1A-7: WATERWORKS SUPERVISOR:
(Rep. by Ord. 732, 8-18-1983)
3-1A-8: PERSONNEL:
The working foreman and mechanic shall be subordinate to the superintendent of
public works, and shall perform such duties as may be delegated to them from
time to time.
The working foreman shall direct, as required, the work of any general labor,
or special labor assigned him either on a regular or seasonal basis. (Ord. 732,
8-18-1983)
3-1A-9: GENERAL LABOR:
Under direct supervision, general labor shall be held responsible for
performing all duties assigned him in the maintenance, repair and upkeep of
public buildings, grounds, streets, and alleys. (Ord. 706, 1-15-1981)
3-1A-10: ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR:
The electrical inspector shall be appointed by the president with the consent
of the board of trustees of the village. He shall be under the direct
supervision of the superintendent of public works and shall be responsible for
certifying and inspecting any electrical equipment in the village which is
either altered or installed at any building or facility in the village. The
electrical inspector shall so certify that the foregoing equipment is in a safe
and operable condition pursuant to the applicable code standards and
specifications adopted by the village. Upon inspection or reinspection of a
building or facility in the village, the electrical inspector shall report his
findings as to the condition of the electrical equipment in said building to
the superintendent of public works at which time the superintendent of public
works shall administer and execute the necessary regulations and procedures
within the department to effectively administer the issuance of permits.
Whenever any electrical equipment has been installed, altered or repaired, no
electrical current shall be supplied to or used on any building or equipment
prior to the inspection of said equipment or building by the electrical
inspector and review by the superintendent of public works. The electrical
inspector shall be compensated for his duties as set forth by the board of
trustees. If the president and board of trustees desire to employ the
electrical inspector in his capacity as an electrician to either work for the
village in said capacity or for an official or employee of the village in his
capacity as an electrical contractor, the village or individual wishing to
employ the electrical inspector may do so; except that any installation or
alteration of electrical equipment to be performed by the electrical inspector
pursuant to the foregoing provisions shall require the approval of the board of
trustees whenever the amount of compensation to be paid to the electrical
inspector for electrical contractor work exceeds the sum of one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. 86-779, 11-6-1986)
CHAPTER 1B
WATER DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
3-1B-1: Department Established
3-1B-2: General Supervision And Control
3-1B-3: Appointments
3-1B-4: Duties Of The Department
3-1B-5: To Obey Orders
3-1B-6: Superintendent Of Water Department
3-1B-7: Water Department Personnel
3-1B-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established the water department, which shall consist of the
water department superintendent, and such other employees as may from time to
time be required. (Ord. 733, 8-18-1983)
3-1B-2: GENERAL SUPERVISION AND CONTROL:
The department shall be under the control and supervision of the water
department superintendent. He shall be responsible to the president of the
village for the efficient operation of the department. (Ord. 733, 8-18-1983)
3-1B-3: APPOINTMENTS:
   (A)   The village president, with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees, shall appoint all employees of the water department.
   (B)   The procedure for handling such appointments shall be in conformance
with the provisions set forth in title I, chapter 18, "Personnel", of this
code, which ordinance is incorporated herein and made a part hereof by
reference. (Ord. 733, 8-18-1983)
3-1B-4: DUTIES OF THE DEPARTMENT:
It shall be the function and duties of the water department to operate and
maintain the water system of the village and to be responsible for inspection
of existing water utilities and any new water utilities which may be authorized
in the future and which are located within the limits of, but not owned by, the
village. (Ord. 733, 8-18-1983)
3-1B-5: TO OBEY ORDERS:
Any water department employee who shall neglect or refuse to perform the duties
assigned him shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to
the discipline of the president and board of trustees upon review of his case
in accordance with proper notice and due process requirements exercised by the
village. (Ord. 733, 8-18-1983)
3-1B-6: SUPERINTENDENT OF WATER DEPARTMENT:
He shall be responsible for the supervision and maintenance of the water supply
and water distribution system, all water equipment related to pumping,
purifying, metering, storing and distributing the water supply, and all
operating personnel.
He shall be responsible for all emergency and regularly planned repairs of the
water system, and supervise the work required in connection with same.
He shall be responsible for maintenance and repair of all water fire lines and
fire hydrants and see that they are in proper working order at all times.
He shall be responsible for all metering of water, repairs of water meters, and
reading and recording of water usage through meters of all customers for proper
billing. Reading and recording of water usage is conducted by supervision and
training of personnel.
He shall have the authority to request additional manpower required for
maintenance and such other services necessary, i.e., daily inspections, grass
cutting, snow removal, painting, etc.
As directed by the president and board of trustees, he shall direct all work
pertaining to the water department awarded to outside contractors and be
responsible for their performance in keeping with the plans and specifications
agreed upon.
He shall, in addition to the above outlined duties, perform such other duties
as may be delegated to him from time to time by the president and board of
trustees of the village. (Ord. 95-917, 3-30-1995)
3-1B-7: WATER DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL:
All employees of the water department shall be subordinate to the water
department superintendent and shall perform such duties as may be delegated to
them from time to time.
All employees of the water department shall be held responsible to the water
department superintendent or any working foreman subsequently appointed, and
shall be held responsible for performing all duties assigned to them in the
maintenance, repair and upkeep of the waterworks facilities of the village.
(Ord. 733, 8-18-1983)
CHAPTER 2
WATER SUPPLY
SECTION:
3-2-1: Limitation Of Water Use
3-2-2: Fire Hydrants
3-2-3: Interference With Hydrants
3-2-4: Excavations
3-2-5: Permit For Excavation
3-2-6: Breaking Of Fire Hydrant
3-2-7: Potable Water Supply
3-2-1: LIMITATION OF WATER USE:
   (A)   Between May 15 through September 15, it shall be unlawful for any
person to use water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns or gardens and
for the cleaning of curbs, streets and alleys on any day of the week except
between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M.,
and seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. In addition to
the aforesaid provisions, it shall also be unlawful for any person to use water
in any manner so as to cause excessive runoff down any street or curb.
   (B)   When the village has been notified by the city of Chicago that an
emergency water supply condition exists, the village president or water
department superintendent shall impose further restrictions which shall permit
sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens only between the hours of eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M., and eight o'clock (8:00)
P.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M., on an odd/even basis by street address
and calendar date (i.e., properties with the last digit of the street address
being an odd number may only water on odd number calendar dates; properties
with the last digit of the street address being an even number may only water
on even number calendar dates during the restricted hours cited within this
subsection).
   (C)   Whenever it is deemed essential for the public health and safety that
the consumption of water from the municipal water system be further restricted,
the village president or water department superintendent may impose such
temporary restrictions as deemed necessary on water use including, but not
limited to, partial or total bans on lawn and plant watering, car washing,
swimming pool filling, and other uses of hoses to dispense water.
   (D)   The president and board of trustees may impose additional interim
water use restrictions as deemed necessary to preserve the public water supply.
   (E)   First time violators of such water use restrictions shall be issued a
warning citation. Subsequent violations of this section will subject the person
to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each observed violation. (Ord. 89-807, 7-20-1989)
3-2-2: FIRE HYDRANTS:
All hydrants erected for the purpose of extinguishing fires are hereby declared
public hydrants, and no person other than the members of the fire department,
when in the discharge of their duties as members of the fire department, and
those especially authorized by the president and board of trustees, and then
only for the uses and purposes of said fire department or in the exercise of
the authority so delegated by said president and board of trustees, shall open
any of the hydrants or attempt to draw water from them or in any manner,
interfere with any of said hydrants. (1965 Code)
3-2-3: INTERFERENCE WITH HYDRANTS:
No person shall wilfully or carelessly break, deface, mar, injure, interfere
with or disturb any public or any private hydrants or stopcock box, shutoff
valve, or shutoff valve box, water supply or service pipe or any part thereof,
nor shall any person deposit anything in any stopcock box or shutoff valve box
or commit any act tending to obstruct or impair the intended use of any of the
above mentioned things, without the permission of the president and board of
trustees. (1965 Code)
3-2-4: EXCAVATIONS:
No person except such as may be duly authorized by the president and board of
trustees, shall make any excavation in any of the streets, avenues or other
public places in said village for the purpose of laying water pipe, or tap any
water or service pipe laid down, or make any connection with tap or water
service pipe. (1965 Code)
3-2-5: PERMIT FOR EXCAVATION:
While ground is frozen no person shall make any excavation in any street,
avenue, alley or public place within four and one-half feet (41/2') of any
water pipe, except by special permission from the president and board of
trustees of the village, which permission when granted must be in writing.
(1965 Code)
3-2-6: BREAKING OF FIRE HYDRANT:
In the event that an emergency should arise by reason of the breaking of any
water hydrant, water main or service pipe or accessory thereto and the flow of
water is or will cause damage to village property or the property of others
unless immediate attention is given thereto, the water department
superintendent shall take such immediate steps that will be necessary to stop
said flow of water and damage to property.
He shall, as soon as possible, proceed to repair said break or damaged hydrant,
water main or service pipe or accessory thereto at once in order to conserve
said water supply and to report said action to the water department committee.
(1965 Code)
3-2-7: POTABLE WATER SUPPLY:
   (A)   Definitions:
    PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, limited
liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust,
estate, or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or
assigns, except for the village of Bedford Park.
   POTABLE WATER: Any water used for human or domestic consumption, including,
but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes,
or preparing foods.
   (B)   Groundwater As A Potable Water Supply Prohibited: Except for uses or
methods being used prior to the approval and adoption of this section, the use
or attempted use, by any person, of groundwater from within the corporate
limits of the village as a potable water supply by the installation or drilling
of wells or by any other method, is hereby prohibited.
   (C)   Penalties: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall
be subject to a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
violation.
   (D)   Memorandum Of Understanding 1 : The president of the village is hereby
authorized and directed to enter into a memorandum of understanding with the
Illinois environmental protection agency ("Illinois EPA") in which the village
assumes responsibility for tracking remediated sites, notifying the Illinois
EPA of changes to this section, and taking certain precautions when siting
public potable water supply wells. (Ord. 98-1009, 5-7-1998)
 
Notes
1 1. On file in the office of the village clerk attached to ordinance 98-1009.
CHAPTER 3
WATER METERS
SECTION:
3-3-1: Meter Required
3-3-2: Uniform Metering
3-3-3: Location Of Meters
3-3-4: Shutoff Valves
3-3-5: Consumers' Responsibility
3-3-6: Fire Lines
3-3-7: Use Of Fire Hydrants
3-3-8: Street Openings To Connect
3-3-9: Water Charges During Construction
3-3-10: Water Rates
3-3-11: Billing
3-3-12: Access To Inspect Systems
3-3-13: Repair Or Removal Of Meters
3-3-14: Violations
3-3-15: Penalties
3-3-1: METER REQUIRED:
With the exception of the residential section of the village, each and every
building connected with the water system of the village, or any other
connection involving the use of water supplied by the village, shall have a
water meter of a type and design approved by the president and board of
trustees attached to its water supply pipes and through which water will be
furnished to consumers. No water will be otherwise supplied to customers except
that under unusual circumstances and for temporary purposes the president and
board of trustees may permit water to be used without the necessity of meters
and may fix the charge to be paid therefor by resolution or otherwise. No meter
shall be connected with said water system until it has been tested and a permit
granted therefor by the water department superintendent. The cost and
installation thereof shall be borne by the water user. (Ord. 95-936, 7-6-1995)
3-3-2: UNIFORM METERING:
Only water meters approved by the president and board of trustees shall be used
within the corporate limits of the village. Such meters shall be purchased from
the village and the payment for same shall be made at the time request is made
to the village for the furnishing of said water. In the case of new
construction, application for water and the payment for the meter must be made
before such construction begins. The size of water meters shall be determined
solely by the water department superintendent. (Ord. 95-918, 3-30-1995)
3-3-3: LOCATION OF METERS:
All water meters shall be located in a meter vault of adequate size and of
concrete construction and shall be located immediately adjacent to the water
supply main. In the event it is impossible to locate said meter vault at such
location, then the water meter shall be placed inside the building adjacent to
the building wall closest to the supply main; provided, however, that the
location of said water meter shall at all times be approved by the water
department superintendent prior to its installation. (Ord. 642, 2-5-1976)
3-3-4: SHUTOFF VALVES:
Shutoff valves shall be located on both sides of the water meter. (Ord. 642, 2-
5-1976)
3-3-5: CONSUMERS' RESPONSIBILITY:
The obligation and liability of the village to furnish water to the consumer
shall terminate at the tap-in point of the private line with the supply main.
(Ord. 642, 2-5-1976)
3-3-6: FIRE LINES:
Every fire line shall be equipped with a one and one-half inch (11/2") bypass
meter, and a reading of the same shall be made at the same time as the regular
monthly readings are made. Replacement of meters shall meet this requirement.
(Ord. 642, 2-5-1976)
3-3-7: USE OF FIRE HYDRANTS:
No person (other than members of the fire department or employees of the
village authorized to do so) shall open any fire hydrant or attempt to draw
water from the same; nor shall any person tap a water main, or insert a
stopcock or shutoff valve therein; except under the following circumstances:
   (A)   The individual or construction company seeking to use a fire hydrant
of the Village shall apply for a fire hydrant permit.
   (B)   Upon approval of said permit for use of a Village fire hydrant by the
user of said hydrant, the user shall pay a fee of one hundred twenty five
dollars ($125.00) to the Village.
   (C)   The permit issued to the fire hydrant user shall specify that damage
which accrues to the hydrant during the time of said use shall be repaired by
the Village and billed to the user of said hydrant and it shall be the user's
responsibility to pay for any repair to the hydrant. If court action becomes
necessary to collect a repair bill, the hydrant user shall bear all costs of
suit including attorney fees relating to collection of a repair bill.
   (D)   All hydrant permits issued by the Village shall be effective for a
maximum of thirty (30) days from the day of issuance unless otherwise specified
by the Village Board.
   (E)   The Village Water Department Superintendent shall attach a fire
hydrant meter to any hydrant being used by a private individual or construction
company for the purpose of recording the use of water from said hydrant. The
user shall be solely responsible for payment of any bill incurred for use of
water from the hydrant under the foregoing provisions. (Ord. 769, 10-3-1985)
3-3-8: STREET OPENINGS TO CONNECT:
All street openings and excavations for the purpose of tapping into water
supply lines shall be made by the Village upon written request to the Water
Department Superintendent by the consumer. The cost of such excavation work
shall be borne by the consumer and the payment for same shall be made at the
time said written request is made to tap into said water supply main. (Ord.
642, 2-5-1976)
3-3-9: WATER CHARGES DURING CONSTRUCTION:
The Village shall furnish water to contractors or owners of property during the
process of construction at a flat rate as follows: For any structure costing
one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) or less, the water furnished during the
process of construction shall be furnished at a flat rate of fifty dollars
($50.00). For any structure costing in excess of one million dollars
($1,000,000.00), water furnished during the process of construction shall be
furnished at a flat rate of seventy five dollars ($75.00). The amounts herein
provided for shall be paid by the owner of the premises upon which the building
is to be erected or by the contractor in charge of the construction of such
building. The cost of furnishing such water shall be paid in advance and at the
time request is made to the Village for the furnishing of said water. The
person, firm or corporation making such application for water shall, at the
time of applying for same, file with the Building Coordinator of the Village a
true statement under oath as to the estimated cost of the structure to be
erected. For the purpose of fixing the rate to be charged as provided herein,
the estimated cost, as shown by such statement, shall be considered as the cost
of the construction.
Any additional water other than that used for ordinary construction purposes
shall be billed to the contractor or owner by the Village. Any amount so billed
shall be in the sole discretion of the Water Department Superintendent or the
President and Board of Trustees of the Village based upon observations of any
Village officer or employee as to the additional water use. (Ord. 642, 2-5-
1976)
3-3-10: WATER RATES:
   (A)   Definitions: "Consumer" means any individual, corporation, partnership
or other business entity who purchases water from the Village.
   (B)   Water Rates: Effective June 1, 2023, the following monthly charges
will be assessed to the consumers of each independent premises where said water
is metered and registered by meter:
Gallons   
Gallons                              
0 to 35,000, inclusive               $155.00
35,001 to 100,000, inclusive        $6.81/1,000 gallons
100,001 to 500,000, inclusive       $6.67/1,000 gallons
500,001 to 1,000,000, inclusive     $6.59/1,000 gallons
1,000,001 to 6,000,000, inclusive   $6.46/1,000 gallons
6,000,001 to 25,000,000, inclusive  $6.29/1,000 gallons
25,000,001 and over                 $6.21/1,000 gallons
 
   These water rates shall not be applicable to residential property within the
Village.
   (C)   Future Rate Increases: Any and all future water rate increases
approved by the City of Chicago and which are applicable to the Village shall
be charged by the Village to its consumers and said consumers shall be
responsible for payment of the same.
   (D)   Notification Of Increase: The village clerk shall send written
notification of any increase to all users as soon as practicable. (Ord. 91-860,
12-5-1991; amd. Ord. 17-1539, 4-6-2017; Ord. 19-1598, 3-21-2019; Ord. 20-1628,
3-16-2020; Ord. 21-1663, 3-18-2021; Ord. 22-1696, 4-7-2022; Ord. 23-1716, 4-6-
2023)
3-3-11: BILLING:
All bills for water supplied by the village shall be due and payable on or
before the fifteenth day following the date of billing at the general offices
of the village, or at such other place or places as the president and board of
trustees may, from time to time designate. An additional charge of ten percent
(10%) of a bill shall be imposed for each month or portion thereof that any
such bill remains unpaid. After thirty (30) days of delinquency a notice of
delinquency will be sent to the delinquent consumer and if such bill is not
paid within ten (10) days of said notice, the president and board of trustees
may terminate the supply of water to the delinquent consumer and no liability
or cause of action for damages of any kind shall accrue therefor on or against
the village. (Ord. 715, 1-7-1982)
3-3-12: ACCESS TO INSPECT SYSTEMS:
Authorized representatives of the village shall have free access at all times
between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. to all
parts of every building in which water is delivered to make inspections,
examine pipes and fixtures and to make meter readings, and if such access is
refused, the supply of water may be cut off without further notice. (Ord. 642,
2-5-1976)
3-3-13: REPAIR OR REMOVAL OF METERS:
The repairing, setting or taking off of water meters shall be done only by the
authorized representatives of the village, and the cost of repairing any meter
shall be borne by the water consumer. (Ord. 642, 2-5-1976)
3-3-14: VIOLATIONS:
For the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or such others as
the president and board of trustees of the village may hereafter adopt, for the
government of water takers, the board reserves the right to stop the supply of
water to such users guilty of said violations without any preliminary notice;
nor will water be restored until the board is satisfied that no further
violations will occur and upon the payment by such violators of all expenses
incident to turning off said water and turning the same on again. Provided,
that the president and board of trustees reserve the right, power and authority
to cut off the supply of water at any time without incurring any liability or
cause of action for damages of any kind, any permit, grant or regulation to the
contrary notwithstanding. (Ord. 642, 2-5-1976)
3-3-15: PENALTIES:
Any person that has not paid its current water bill shall be sent a delinquency
notice by the village, by certified mail, thirty (30) days after the initial
current water bill has been posted.
Failure to pay the water bill within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the
delinquency notice shall result in the filing of a lien by the village against
the real estate owned, leased, or otherwise occupied by the delinquent water
user. Upon the filing of the lien, a copy of said lien shall be forwarded, by
certified mail, to the delinquent water user and/or the owner of the real
estate in cases wherein the two (2) persons are not one in the same.
The village will issue a release of lien against the title to the real estate
only upon payment in full of the delinquent water bill.
Any person shall violate any of the other, nonpayment provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 87-786, 9-17-1987)
CHAPTER 3A
WATER; CROSS CONNECTIONS
(Rep. by Ord. 91-831, 4-4-1991)
CHAPTER 3B
CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL PROGRAM
SECTION:
3-3B-1: Definitions
3-3B-2: Cross Connections Prohibited
3-3B-3: Backflow Preventers
3-3B-4: Cross Connection Control Survey
3-3B-5: Testing, Maintenance And Record Keeping
3-3B-6: Penalty For Violations
3-3B-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used
in this chapter shall be as follows:
AIR GAP: The unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between
the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank, plumbing
fixture or other device and the flood level rim of the receptacle.
APPROVED DEVICE: A cross connection control device approved by the Research
Foundation for Cross Connection Control of the University of Southern
California, American Water Works Association, American Society of Sanitary
Engineering, American National Standards Institute or certified by the National
Sanitation Foundation.
ATMOSPHERIC VACUUM BREAKER: An approved device designed to admit atmospheric
pressure into a piping system whenever a vacuum is caused on the upstream side
of the device.
AUXILIARY SUPPLY: Any water source or system other than the potable public
water supply system that is on or available to a premises. This includes water
that may originally have been supplied by the public water supply system.
BACKFLOW: The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the
distribution pipes of a potable water supply system from any source other than
the intended source of the potable water supply. Backsiphonage is one type of
backflow.
BACKFLOW PREVENTER: A cross connection control device, method, or type of
construction designed to prevent backflow.
CHECK VALVE: A self-closing cross connection control device that is designed to
permit the flow of fluids in one direction and to close if there is a reversal
of such flow.
CONTAMINATION: Any impairment of the quality of the water through the
introduction of any substance to a degree which could create a health hazard.
CROSS CONNECTION: Any physical connection or arrangement between two (2)
otherwise separate piping systems, one of which contains potable water and the
other containing water of unknown or questionable safety, or steam, gases or
chemicals whereby there may be a flow from one system to the other. A "direct
cross connection" is a cross connection formed when a water system is
physically joined to a source of unknown or unsafe substance. An "indirect
cross connection" means a cross connection formed when an unknown substance can
be forced, drawn by vacuum or otherwise introduced into a safe water system.
CUSTOMER'S WATER SYSTEM: Any water system, including the plumbing system within
a structure, located on the customer's premises.
DOUBLE CHECK VALVE ASSEMBLY: An approved device consisting of an assembly
composed of single, independently acting check valves. A double check valve
assembly must include tight shutoff valves located at each end of the assembly
and suitable connections for testing the watertightness of each check valve.
HEALTH HAZARD: Any conditions, devices or practices in the public water supply
system and its operation which create or, in the judgment of the person in
responsible charge, may create a danger to the health and well being of the
water customer.
IEPA: The Illinois environmental protection agency.
NONPOTABLE WATER: Water that is not safe for human consumption and use or which
does not meet state regulations for potable water.
PLUMBING: The actual installation, repair, maintenance, alteration or extension
of a plumbing system. Plumbing includes the water supply and distribution pipes
and all other fixtures and appliances used to supply water for any purpose.
Plumbing includes all piping from discharge of pumping units to and including
pressure tanks and water supply systems. Plumbing includes all piping and
fixtures for a building drain and any sanitary drainage and related ventilation
of any building from the point of connection of such building drain to the
building sewer or private sewage disposal system five feet (5') beyond the
foundation walls.
POTABLE WATER: Water which is free from contamination in amounts sufficient to
cause harmful effects and which meets the requirements of state regulations
regarding its bacteriological and chemical quality. Water which is safe for
drinking and other use.
PROCESS FLUID: Any fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically or
otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would
constitute a health, pollution or system hazard if introduced into the public
or a customer's potable water system. This includes, but is not limited to:
   (A)   Polluted or contaminated waters.
   (B)   Process waters.
   (C)   Used waters originating from the public water supply system which may
have deteriorated in sanitary quality.
   (D)   Cooling waters.
   (E)   Questionable or contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes,
streams or irrigation systems.
   (F)   Chemicals in solution or suspension.
   (G)   Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquid and gaseous fluids used
in industrial or other processes, or for firefighting purposes.
REDUCED PRESSURE PRINCIPLE BACKFLOW PREVENTER: An approved device consisting of
an assembly of two (2) check valves and a differential relief valve including
an automatically opened spillage port to the atmosphere designed to prevent
backflow. The assembly must include tightly closing shutoff valves located at
each end of the device and must be fitted with properly located test cocks.
(Ord. 91-831, 4-4-1991)
3-3B-2: CROSS CONNECTIONS PROHIBITED:
   (A)   Connections between potable water systems and other systems or
equipment containing water or other substances of unknown or questionable
quality are prohibited, except when and where approved cross connection control
devices or methods are installed, tested and maintained to ensure proper
operation on a continuing basis.
   (B)   1. No physical connection shall be permitted between the potable
portion of a supply and any other water supply not of equal or better
bacteriological and chemical quality as determined by inspection and analysis
by the IEPA.
      2.   There shall be no arrangement or connection by which an unsafe
substance may enter a supply.
      3.   No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public
water supply of the village enters the supply or distribution system of said
municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the
method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the
water supervisor and the IEPA.
   (C)   Complete removal of the cross connection or installation of an
approved cross connection control device is required for control of backflow
and backsiphonage. Only approved devices as defined in this chapter may be
installed in any plumbing system connected to the public water supply. Cross
connection control devices must be installed in accord with the manufacturer's
instructions and must be inspected at least annually by a person approved by
IEPA as a cross connection control device inspector (CCCDI). The inspection of
mechanical devices shall include physical testing in accord with the
manufacturer's instructions. (Ord. 91-831, 4-4-1991)
3-3B-3: BACKFLOW PREVENTERS:
   (A)   If, in accordance with this chapter, the Bedford Park plumbing code,
state regulations or, if in the opinion of the water supervisor, an approved
backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water
supply system, the water supervisor will give notice to the water customer
requiring the installation of such an approved device immediately. The water
customer or property owner, at no expense to the village, shall install such an
approved device at a location and in a manner in accordance with all applicable
local ordinances and state regulations, and shall have inspections and tests
made of such approved devices upon installation and as required by local
ordinances and state regulations.
   (B)   An approved backflow preventer shall be installed on each service line
to a customer's water system when, in the judgment of the water supervisor,
actual or potential hazards to the public water supply system exist, and when
the following conditions exist:
      1.   Premises having an auxiliary water supply unless such auxiliary
supply is accepted as an additional source by the water commissioner and the
source is approved by the IEPA.
      2.   Premises on which any substance is handled which can create an
actual or potential hazard to the public water supply system. This shall
include premises having sources or systems containing process fluids or waters
originating from the public water supply system which are no longer under the
sanitary control of the village.
      3.   Premises having internal cross connections that, in the judgment of
the water supervisor and the cross connection control device inspector, are not
correctable or premises having intricate plumbing arrangements which make it
impractical to determine whether or not cross connections exist.
      4.   Premises where, because of security requirements or other
prohibitions or restrictions, it is impossible or impractical to make a
complete cross connection survey.
      5.   Premises having a repeated history of cross connections being
established or reestablished.
   (C)   In accord with IEPA regulations (35 Illinois administrative code
section 653.803(c)(4)), water service lines which connect the public water
supply to industrial or commercial establishments shall include either a
reduced pressure principle backflow preventer or a fixed proper air gap with
repumping if those establishments constitute a hazard to the water supply due
to the nature of chemicals or other material handled within the facility. In
addition, an approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each
service line to a customer's water system serving, but not necessarily limited
to, the following types of facilities unless the water commissioner determines
that no actual or potential hazard to the public water supply system exist:
      1.   Hospitals, mortuaries, clinics, nursing homes.
      2.   Laboratories.
      3.   Piers, docks, waterfront facilities.
      4.   Sewage treatment plants, sewage pumping stations or storm water
pumping stations.
      5.   Food or beverage processing plants.
      6.   Chemical plants.
      7.   Metal plating industries.
      8.   Petroleum processing or storage plants.
      9.   Radioactive material processing plants or nuclear reactors.
      10.   Car washes.
      11.   Pesticide, herbicide or extermination plants and trucks.
      12.   Farm service and fertilizer plants and trucks.
   (D)   In accord with IEPA regulations (35 Illinois administrative code
section 653.805), where a public water supply or an auxiliary water supply is
used for a fire protection system, reduced pressure principle backflow
preventers shall be installed on fire safety systems connected to the public
water supply when:
      1.   The fire safety system contains antifreeze, fire retardant or other
chemicals;
      2.   Water is pumped into the system from another source;
      3.   Water flows by gravity from a nonpotable source; or
      4.   There is a connection whereby another source can be connected to the
fire safety system.
   (E)   Backflow preventers shall not be made inoperative, bypassed, removed
or otherwise made ineffective without specific authorization by the water
commissioner.
   (F)   Where a booster pump has been installed on the service line to or
within any premises, such pump shall be equipped with a low pressure cutoff
device designed to shut off the pump when the pressure in the service line on
the suction side of the pump drops to twenty (20) psi or below. The low
pressure cutoff device shall be inspected at least annually by the customer to
ensure that it works properly. (Ord. 91-831, 4-4-1991)
3-3B-4: CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL SURVEY:
In accord with IEPA regulations (35 Illinois administrative code section
653.801), the water supervisor shall conduct or cause the conducting of a cross
connection control device survey of the distribution system which shall be
conducted at least every two (2) years by the village or an authorized agent of
the village. The survey need not include actual visual inspection of plumbing
systems, but by telephone, mail or other personal contact with the owner,
occupant or manager of property, must attempt to survey and compile an
inventory of cross connection control devices in place on industrial,
commercial and other property connected to the public water supply where
devices are required. Records compiled from such surveys shall be maintained
and available for review for at least five (5) years from the completion of the
survey. The refusal to supply requested survey information shall, within the
discretion of the water supervisor, be deemed evidence of the presence of
improper connections and appropriate action may be taken as prescribed by this
chapter. (Ord. 91-831, 4-4-1991)
3-3B-5: TESTING, MAINTENANCE AND RECORD KEEPING:
   (A)   In accord with IEPA regulations (35 Illinois administrative code
section 653.802(c) and (e)) and this chapter, it is the duty of the customer on
any premises where cross connection control devices are required to cause such
devices to be tested at least annually or more frequently if recommended by the
manufacturer and to keep records of testing results and maintenance performed.
Testing shall be at the customer's expense and shall be performed by a cross
connection control device inspector (CCCDI), or a person otherwise authorized
by IEPA to perform such testing, who shall be selected by the customer.
   (B)   Each device shall have a tag attached listing the date of the most
recent test, name of the tester and the type and date of repairs. Repairs
required for double check valve assemblies shall be performed within fifteen
(15) days and those required for reduced pressure principle backflow preventers
shall be performed within five (5) days of the discovery of their need. Repairs
or replacement shall be at the expense of the customer or property owner.
   (C)   Customers must maintain a maintenance log documenting each device and
including:
      1.   Date of each test or visual inspection;
      2.   Name and approval number of the person performing the test or visual
inspection;
      3.   Test results;
      4.   Repairs or servicing required;
      5.   Repairs and date completed; and
      6.   Servicing performed and date completed.
   (D)   Within seven (7) days of the testing of devices or the completion of
repairs initiated as a result of such testing as required by this chapter, the
customer shall furnish to the water supervisor a record of the test results and
repairs containing, at a minimum, the information specified in subsection (C)
of this section. In addition, on request of the water supervisor or an
authorized representative, the customer shall furnish to the village
maintenance records or other requested information regarding the customer's
plumbing system. The customer shall make the premises available for inspection
at all reasonable times for verification of information supplied to the village
regarding cross connection control device inspection results. Failure to
provide the information or access to the premises as required by this
subsection (D) shall, within the discretion of the water supervisor, be deemed
evidence of the presence of improper connections.
   (E)   Cross connection control devices located in the treatment plant, well
house or booster station of the village public water supply facility shall be
inspected at least annually by either an approved cross connection control
device inspector or by a certified water supply operator trained for testing,
installation, repair and maintenance of cross connection control devices.
Records regarding these devices must be kept by the village in the same fashion
as those required to be kept by customers. (Ord. 91-831, 4-4-1991)
3-3B-6: PENALTY FOR VIOLATIONS:
   (A)   The water supervisor shall take reasonable precautionary measures or
may deny or discontinue, after reasonable notice to the owner or the
representative of the owner and the owner's or customer's failure to correct
the violation, the water service to any property wherein an illegal cross
connection is known to exist; wherein required cross connection control devices
are not being inspected, tested, maintained or repaired as required by this
chapter; or wherein it is found that a device has been bypassed or removed.
Applicable water service connection fees may be reassessed by the village in
situations where service is discontinued under this chapter and then started
again at a later date.
   (B)   Any person responsible for backsiphoned material or contamination
through backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply system occurs
through an illegal cross connection or an improperly installed, maintained or
repaired device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear the cost of
clean up of the potable water supply system.
   (C)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter may be
fined up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense and a separate
offense shall be deemed to have been committed on each day during which a
violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 91-831, 4-4-1991)
CHAPTER 4
HOUSE NUMBERING
SECTION:
3-4-1: Numbering Required
3-4-2: North-South Numbering
3-4-3: East-West Numbering
3-4-4: Allotment Of Numbers
3-4-5: Odd-Even Numbers
3-4-6: Prefix To Numbers
3-4-7: Assignment Of Numbers
3-4-8: Display Of Numbers
3-4-9: Penalty
3-4-10: Change Of Numbers
3-4-1: NUMBERING REQUIRED:
It is hereby made the duty of the owner, agent or person in possession of every
building to number the same in the manner herein provided. (Ord. 26, 1-2-1941)
3-4-2: NORTH-SOUTH NUMBERING:
All lots or houses located upon north and south streets or on streets running
in a northerly or southerly direction shall be numbered from the northern line
of the village southward, beginning with a number corresponding with the
corresponding east and west street extended west from the streets in the city
of Chicago. (Ord. 26, 1-2-1941)
3-4-3: EAST-WEST NUMBERING:
All lots or houses located upon east and west streets or on streets running in
an easterly or westerly direction shall be numbered from the east line of the
village, being at Cicero Avenue, also known as Forty Eighth Avenue, beginning
with the number 4800 and running westerly. (Ord. 26, 1-2-1941)
3-4-4: ALLOTMENT OF NUMBERS:
There shall be assigned to each mile eight hundred (800) numbers, or one
hundred (100) numbers to each one-eighth (1/8) of a mile, on all streets, and
such numbers shall change from any one hundred (100) to the succeeding one
hundred (100) at the intersecting street nearest the said one-eighth (1/8) of a
mile line. (Ord. 26, 1-2-1941)
3-4-5: ODD-EVEN NUMBERS:
The even numbers on north and south streets, or streets running in a northerly
or southerly direction, shall be on the west side of said streets, the even
numbers on east and west streets, or streets running in an easterly or westerly
direction, shall be on the north side of the streets. (Ord. 26, 1-2-1941)
3-4-6: PREFIX TO NUMBERS:
All north and south streets, or streets running in a northerly or southerly
direction, shall bear the prefix south, and all east and west streets, or
streets running in an easterly or westerly direction, shall bear the prefix
west. (Ord. 26, 1-2-1941)
3-4-7: ASSIGNMENT OF NUMBERS 1 :
The building inspector shall assign or cause to be assigned to each lot or
