jurisdictions, local health departments certified by the Illinois department of
public health are authorized to provide the same continuing programs. (Ord. 06-
1198, 4-6-2006, eff. 6-1-2006)
4-6-12: OTHER APPLICABLE LAWS:
This chapter shall not be interpreted or be construed to permit smoking where
it is otherwise restricted by other applicable laws. (Ord. 06-1198, 4-6-2006,
eff. 6-1-2006)
CHAPTER 7
NOISE REGULATIONS 1
SECTION:
4-7-1: Definitions
4-7-2: Noise, Amplified Sound
4-7-3: Power Landscape Equipment
4-7-4: Construction Noise
4-7-5: Mechanical Equipment Noise
4-7-6: Excessive Noise Prohibited
4-7-7: Enforcement
4-7-8: Abatement Of Noise Source
4-7-9: Penalties
 
Notes
1 1. See also title IX, chapter 18 of this code.
4-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
NOISE OR SOUND LEVEL: The weighted sound pressure level obtained by the use of
a sound level meter and frequency weighting network "A" as specified in
American National Standards Institute specifications for sound level meters
(ANSI SI.4-1971, or the latest approved revision thereof), using a sound level
meter meeting ANSI standards for type 1 or type 2 sound level meters or an
instrument and associated recording the analyzing equipment that will provide
equivalent data to measure compliance.
Sound level measurements using sound meters may be administered by members of
the police department or any other authorized employees of the village, all of
whom shall have received specific training in the application, department
guidelines and procedures, and operation of the approved sound meter for the
measurement of sound that conforms to the standards and recommended practices
established by the American National Standards Institute.
QUIET HOURS: Quiet hours shall be from ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. until seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. the following day, unless the following day is a Saturday,
Sunday or nationally recognized holiday, in which case quiet hours shall be
from eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. until nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. the following
day.
QUIET HOURS SOUND LIMITS: (A) Sound emitting from any single-unit property
shall not be plainly audible at any point beyond the lot line of that property.
   (B)   Sound emitting from inside any dwelling unit of a multi-unit structure
shall not be plainly audible beyond the walls of that dwelling unit.
   (C)   Sound emitting from elsewhere within, or outdoors upon the property of
a multi-unit structure shall not be plainly audible inside any dwelling unit of
that structure, nor at any point beyond the lot lines of that property.
   (D)   Sound emitting from any other location shall not be plainly audible at
any point more than thirty feet (30') in any direction from the sound source.
SOUND LIMITS IN DECIBELS (dB) DURING TIMES OTHER THAN QUIET HOURS: (A) Sound
emitting from any single-unit property shall not exceed sixty five (65) dB at
any one point beyond the lot line of that property.
   (B)   Sound emitting from inside any dwelling unit of a multi-unit structure
shall not exceed fifty five (55) dB beyond the walls of that dwelling unit.
   (C)   Sound emitting from elsewhere within or outdoors upon the property of
a multi-unit structure shall not exceed fifty five (55) dB inside any dwelling
unit of that structure, nor sixty five (65) dB beyond the lot lines of the
structure's property.
   (D)   Sound emitting from any other location shall not exceed sixty five
(65) dBa at any one point more than thirty feet (30') in any direction from the
sound source. (Ord. 07-1218, 2-1-2007)
4-7-2: NOISE, AMPLIFIED SOUND:
   (A)   During Quiet Hours: During the quiet hours, no person shall cause or
permit the sound of persons talking, yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or
singing or the sound of any television, radio, stereo set, musical instrument,
phonograph, amplifier, loudspeaker or other similar device for the production
or amplification of sound to exceed the limits defined herein.
   (B)   Sound Limits At Times Other Than Quiet Hours: No person shall cause or
permit sounds of the types defined in subsection (A) of this section to exceed
the limits defined in section
4-7-1 of this chapter, if such sounds disturb the comfort or repose of
reasonable persons of normal sensibilities within the area of audibility. (Ord.
07-1218, 2-1-2007)
4-7-3: POWER LANDSCAPE EQUIPMENT:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to operate or use any power landscape equipment
in a manner that is plainly audible beyond the boundaries of the premises upon
which such equipment is operated or used; provided, however, the use or
operation of power lawn equipment shall be lawful:
      1.   Between seven thirty o'clock (7:30) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00)
P.M. on Mondays through Fridays, inclusive, and between nine o'clock (9:00)
A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. on Saturdays, Sundays and nationally
recognized holidays;
      2.   On golf courses at any time; and
      3.   On park district owned or maintained property at any time.
   (B)   For the purposes of this section, "power landscape equipment" shall
mean all landscape equipment powered by any source other than manual power that
is used for landscaping or lawn maintenance activities including, without
limitation, mowers, tractors, trimmers, vacuums, blowers, tillers or hedge
clippers. (Ord. 07-1218, 2-1-2007)
4-7-4: CONSTRUCTION NOISE:
   (A)   No person shall cause or permit construction/demolition noise which is
plainly audible beyond the boundaries of the property from which it emanates,
other than between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:
00) P.M. Monday through Friday, and between nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and five
o'clock (5:00) P.M. Saturday, and not at all on Sunday or nationally recognized
holidays, except in cases of urgent necessity in the interest of public health
and safety.
   (B)   For the purpose of this chapter, "construction/demolition noise" is
defined as sound emissions associated with the construction or demolition of
any building or structure, to include, without limitation, activities such as:
grading, excavation, demolition, alteration or repair; and loading, unloading,
starting, moving or preparation of any materials, supplies equipment or
personnel; or the idling of engines on motor vehicles exceeding eight thousand
(8,000) pounds gross vehicle weight, while such vehicles are standing upon or
adjacent to job sites.
   (C)   Construction activities performed not for compensation, by a person
upon his own property where he resides, shall be exempt from the prohibitions
of this chapter seven (7) days per week, provided, however, that noise
emissions associated with such work shall not be plainly audible beyond the
boundaries of the property from which it emanates between the hours of ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. (Ord. 07-1218, 2-1-2007)
4-7-5: MECHANICAL EQUIPMENT NOISE:
   (A)   Except temporarily in the case of urgent necessity to protect public
health or safety, no person shall cause or permit the operation of any blower,
fan, pump, or compressor, or engine or motor in connection therewith including,
without limitation, stationary motor vehicle engines, fixed or vehicle mounted
heating, ventilation, refrigeration or cooling systems, pool filtration
systems, generators or other such mechanical equipment, which emits noise of a
continuous or penetrating nature that disturbs the comfort or repose of any
reasonable person of ordinary sensibilities occupying residential property
within the area of audibility, if the sound level of such noise exceeds the
residential noise level standards.
   (B)   Noise defined in subsection (A) of this section, emitted from any
property shall not exceed the average sound levels set forth in this subsection
upon any portion of any other property if such other property is zoned for
residential use:
      1.   Between ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.:
Sixty three (63) decibels (dB).
      2.   Between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.:
Sixty eight (68) decibels (dB). (Ord. 07-1218, 2-1-2007)
4-7-6: EXCESSIVE NOISE PROHIBITED:
It is hereby unlawful for any person or corporation to commit or cause to
commit any excessive sound and/or noise as indicated in sections
4-7-1,
4-7-2,
4-7-3,
4-7-4, and
4-7-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 07-1218, 2-1-2007)
4-7-7: ENFORCEMENT:
The Bedford Park code enforcement officer shall have the authority to enforce
the provisions of this chapter and direct the immediate termination of any
noise source determined to be excessive. (Ord. 07-1218, 2-1-2007)
4-7-8: ABATEMENT OF NOISE SOURCE:
Upon finding of a violation of the standards herein, the person or corporation
causing or permitting the noise to continue shall be advised of the violation
and given an opportunity to abate the noise level. (Ord. 07-1218, 2-1-2007)
4-7-9: PENALTIES:
Any person or corporation found guilty of violating, disobeying, omitting,
neglecting or refusing to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall be
fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed to be
committed for each day that a violation exists. In addition to the imposition
of fines, the person or corporation may be directed to correct, repair or
remedy the code violation at its sole cost and expense. Noncompliance with the
provisions of this chapter is a basis for the revocation of a business
certificate. (Ord. 07-1218, 2-1-2007)
CHAPTER 8
DISCHARGE OF WASTE INTO SEWER SYSTEM
SECTION:
4-8-1: Prohibition
4-8-2: Sources Of Illicit Discharges
4-8-3: Exempt Discharges
4-8-4: Construction Site Runoff
4-8-5: Postconstruction Runoff
4-8-6: Penalties
4-8-1: PROHIBITION:
It shall be unlawful and prohibited for any individual, partnership, company or
other business entity to allow or permit or cause to allow or permit the
illicit discharges of waste and wastewater from nonstormwater sources. (Ord.
09-1294, 5-7-2009)
4-8-2: SOURCES OF ILLICIT DISCHARGES:
The following list is to be considered sources of illicit discharges:
   (A)   Sanitary wastewater.
   (B)   Effluent from septic tanks.
   (C)   Car wash wastewaters.
   (D)   Improper oil disposal.
   (E)   Radiator flushing disposal.
   (F)   Laundry wastewaters.
   (G)   Spills from roadway accidents.
   (H)   Improper disposal of auto and household toxins. (Ord. 09-1294, 5-7-
2009)
4-8-3: EXEMPT DISCHARGES:
The following list is to be considered exempt discharges:
   (A)   Water line flushing.
   (B)   Landscape irrigation.
   (C)   Diverted stream flows.
   (D)   Rising groundwaters.
   (E)   Uncontaminated groundwater infiltration.
   (F)   Uncontaminated pumped groundwater.
   (G)   Discharges from potable water.
   (H)   Foundation drains.
   (I)   Air conditioning condensation.
   (J)   Irrigation water.
   (K)   Springs.
   (L)   Water from crawl space pumps.
   (M)   Footing drains.
   (N)   Lawn watering.
   (O)   Individual residential car washing.
   (P)   Dechlorinated swimming pool discharges.
   (Q)   Street wash water. (Ord. 09-1294, 5-7-2009)
4-8-4: CONSTRUCTION SITE RUNOFF:
Any contractor of any kind doing business within the village of Bedford Park
must utilize the best management practice at a construction site to prevent
runoff. (Ord. 09-1294, 5-7-2009)
4-8-5: POSTCONSTRUCTION RUNOFF:
Subsequent to the completion of a construction project, any contractor of any
kind shall adhere to the best management practice in order to eliminate
postconstruction runoff. The best management practices shall include the
following procedures:
   (A)   Storage practices:
      1.   Wet ponds.
      2.   Dry basins.
      3.   Multichamber catch basins.
   (B)   Infiltration practices:
      1.   Infiltration basins/trenches.
      2.   Dry wells.
      3.   Porous pavement.
   (C)   Vegetative practices:
      1.   Grassy swales.
      2.   Filter strips.
      3.   Artificial wetlands.
      4.   Rain gardens. (Ord. 09-1294, 5-7-2009)
4-8-6: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation who is found to be in violation of this chapter
shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues
to exist. (Ord. 09-1294, 5-7-2009)
TITLE V
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
FIRE INSURANCE TAX
SECTION:
5-1-1: Compliance Required
5-1-2: Amount Of Tax
5-1-3: Premium Report
5-1-4: Liability For Tax
5-1-5: Agent's Responsibility
5-1-1: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any corporation or association, not incorporated under
the laws of the state of Illinois, to transact any business of fire insurance
in the village, while in default by not fully complying with any of the
requirements of this chapter, and until such requirements shall have been fully
complied with; but this provision shall not relieve any company, corporation or
association from the payment of any risk that may be undertaken in violation of
this chapter. (Ord. 35, 7-19-1941)
5-1-2: AMOUNT OF TAX:
Any such corporation, company or association not incorporated under the laws of
the state of Illinois, which is engaged in the village in effecting fire
insurance, shall pay the treasurer, for the maintenance, use and benefit of the
fire department, a sum of money equal in amount to two percent (2%) per annum
of the gross receipts received as premiums upon fire insurance policies by any
and all agents of such corporation, company or association, during the year
ending on July 1 in each year, for any insurance effected, or agreed to be
effected on property located in the village, by or with such corporation,
company or association during such year. (Ord. 35, 7-19-1941)
5-1-3: PREMIUM REPORT:
Every person acting as agent, for or on behalf of any such corporation, company
or association, shall, on or before July 15 of each and every year, render the
clerk a full, true and just account verified by his oath, of all premiums upon
fire insurance policies which, during the year ending July 1 preceding such
report, shall have been received by him, or by some other person for him, in
his behalf of any such corporation, company or association on property located
in the village. Such agent shall also at the time of rendering the aforesaid
report, pay to the village treasurer the sum of money for which company,
corporation or association, represented by him is chargeable, by virtue of the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 35, 7-19-1941)
5-1-4: LIABILITY FOR TAX:
The sum of money for which such company, corporation or association is so
chargeable may be recovered of it, or its agents or agent, by an action in the
name of and for the use of the village as for money had and received. Nothing
in this section shall be held to exempt any person, corporation, company or
association from indictment and conviction under the provisions of an act
entitled "an act to enable cities, towns and villages, organized under any
general or special law, to levy and collect a tax or license fee from foreign
insurance companies for the benefit of organized fire departments", in force
July 1, 1895. (Ord. 35, 7-19-1941)
5-1-5: AGENT'S RESPONSIBILITY:
No insurance agent in the village shall have any insurance business or dealings
with any company, association or corporation not incorporated under the laws of
this state, which shall be in default for not reporting or making payments as
hereinbefore provided, until it shall have complied with all the requirements
of this chapter. (Ord. 35, 7-19-1941)
CHAPTER 2
TAXICABS
SECTION:
5-2-1: Definitions
5-2-2: Scope; Jurisdiction; Number Of Licenses Issued
5-2-3: Taxicab Service
5-2-4: Licenses Required
5-2-5: Taxicab Company Licenses
5-2-6: Insurance Requirements
5-2-7: Taxicab Vehicle License
5-2-8: Vehicle Inspections
5-2-9: Vehicle Requirements
5-2-10: Rates Of Fare
5-2-11: Taxicab Driver's License
5-2-12: Driver Qualifications
5-2-13: Application; Term; Renewal; Late Penalty
5-2-14: Record Of Licenses
5-2-15: Taxicab Driver's License Suspension Or Revocation
5-2-16: Conduct And Appearance Of Taxicab Drivers
5-2-17: Mandatory Operations; Abandonment Of Service
5-2-18: Register Of Licensed Vehicles
5-2-19: Condition Of Vehicle; License Suspension Or Revocation
5-2-20: Violation; Penalty
5-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly stated, whenever used in this chapter, the following
terms shall respectively be deemed to mean:
DRIVER: Any person driving a taxicab.
OPERATOR: Any person engaging in the business of the operation of a taxicab and
having control of the operation and maintenance of a taxicab or of the
collection of revenue from its operation.
TAXICAB: All public vehicles driven by mechanical power used to transport
passengers for hire, except those vehicles commonly known as buses.
TAXICAB COMPANY: Every individual, trustee, partnership, association, firm or
corporation engaged in business as a proprietor, franchisor or dispatcher of
one or more taxicabs.
TAXIMETER: A mechanical instrument or device by which the charge for hire of a
taxicab is mechanically calculated, either for distance traveled or for waiting
time, or for both, and upon which such charge shall be indicated by means of
figures. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-2: SCOPE; JURISDICTION; NUMBER OF LICENSES ISSUED:
   (A)   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prohibit any public
passenger vehicle from coming into the village to discharge passengers accepted
for transportation outside the village.
   (B)   The village clerk shall be responsible for licensing all taxicabs and
owner/operators operating taxicabs within the village.
   (C)   The village clerk shall issue a total of thirty (30) taxicab vehicle
licenses on an annual basis, which shall be issued on a first come, first
served basis. A taxicab company shall not be entitled to more than ten (10)
such vehicle licenses. Applications must be complete at the time of submission
with the village clerk's office. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-3: TAXICAB SERVICE:
Every owner and driver is required to furnish reasonably safe and adequate
service at just and reasonable rates within the village as may reasonably be
required to ensure adequate accommodations to the public in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-4: LICENSES REQUIRED:
   (A)   Taxicab Company License: No taxicab company shall engage in business
unless there shall first have been obtained therefor licenses from the village
clerk.
   (B)   Taxicab Vehicle License: No person shall operate a taxicab without
first having obtained a valid taxicab vehicle license in the manner set forth
in this chapter and unless the license is in full force and effect.
   (C)   Taxicab Driver's License: No person shall operate a taxicab as the
driver thereof without first having obtained a valid taxicab driver's license
in the manner set forth in this chapter and unless the license is in full force
and effect. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-5: TAXICAB COMPANY LICENSES:
All taxicab companies must be licensed as set forth below:
   (A)   Applications: Applications for taxicab company licenses shall be made
in writing to the village clerk on forms as reasonably required and approved by
the village administrator. Such application shall contain the following:
      1.   The address of the company's principal place of business;
      2.   The full name and address of the owner or operator;
      3.   The financial status of the applicant, including the amounts of all
unpaid judgments that arise from operation within the village against the
applicant and the nature of the transaction or acts giving rise to such
judgments;
      4.   The number of vehicles to be operated or controlled by the applicant
and the location of proposed depots and terminals;
      5.   The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate the vehicle or
vehicles of the applicant;
      6.   A rate sheet to be in effect for the period the taxicab company
license shall be in effect;
      7.   Any facts which the applicant believes tend to prove that public
convenience and necessity require the granting of a license;
      8.   Such further information as the village clerk may require.
   (B)   Color Similarity: All taxicabs owned or operated by or on behalf of a
taxicab business licensee shall be identically painted so that they are readily
identifiable. However, no coloring scheme or name shall be similar to that of
any other taxicab company which has previously been issued a taxicab license by
the village.
   (C)   License Fee: Each applicant for a taxicab company license shall submit
to the village clerk at the time of filing its application, a license fee of
three hundred dollars ($300.00). This license fee shall be nonrefundable.
   (D)   Renewal: Each licensee shall annually pay the license fee in full for
each taxicab company license before November 1 of each year.
   (E)   Penalty: If licensee does not renew his/her license and pay the annual
license fee, the licensee will incur a penalty of one hundred percent (100%) of
the annual license fee, in addition to the annual license fee.
   (F)   Change Of Address: If a licensee holding a taxicab company license
under this chapter changes its principal place of business, it shall notify the
village clerk in writing. Upon receipt, the village clerk shall make the
necessary alteration to the village's records. No fee shall be required for a
change in address.
   (G)   Change Of Ownership: If ownership of a cab company licensed under this
chapter is conveyed to a new owner, said new owner shall apply for a new
license in its name in accordance with this chapter. There shall be no transfer
of a license from one owner of a business to another. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-6: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
Each taxicab company must comply with the following insurance requirements:
   (A)   Every licensee shall carry public liability and property damage
insurance and, where applicable, workers' compensation insurance for his
employees with solvent and responsible insurers approved by the village
attorney, licensed by and authorized to do business in the state of Illinois,
and qualified under the laws of Illinois to assume the risk in the amount
hereinafter set forth, to secure payment by the licensee, his agents, employees
or lessees of any final judgment or settlement of any claim against them
resulting from any occurrence caused by or arising out of the operation or use
of any of the licensee's public passenger vehicles. All insurance policies
shall name the village, its officers, and agents as additional insured.
   (B)   Every insurance policy or contract for such insurance shall provide
that suit may be brought in any court of competent jurisdiction upon such
policy or contract by any person for the payment and satisfaction of any final
judgment rendered against the licensee or person insured arising from the
operation or use of such vehicle.
   (C)   Every public liability insurance policy must meet the requirements of
state law, governing coverage for damages from owners or operators of uninsured
motor vehicles, hit and run motor vehicles, and underinsured motorists.
   (D)   Each public liability insurance policy shall provide for coverage in
an amount as required by state law, as may be amended from time to time 1 .
   (E)   The insurance policy shall contain a description of each public
passenger vehicle insured, manufacturer's name and number, the state license
number and the public passenger vehicle license number.
   (F)   All insurance policies or contracts as required by this section, or
copies thereof certified by the insurers or sureties shall be filed with the
village clerk. The policy shall be further endorsed to provide thirty (30) day
advance notice of any cancellation thereof to the village clerk. If any
insurance policy is canceled or permitted to lapse for any reason, the village
shall suspend the license for the vehicle affected for a period not to exceed
ten (10) days to permit another insurance policy to be supplied in compliance
with the provisions of this section. If such other insurance policy is not
supplied within the period of suspension of the license, the village shall
revoke the license for such vehicle. In the event that such insurance is
supplied, the commissioner shall nevertheless suspend the license for each
vehicle affected for an additional period of five (5) days for every day of
noncompliance, except by reason of the insolvency of the insurer without
advance written notice to the licensee, for the first such violation of
insurance requirements, and a period of ten (10) days for every day of
noncompliance for the second such violation within any three (3) year period.
The third violation of this insurance requirement within any three (3) year
period shall result in revocation of the licenses of the affected vehicles.
(Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/8-109.
5-2-7: TAXICAB VEHICLE LICENSE:
No taxicab vehicle may be operated in the village unless the person who owns
and operates or drives the taxicab shall have first obtained a taxicab vehicle
license issued in accordance with this chapter. Every such owner shall comply
with the following licensing requirements:
   (A)   Contents Of Application: Each taxicab vehicle license applicant shall
submit in writing to the clerk an application that includes the following
information:
      1.   A full description of the motor vehicle for which the license is
desired, including the make, model and vehicle identification number and the
state license number;
      2.   The length of time the vehicle has been in use, the number of
persons it is capable of carrying;
      3.   Any other information that the mayor or the village clerk may
require.
   (B)   License Fees: Each applicant shall submit the annual fee of three
hundred dollars ($300.00) to the village clerk at the time of submitting the
application. This annual license fee shall be paid for each and every taxicab
which shall operate upon the streets of the village. Such license fee shall be
in lieu of the regular annual vehicle sticker fees charged by the village for
motor vehicles housed in the village as heretofore established.
   (C)   Renewal: Each licensee shall annually pay the license fee in full for
each taxicab vehicle license before November 1 of each year.
   (D)   Penalty: If licensee does not renew his/her license and pay the annual
license fee before November 1 the licensee will incur a penalty of one hundred
percent (100%) of the annual license fee, in addition to the annual license
fee.
   (E)   Verification Of State Registration: Such application shall thereupon
be referred by the village clerk to the chief of police who shall verify that
the taxicab is properly registered with the state of Illinois. Upon approval of
the chief of police of the application, he shall so endorse the application and
file same with the village clerk, who shall, upon payment of the required fee,
issue the license.
   (F)   Issuance Of License: Upon approval of the chief of police, payment of
the fee, and verification that the applicant has complied with all requirements
of this chapter, the village clerk shall issue the license.
   (G)   Term Of License: Such licenses shall be issued annually on November 1
in each and every year and shall be valid for one year to and including October
31 next succeeding year unless sooner suspended or revoked. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-
2010)
5-2-8: VEHICLE INSPECTIONS:
All vehicles are subject to the following inspections:
   (A)   All licenses under this chapter must be accompanied by a satisfactory
completed vehicle inspection report stating that the vehicle is in a good and
safe mechanical condition. Said safety test shall be conducted by a duly
licensed state mechanic. The passing of the safety test shall not be a bar at
any time to prosecution for operating or causing to be operated a taxicab not
in good and safe condition. Charges for all safety inspections are to be paid
by the owner/operator of the taxicab.
   (B)   Any member of the police department designated by the chief of police
shall inspect the outward appearance of all taxicabs to assure compliance with
similar colors, signage, lighted dome light, taximeter placement and lighted
dial and general condition of the vehicle before licensing by the village
clerk.
   (C)   It shall be the duty of the owner of each taxicab to submit to the
chief of police each taxicab for inspection prior to the issuance of a license.
   (D)   No vehicle shall be issued a license until it has been thoroughly
inspected and examined and found to be in a thoroughly safe condition for the
transportation of passengers, clean, fit, of good appearance and well painted.
   (E)   The chief of police or his designated inspector(s) may inspect any
taxicab from time to time that he may feel is in a condition not fit for public
use in compliance with this chapter as written and Illinois state law, or on
the complaint of any person or persons. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-9: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
All taxicab vehicles shall comply with the following requirements:
   (A)   Size: Licenses may be issued for vehicles to operate as taxicabs only
if the vehicle has a capacity for no more than six (6) passengers, excluding
the driver. No vehicle shall be licensed unless it has two (2) doors on each
side, and is a "full size" vehicle or larger. Exceptions shall be made for
specialty vehicles or hybrid vehicles.
   (B)   Name And Phone Number: Every taxicab licensed as provided in this
chapter shall bear on the outside of the vehicle, in a conspicuous place, the
name and phone number of the operator thereof, in letters not less than two
inches (2") high, which letters shall be of a contrasting color to the color of
the vehicle, and shall be properly proportioned and legible.
   (C)   Lighted Dome: The cab shall also have a lighted dome light on the roof
of the vehicle noting that the vehicle is a taxicab.
   (D)   License Decal: The taxicab vehicle license to be issued by the village
clerk as hereinabove provided shall be in the form of a decal. Said decal shall
be affixed to the bottom left rear window of the taxicab.
   (E)   Taximeter: Every taxicab operated by a taxicab company and licensed by
the village shall be equipped with a taximeter, in good working order,
connected with and operating from the transmission of the taxicab.
      1.   Visibility: No taxicab vehicle license shall be issued unless and
until said taximeter functions as follows:
During the period between sunset and sunrise, be equipped with a light which
shall be so reflected upon the dial of the taximeter as to enable the passenger
or passengers engaging and using such taxicab to read the figures thereon.
Every taximeter hereafter placed on a taxicab shall be so arranged that the
dial thereof is in plain view of the passenger while riding in such taxicab, or
upon alighting from the same.
      2.   Inspection: No license shall be issued for a taxicab until the
taximeter attached thereto shall have been inspected by the inspector of
weights and measures as provided herein and proof thereof provided to the
village clerk.
      3.   Testing: No person owning or operating any taxicab shall offer or
let the same for hire or reward anywhere within the village unless the
taximeter placed, attached or installed thereon has been inspected and tested
by said inspector.
      4.   Transfer Of Meters: No person shall detach any certified or
inspected taximeter from any taxicab and attach the same to any other taxicab,
the front wheels of which are of a different diameter than those with reference
to which said taximeter was originally tested, unless a new inspection or
certification is made on such taximeter.
      5.   Unapproved Meters: No person shall drive a vehicle to which is
attached a taximeter that has not been duly inspected and approved.
      6.   Credit Card Payments: Each vehicle shall be equipped to process
credit card payments by passengers.
      7.   No Smoking: It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke any tobacco
at any time in any taxicab.
      8.   Cellular Telephone: Taxicab operators may not use cellular
telephones while transporting passengers.
      9.   Insurance: The application for a taxicab vehicle license shall be
accompanied by evidence of the liability insurance as required in section
5-2-6 of this chapter.
      10.   Nontransferable: It shall be unlawful to transfer any taxicab
vehicle license from one vehicle to another. Transferring any taxicab vehicle
license shall be grounds for revocation of all licenses issued pursuant to this
chapter to both the owner of the license and the vehicle to which the license
is transferred. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-10: RATES OF FARE:
Taxicab maximum rates shall be as follows:
   (A)   Two dollars twenty five cents ($2.25) upon hire for the first
passenger and one dollar ($1.00) for each additional passenger above the age of
twelve (12), provided that there shall be no more than four (4) passengers,
including passengers over the age of twelve (12), permitted in a taxicab which
is an automobile or more than seven (7) passengers, including passengers over
the age of twelve (12), in a taxicab which is a minivan;
   (B)   An additional twenty two cents ($0.22) for each one-tenth (1/10) mile
or fraction thereof that is traveled in the taxicab. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-11: TAXICAB DRIVER'S LICENSE:
Every person driving a taxicab must be licensed as such and carry said license
on his person while operating a taxicab in the village. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-
2010)
5-2-12: DRIVER QUALIFICATIONS:
Each driver who shall drive any taxicab in the village shall at all times meet
the following qualifications:
   (A)   Possess a valid state of Illinois driver's license of a classification
required by state law for the transport of persons for hire;
   (B)   Be twenty one (21) years of age or older;
   (C)   Be in good physical condition and shall not have any nervous, organic,
or functional condition or disease which is likely to interfere with the safe
performance of his or her duties as a driver;
   (D)   Be able to read, write and speak the English language, as determined
by a test administered by the village clerk or her designee;
   (E)   Have a secretary of state's court purposes driving abstract showing no
convictions for any of the following offenses:
      1.   Driving under the influence of a controlled substance, cannabis or
an intoxicating compound or similar provision of a local ordinance or any like
offense of another state or country within the past five (5) years; and
      2.   Reckless driving or a similar provision of a local ordinance or any
like offense of another state or country, within the past five (5) years; and
      3.   Any offense originally charged as listed in this subsection and
later reduced to any negotiated lesser offense within the past five (5) years;
and (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
   (F)   Shall not have been convicted of any felony or crime involving moral
turpitude. (Ord. 11-1349, 2-3-2011)
5-2-13: APPLICATION; TERM; RENEWAL; LATE PENALTY:
Any person desiring to secure a license as driver of any public vehicle
licensed hereunder and used for the carrying of passengers for hire or reward
shall make application in writing therefor to the village clerk. Such
application shall include the following information:
   (A)   Personal Information: The name of the applicant, his residence and
occupation.
   (B)   Investigation/Approval: Said application shall be referred by the
village clerk to the chief of police who shall then verify that the driver is
properly licensed by the state of Illinois. Upon the chief of police's approval
of the application, he shall so endorse the application and return same to the
village clerk who shall, upon payment of the fee prescribed herein, issue the
license.
   (C)   License Fee: The annual fee for taxicab driver's licenses shall be ten
dollars ($10.00).
   (D)   Term: Taxicab driver's licenses shall be issued as of November 1 in
each and every year and shall be valid to and including October 31 of the next
succeeding year.
   (E)   Renewal: Each licensee shall annually pay the license fee in full for
each taxicab driver's license before November 1 of each year.
   (F)   Penalty: If licensee does not renew his/her license and pay the annual
license fee before November 1, the licensee will incur a penalty of one hundred
percent (100%) of the annual license fee, in addition to the annual license
fee. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-14: RECORD OF LICENSES:
There shall be kept in the office of the village clerk a complete record of
each taxicab driver's license and of all renewals, suspensions or revocations
thereof. The village clerk's record shall be kept on file with the original
application. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-15: TAXICAB DRIVER'S LICENSE SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION:
A taxicab driver's license may be suspended or revoked at any time by the mayor
for cause. Any such suspension shall be noted on the license, together with a
statement of the reason therefor, and the village shall deprive the driver of
his license. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-16: CONDUCT AND APPEARANCE OF TAXICAB DRIVERS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any driver to conduct himself in a
disrespectful or contemptuous manner toward any person or to use abusive or
profane language while so occupied or in charge of such vehicle.
   (B)   Every driver of a taxicab shall maintain a reasonable degree of
personal hygiene and be dressed in clean clothing. Taxicab drivers are
prohibited from wearing the following articles of clothing as outer garments:
underwear, tank tops, swimwear, jogging suits, body shirts, shorts, cutoffs,
trunks or similar attire, or sandals without socks. Bermuda or post office type
shorts may be worn between May 1 and September 30. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-17: MANDATORY OPERATIONS; ABANDONMENT OF SERVICE:
The applicant shall regularly and daily operate his or its licensed taxicab
during each day of the licensed year to the extent reasonably necessary to meet
the public demand for such taxicab service. Upon complete abandonment of
taxicab service for the period of ten (10) consecutive days by the owner or
operator of such taxicab service, the chief of police, upon hearing, shall
after five (5) days' notice to said owner or operator, thereupon recommend to
the mayor that the license of such owner or operator shall be revoked covering
such taxicabs of the said owner or operator. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-18: REGISTER OF LICENSED VEHICLES:
The village clerk shall keep a register of the name and address of each taxicab
company owning or operating a taxicab licensed under this chapter, together
with a list of each licensed driver and each licensed vehicle, with the license
number and the description, make and necessary dimensions of such vehicle, and
with the date and complete record of inspections made of it. Such records shall
be open to the inspection of the public at all reasonable times and shall be
public records. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-19: CONDITION OF VEHICLE; LICENSE SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION:
   (A)   Licenses granted hereunder are subject to revocation at any time by
the mayor for good cause shown or if it shall have been determined that said
vehicle is not in good condition for operation. Licenses, when so revoked or
suspended shall not be reissued until the cause of such revocation shall have
been removed to the satisfaction of the mayor.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any taxicab not licensed by the village to
come into the village to pick up a passenger unless that passenger is to return
to that community in which the taxicab is licensed, and then only when such
transportation has been arranged for in advance either by writing or by
telephone. While said vehicle is in the village, no roof light shall be used to
indicate that the vehicle is vacant or subject to hire, but a white card
bearing the words, "Not For Hire", printed in black letters not less than two
inches (2") in height shall be displayed on the windshield of said vehicle. No
person shall be solicited or accepted in said vehicle for transportation from
any place within the village unless prearranged as indicated above. Any person
in control or possession of said vehicle who violates any of the provisions of
this chapter shall be subject to the penalties as herein provided in this
chapter. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
5-2-20: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provisions of this chapter shall be ticketed and
fined the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00). If after fourteen (14) days the
ticket is not paid, the fine shall increase to three hundred fifty dollars
($350.00). If the fine is not received within thirty (30) days after issuance,
the ticket will be set up for an adjudication hearing in accordance with the
administrative adjudication of traffic and other violations provisions
contained in this code. In addition to such fine that may be imposed, any
license issued pursuant to this chapter may be suspended or revoked as provided
herein. (Ord. 10-1337, 9-2-2010)
CHAPTER 3
GROSS RECEIPTS TAX
SECTION:
5-3-1: Tax Imposed
5-3-2: Report Required
5-3-3: Tax Payment
5-3-1: TAX IMPOSED 1 :
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling
tangible personal property at retail at the rate of one-half of one percent
(0.05%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such
business, in accordance with the provisions of section 23-111 of the revised
cities and villages act. (Ord. 96, 8-18-1955)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-54-1.
5-3-2: REPORT REQUIRED:
Every such person engaged in such business shall file on or before the
fifteenth day of each calendar month the report to the state department of
revenue required by section 3 of "an act in relation to a tax upon persons
engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property to purchasers for
use or consumption", approved June 28, 1933, as amended. (Ord. 96, 8-18-1955;
amd. Ord. 98)
5-3-3: TAX PAYMENT:
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department
of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the receipts from
sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month. (Ord. 96, 8-18-
1955)
CHAPTER 4
AMUSEMENT DEVICES AND TAX
SECTION:
5-4-1: Definitions
5-4-2: License Required
5-4-3: Application For License
5-4-4: License Fees
5-4-5: Amusement Tax
5-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this chapter, they shall have
such meanings herein ascribed to them:
AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any mechanically operated device, the operation of which is
governed or controlled by the deposit of coins or tokens, and which is played
solely for the amusement or pleasure of the operator.
JUKEBOX: Any mechanical machine or device, the operation of which is governed
or controlled by the deposit of coins or tokens, capable of producing or
reproducing any vocal or instrumental sound. (Ord. 121, 12-18-1958)
5-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall install, maintain, operate or make available for use in a
public place any amusement device or jukebox without first having obtained a
license for each of the same as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 121, 12-18-1958)
5-4-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person desiring to install, maintain, operate or make available for use in
a public place any amusement device or jukebox shall make application for a
license for that purpose to the clerk. Such application shall set forth the
name and address of the applicant, the number of amusement devices or jukeboxes
for which applicant desires licenses, and the addresses where said amusement
devices or jukeboxes will be located. If the applicant is found to be of good
character and reputation, the clerk shall cause a license to be issued such
applicant upon the payment of the license fees hereinafter set forth, which
license shall be valid for a period of one year. The annual license shall be
effective from July 1 to June 30 on an annual basis. (Ord. 121, 12-18-1958;
amd. Ord. 21-1652, 2-4-2021)
5-4-4: LICENSE FEES:
Said applicant shall pay an initial fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each
amusement device installed, maintained, operated or made available for use in a
public place. Each applicant shall thereafter pay an annual fee of fifty
dollars ($50.00) for each amusement device installed, maintained, operated or
made available for use in a public place. (Ord. 90-815, 2-1-1990; amd. Ord. 20-
1623, 2-6-2020)
5-4-5: AMUSEMENT TAX:
   (A)   Definition:
 
           Any theatrical, dramatic, musical, or spectacular performance;
           motion picture show; trade show, convention, any athletic contest,
AMUSEMENT: sport, game or similar exhibition for public entertainment
           including, without being limited to, boxing, wrestling, dancing,
           baseball, basketball, volleyball, hockey, track and field games,
           bowling, billiards and pool.
 
   (B)   Tax Imposed. A tax is imposed upon all amusements within the Village
of an amount equal to five percent (5%) of the gross receipts from admission
fees or other charges, exclusive of Federal or State taxes, to witness or to
participate in such amusements. No person shall produce, present or conduct any
amusements, for gain or profit, without payment of the tax.
   (C)   Tax Returns. On or before the tenth day of each month following the
quarter, each person liable for the tax herein imposed shall make a report in
writing and file it with the Village Treasurer stating the total amount
collected during the preceding quarter for admission fees or charges to each
amusement operated by him exclusive of any tax imposed on such admission fees
by the United States of America or the State.
   (D)   Inspection of Books and Records. The Village Treasurer, either
personally or through his authorized agents, shall have the right at all
reasonable times to inspect and check the books and records of any amusement or
person liable for such tax insofar as they pertain to admissions.
   (E)   Tax Due.
      1.   The tax herein imposed shall be due and payable on the tenth day of
each month for the preceding quarter of March, June, September, and December;
provided, however, that the tax herein imposed on amusements other than
theatrical performances and motion picture shows shall be due on the day
following the day of holding the event. Such tax shall be paid to and collected
by the Treasurer.
      2.   If, for any reason, any tax is not paid when due, a penalty at the
rate of one percent (1%) per thirty (30) day period, or portion thereof, from
the day of delinquency shall be added and collected.
   (F)   Penalty. Any person who violates any provision of this chapter, upon
conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense, and each day such violation shall continue shall be regarded as a
separate offense. (Ord. 21-1671, 7-1-2021)
CHAPTER 5
VENDING MACHINES
SECTION:
5-5-1: License Required
5-5-2: License Application
5-5-3: License Fees And Placement Of Machines
5-5-4: Inspections
5-5-5: Permit, License; Defined
5-5-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall install, keep, maintain or operate any automatic vending
machine for the sale of any merchandise, nor sell or offer for sale any such
merchandise by means of an automatic vending machine without first having
obtained a license for each of said automatic vending machines as hereinafter
provided.
It shall further be unlawful for any person to permit the installation,
keeping, maintenance or use upon his premises of any automatic vending machine
owned or operated by a person who has not first obtained a license for each of
said automatic vending machines as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 535, 1-5-1967)
5-5-2: LICENSE APPLICATION:
Any person desiring to sell any merchandise by means of automatic vending
machines shall make application for a license for that purpose to the village
clerk. Such application shall set forth the name and address of the applicant,
the retailers' occupation tax registration number assigned to applicant by the
Illinois department of revenue, the number of vending machines for which
applicant desires licenses, the locations where said vending machines will be
located, and the merchandise being offered for sale by means of said automatic
vending machines. If the applicant is found to possess such registration number
and to be of good character and reputation, the village clerk shall cause a
license or licenses to be issued such applicant upon the payment of the license
fees hereinafter set forth, which license shall be valid for a period of one
year. Such period for which each annual license is issued shall be from July 1
to June 30 of the following year. No such license shall be issued, however,
where an applicant does not have such registration number. (Ord., 6-17-1965;
amd. Ord. 21-1653, 2-4-2021)
5-5-3: LICENSE FEES AND PLACEMENT OF MACHINES:
   (A)   Any person desiring to sell any merchandise by means of an automatic
vending machine shall pay an annual license fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per
machine, other than amusement device machines, that is installed, maintained,
operated or made available for public use located in the village.
   (B)   Upon proper application being made to the village clerk, a license
shall be issued to said applicant for the operation of such vending machine
which shall be posted in a conspicuous place upon each machine so licensed.
   (C)   No person shall alter or deface any license sticker issued by the
village clerk.
   (D)   A license is issued to the applicant to operate a newspaper vending
machine said machine shall not be attached to any light pole or other property
owned by the village. (Ord. 91-842, 6-6-1991)
   (E)   Said applicant shall pay an initial fee of five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each amusement device installed, maintained, operated or made
available for use in a public place. Each applicant shall thereafter pay an
annual fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each amusement device
installed, maintained, operated or made available for use in a public place.
Applicants shall continue to pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per year for
each jukebox installed, maintained, operated or made available for use in a
public place. (Ord. 90-815, 2-1-1990)
Any person who violates this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense and every
such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for every day during
which the violation continues. (Ord. 91-842, 6-6-1991)
5-5-4: INSPECTIONS:
The public heath commissioner or the supervisor of public works are hereby
authorized and empowered to inspect and examine all merchandise being offered
for sale by means of automatic vending machines for the purpose of ascertaining
whether such merchandise so offered for sale is fresh, clean and wholesome. All
owners of said vending machines shall, on the request of either of said village
representatives, furnish keys for said machines so that the contents of same
may be inspected in company with the owner of the machine or his agent. (Ord.
122, 12-18-1958)
5-5-5: PERMIT, LICENSE; DEFINED:
Whenever the word "license" or "permit" is used in this chapter, they shall
mean the same. (Ord. 122, 12-18-1958)
CHAPTER 6
ROOMING HOUSES
SECTION:
5-6-1: Definition
5-6-2: Prohibition
5-6-3: Application For Permit
5-6-4: Intent
5-6-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this chapter, a "rooming house" shall mean and include every
dwelling house, furnished rooming house, and every other similarly occupied
building or structure, or portion thereof, kept, held or used where sleeping or
lodging is provided, or which is equipped to provide lodging by prearrangement,
for a definite period, for compensation, for three (3) or more persons, in
contradistinction to hotels or motels open and catering to transients. (Ord.
132, 10-1-1959)
5-6-2: PROHIBITION:
No house or building shall be used or occupied as or leased for a rooming
house; and it shall therefore be unlawful for any person to maintain, keep,
manage, conduct or operate a rooming house, or cause a rooming house to be
maintained, kept, managed, conducted or operated. (Ord. 132, 10-1-1959)
5-6-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
In all instances where less than three (3) roomers or lodgers are permitted,
the following conforming practices and requirements shall be met before any
house or building may be used for such purposes:
   (A)   Written application shall first be made to the president and board of
trustees on blanks furnished by the clerk for permission to allow catering to
not more than two (2) roomers or lodgers. The application shall state the full
name and address of the applicant seeking such permission, the name and address
of the owner of the building, the address of the building itself, the number of
roomers or lodgers to be accommodated, and the number of roomers or lodgers in
each room.
   (B)   Such written application for permission to house not more than two (2)
roomers or lodgers shall be made annually on or before January 15 of each year.
   (C)   The original application for such permission shall be accompanied by a
plan of each floor showing all entrances and exits, halls, size of all windows,
and the location and size of each room to be used and occupied by roomers or
lodgers. The applicant shall not be required to submit such plan upon
application for renewal of such permission, provided no physical changes or
alterations have been made to the structure accommodating such roomers or
lodgers since the filing of the original plan. If changes or alterations have
been made since the filing of the original application for such permission, new
plans shall be filed showing such changes or alterations.
   (D)   Upon receipt of such application, or renewal thereof, the village
shall cause an inspection to be made of the premises to determine whether such
premises are safe and habitable, whether the same are provided with adequate
heating, lighting and ventilating facilities, whether the premises contain
adequate and sufficient fire extinguishing facilities, and whether the premises
have good and proper sanitary facilities. Should such inspection disclose a
compliance with all the requirements of this chapter and all other applicable
provisions of this code, a permit shall be granted by the village to the
applicant to cater to roomers or lodgers.
   (E)   The permit holder shall maintain a proper registration of each roomer
or lodger, which registration shall include the name, permanent address and
period of stay of each such roomer or lodger. Such registration shall be made
available to the village upon request.
   (F)   No attic or basement, or any part thereof, shall be used as habitable
rooms.
   (G)   No cooking or preparation of food or meals, or the storage of
foodstuff or so called light housekeeping shall be permitted in any sleeping
room. (Ord. 132, 10-1-1959)
5-6-4: INTENT:
It is the intent of section
5-6-3 of this chapter that the provisions contained therein shall be the
minimum requirements with respect to houses catering to roomers or lodgers for
the promotion of public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general
welfare. (Ord. 132, 10-1-1959)
CHAPTER 7
BUSINESS REGULATION CERTIFICATE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
5-7-1: Title
5-7-2: Definitions
5-7-3: Certificate Required
5-7-4: Application
5-7-5: Term Of Certificate
5-7-6: Fee
5-7-7: Amount Of Fee
5-7-8: Computation
5-7-9: Records And Certificate
5-7-10: Investigations
5-7-11: Location
5-7-12: Administration And Enforcement
5-7-13: Suspension, Revocation Of Certificate
5-7-14: Appeal
5-7-15: Certificate To Be Posted
5-7-15-1: Duty Of Owner Of Real Estate
5-7-16: Penalty
5-7-17: Accessory Use Permits
5-7-18: Conflict
5-7-19: Invalidity
5-7-1: TITLE:
This chapter may be cited and referred to as the BUSINESS REGULATION
CERTIFICATE PROVISIONS. (Ord. 650, 8-5-1976)
5-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and terms whenever they occur in this chapter shall be
construed as herein defined:
ACCESSORY USE: The use subordinate to the principal use of a building including
any temporary public sale or other public gathering for commercial purpose
which is not a part of the regular daily function of the business
establishment.
BASEMENT: That portion of a building fully or partially below the ground
surface.
BULK STORAGE OF FLAMMABLES: The method of containing, holding or storing any
liquid having a flash point below two hundred degrees Fahrenheit (200°F) and
having a vapor pressure not exceeding forty (40) pounds per square inch
(absolute) at one hundred degrees Fahrenheit (100°F).
FLOOR AREA: The total horizontal area of all building floors measured in square
feet from the outside walls and shall include basement floors and all motor
vehicle or tractor parking space when such space is used in conjunction with
retail and wholesale establishments or when such space is used for the parking
of motor vehicles or trailers for their repair or storage; all outside area
used in conjunction with filling stations and all floor space used for
mechanical equipment whether open or closed including such equipment as may be
located on the roof, porches or verandas.
INDUSTRIAL ESTABLISHMENT: A place of business the principal use of which is
manufacturing, assembly or fabrication.
LOADING DOCKS OR DOORS: The openings or platforms for the loading or unloading
of materials.
MOTOR FREIGHT OR TRUCK TERMINAL: A building or premises in which freight
transported by motor truck is assembled, sorted or stored.
RETAIL OR WHOLESALE ESTABLISHMENT: A building or premises the principal use of
which is for the sale or distribution of any commodity by a seller to a
consumer.
SERVICE OR OFFICE ESTABLISHMENT: A building or premises the principal use of
which is for the rendering of personal or material services.
TANKS: Any receptacles for storing or holding liquids of more than one thousand
(1,000) gallon capacity.
TRUCK AND TRAILER REPAIR, LEASING OR STORAGE ESTABLISHMENTS: A building or
premises, including the parking or storage area in connection therewith, the
principal use of which is for the repair or rental or storage of motor trucks
or trailers.
WAREHOUSE ESTABLISHMENT: A building or premises and the outside area used in
conjunction therewith for the storage of goods, wares, merchandise or
commodities. (Ord. 650, 8-5-1976; amd. Ord. 713, 11-5-1981)
5-7-3: CERTIFICATE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, manage, operate or conduct
any trade, industry or business without first having obtained a business
regulation certificate therefor. (Ord. 650, 8-5-1976)
5-7-4: APPLICATION:
All applications for such certificates shall be made in writing to the Village
Clerk on forms to be furnished by the Village Clerk. In addition to all other
information contained in such application, the same shall state therein the
name of the applicant, the address of the property intended to be used for any
trade, industry or business, and the nature of the trade, product to be
manufactured or assembled, or business to be conducted on such premises, the
fee to be paid, and the floor area of the building and outside areas as
applicable in square feet and the number of docks or doors as applicable and
the number of tanks as applicable or such other and further information
requested from time to time by the Village Clerk. If the applicant is a
partnership, the names of the partners, together with their residence addresses
shall be included. If the applicant is a corporation, the names and residence
addresses of the president, secretary and registered agent shall be furnished.
In all instances, the name, residence address and home telephone number of the
sole owner, partner, officer or employee in charge of any trade, industry or
business so situated in the Village shall also be included in order to provide
for any emergency which may arise when no such owner, partner, officer or
employee is on the premises. (Ord. 650, 8-5-1976)
5-7-5: TERM OF CERTIFICATE:
Subject to the terms and provisions of this chapter, the Village Clerk shall
cause to be issued the certificate subject to investigations by various Village
departments, to permit the operation of the establishment in the Village for a
period of one year which shall begin on July 1 of the year for which such
document is issued and shall terminate on June 30 of the following year. No
certificate shall be issued at the yearly rate of fees except for the full
regulatory year. (Ord. 16-1508, 6-2-2016)
5-7-6: FEE:
The required fee for each certificate issued shall be collected upon
application. In no event shall any rebate or refund be made of any regulatory
fee, or part thereof, by reason of death or by any reason of nonuse of the
certificate or discontinuance of the operation of the establishment. In the
event a commercial establishment moves its place of operation from one location
in the Village to another location in the Village, a new regulatory certificate
shall be charged for the new location in accordance with the terms and
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 650, 8-5-1976)
5-7-7: AMOUNT OF FEE:
   (A)   For retail, wholesale, warehouse or industrial establishments,
including motor freight/truck terminals, truck and trailer repair, leasing or
storage establishments, and service/office establishments:
 
0 to 10,000 square feet floor area            $ 50.00
Over 10,000 to 50,000 square feet floor area  $100.00
Over 50,000 to 200,000 square feet floor area $200.00
Over 200,000 square feet floor area           $300.00
 
   (B)   For bulk storage of flammable establishments:
 
1 to 20 tanks  $ 50.00
21 to 30 tanks $100.00
31 to 50 tanks $200.00
Over 50 tanks  $300.00
 
   (C)   Miscellaneous, including cell towers and billboards:
 
Flat fee $ 50.00
 
(Ord. 650, 8-5-1976; amd. Ord. 21-1654, 2-4-2021)
5-7-8: COMPUTATION:
Total floor area applicable for the determination of the yearly regulatory fee
shall include all measurements as set forth in the definition of "floor area"
in section
5-7-2, "Definitions", of this chapter, even though any such floor area may be
temporarily vacant or not in use. All measured area shall be expressed in
square feet to the nearest integral square foot. (Ord. 650, 8-5-1976)
5-7-9: RECORDS AND CERTIFICATE:
Forms for all business regulation certificates and applications therefor shall
be prepared and kept on file by the village clerk together with all supporting
documents subject to the terms and conditions set forth in this chapter; and
upon full payment of the prescribed fees, the village clerk shall issue a
certificate bearing the signature or facsimile of the village president and
village clerk. The certificate shall be displayed by the owner of the business
establishment in a conspicuous place on the premises. (Ord. 650, 8-5-1976)
5-7-10: INVESTIGATIONS:
   (A)   Upon the receipt of an application for a business regulation
certificate, where an investigation or inspection is required by ordinance
before the issuance of such permit or license, or where an inspection or
investigation shall be deemed reasonably necessary or appropriate, the village
clerk, within forty eight (48) hours of such receipt, shall refer the
application to the appropriate officials for the making of such investigation
or inspection.
   (B)   The officials to whom the application has been referred shall make a
report thereon, favorable or otherwise, within ten (10) days after receiving
such application or a copy thereof.
   (C)   Upon receipt of all related investigative reports, the village clerk
shall forward such reports, together with the application, to the village
president and board of trustees for evaluation and determination.
   (D)   If it shall appear to the corporate authorities that the matters and
circumstances relating to an application require further information before a
proper determination can be made, such application shall be returned to the
village clerk for the inclusion of such additional information as may be
specified necessary and appropriate.
   (E)   If, after due consideration of the information contained within the
application and the related investigative reports, the corporate authorities
shall determine that the matters concerning the application are unsatisfactory,
they may disapprove such application, indicating the reasons therefor.
Thereupon, the village clerk shall be directed to promptly notify the applicant
that his application is disapproved, and that no business regulation
certificate will be issued.
   (F)   If, after due consideration of the information contained within the
application and the related investigative reports, the corporate authorities
shall determine that the application is satisfactory, they shall approve the
application. Thereupon, the village clerk shall be directed to promptly notify
the applicant that his application is approved, and the certificate may be
issued. (Ord. 650, 8-5-1976)
5-7-11: LOCATION:
No license for the operation of a business or establishment in the village
shall be construed to permit the operation of a licensed business or
establishment in more than one location in the village; a separate license
shall be required for each location of a licensed establishment. For the
purposes of this chapter, the existence of a single location shall be evidenced
by the fact that all buildings containing the principal or accessory uses shall
be connected or shall be located on the same lot or parcel, shall be operated
and managed by the same person or owner, and shall be an establishment with the
same classification. (Ord. 650, 8-5-1976)
5-7-12: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the village clerk to administer and enforce, or cause
to be enforced by an appropriate officer of the village, the terms and
provisions of this chapter and to cause to be made such inspections of the
buildings or premises as may be necessary to accomplish such administration or
enforcement. (Ord. 709, 4-2-1981)
5-7-13: SUSPENSION, REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE:
   (A)   When the conduct or operation of any business or establishment,
whether or not a certificate has been issued, shall constitute a nuisance in
fact and a clear and present danger to the public health, safety or general
welfare, the village president shall be authorized to summarily order the
cessation of business, the closing of the premises and the suspension of any
certificate for a period not to exceed ten (10) days.
   (B)   Within eight (8) days after he has so acted, the village president
shall call a hearing for the purpose of determining whether or not the
certificate should be revoked.
   (C)   Certificate issued under the ordinances of the village, unless
otherwise provided, may be revoked by the village president after notice and
hearing as provided in subsections (D) and (E) of this section for any of the
following causes:
      1.   Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the
application for the certificate;
      2.   Any violation of ordinance provisions relating to the certificate,
the subject matter of the certificate, or the premises occupied;
      3.   Conviction of the holder of the certificate of any felony or of a
misdemeanor involving moral turpitude;
      4.   Failure of the holder of the certificate to pay any fine or penalty
owing to the village;
      5.   Refusal to permit an inspection or sampling, or any interference
with a duly authorized village officer or employee while in the performance of
his duties in making such inspections.
Such revocation, if ordered, shall not preclude prosecution and imposition of
any of the penalties provided for the violation of other applicable ordinances
of the village. (Ord. 650, 8-5-1976)
      6.   The fire prevention bureau for the village of Bedford Park shall
periodically inspect all businesses and establishments during the term of the
certificate. Violations of the Bedford Park fire prevention code not corrected
shall be reason for revocation, suspension or lack of reissuance of the
certificate; (Ord. 668, 7-7-1978)
      7.   Denial, suspension, or revocation by any other municipality or by
the state or any regulatory body of the state of a comparable license or
permit;
      8.   Failure to comply with BOCA and the village building safety codes;
or
      9.   Excessive consumer complaints regarding the business or the owners
or managers of the business or a related business. (Ord. 10-1324A, 6-3-2010)
   (D)   Notice of the hearing for revocation of a certificate shall be given
in writing setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time
and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be sent by certified mail, return
receipt requested, to the holder of the certificate at his last known address
at least five (5) days prior to the date set for the hearing. (Ord. 650, 8-5-
1976)
   (E)   At the hearing, the village prosecutor shall present the complaint.
The village attorney shall represent and advise the village president and board
during the hearing. The certificate holder shall be permitted counsel and shall
have the right to submit evidence and cross examine witnesses. The village
president shall preside and shall render the decision. (Ord. 01-1089, 8-15-
2001)
5-7-14: APPEAL:
Any person aggrieved by the decision of the village president in regard to the
denial of an application for a certificate, as provided in section
5-7-10 of this chapter, or in connection with the revocation of a license or
permit, as provided in section
5-7-13 of this chapter, shall have the right to appeal to the board of
trustees. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the village clerk, within
ten (10) days after notice of a denial of an application or a revocation of a
certificate, a written statement under oath setting forth specifically the
grounds for appeal. The board of trustees shall thereupon set the time and
place for a hearing on such appeal, and notice of such hearing shall be given
to the applicant or holder of the certificate in the same manner as provided in
section
5-7-13 of this chapter. The decision of the board of trustees on such appeal
shall be final. (Ord. 650, 8-5-1976)
5-7-15: CERTIFICATE TO BE POSTED:
It shall be the duty of every person conducting a business in the village to
keep his certificate posted in a prominent place on the premises used for such
business at all times. (Ord. 650, 8-5-1976)
5-7-15-1: DUTY OF OWNER OF REAL ESTATE:
Notwithstanding any provision hereof, it shall be the duty and responsibility
of the owner of any real estate upon which a business regulations certificate
is required, to require that the tenant who occupies or uses said real estate
shall conform with all the provisions of this chapter as heretofore or
hereafter enacted. (Ord. 692, 1-3-1980)
5-7-16: PENALTY:
Any person who shall be convicted of violating any provision of this chapter
shall be fined not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each such
offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 695, 2-21-1980)
5-7-17: ACCESSORY USE PERMITS:
It shall be unlawful for any business establishment to engage in any accessory
use without first having obtained an accessory use permit therefor.
   (A)   Application for such permit shall be made in writing to the village
clerk on forms to be furnished by the village clerk. Prior to issuance of the
permit, the applicant must contact the police chief and fire chief who will
determine the necessary fire and police personnel required to protect the
public health and safety. The required police and fire personnel must be in
attendance at all times the establishment is open to the public during the term
of the accessory use.
   (B)   Village employees will be on duty for the municipality and
remuneration for the village personnel required shall be made by the applicant
directly to the village at an hourly rate equal to the employee's regular
calculated hourly pay rate.
   (C)   A deposit of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) will be paid to the
village upon application for issuance of a permit. Said deposit will be
refunded to the applicant should the village deny the issuance of the permit.
Upon approval of any permit, the fee shall be credited to the total
remuneration due and owing from the permit holder to the village, relative to
this section.
   (D)   On completion of the term of the accessory use permit, the village
will invoice the permit holder for the total amount due for the time expended
by the village personnel, and any additional workers' compensation premium,
unemployment compensation and withholding taxes incurred. (Ord. 713, 11-5-1981)
5-7-18: CONFLICT:
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with any of the terms or
provisions of this chapter are hereby repealed. All ordinances or parts of
ordinances in respect to the regulating of activities not described or defined
in this chapter shall remain in full force and effect. (Ord. 713, 11-5-1981)
5-7-19: INVALIDITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this
chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of
competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and
independent provision; and such holding shall not affect the validity of the
remaining portion thereof. (Ord. 713, 11-5-1981)
CHAPTER 8
WHEEL TAX LICENSE
SECTION:
5-8-1: License Required
5-8-2: License Application
5-8-3: License Fees
5-8-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person residing or operating a business within the
village to use, operate or park or cause or permit any of his agents or
employees to use or operate or park any motor passenger vehicle, motor bicycle
or motor truck and/or trailer upon the streets, avenues or alleys of the
village unless such vehicle is licensed as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 602, 8-
17-1972)
It shall be the duty of the licensee to attach the license/sticker in a
conspicuous place on the front of such vehicle where the same can be plainly
seen. In the case of automobiles or trucks, the licensee shall attach the
license/sticker to the lower right hand corner of windshield in such a manner
as to be easily read from the outside. In the case of motorcycles, the license/
sticker shall be placed on the rear license plate. Any person carrying a
license plate or sticker on his vehicle shall keep the same clear of dust and
mud so that the same can be plainly seen at all times. (Ord. 97-1000, 8-20-
1997)
5-8-2: LICENSE APPLICATION:
   (A)   Contents Of Application; License Issuance: Any person requiring such
license for any motor passenger vehicle, motor bicycle or motor truck and/or
trailer shall file an application with the clerk upon a form provided by him,
setting forth the name and address of the applicant, the description of the
vehicle for which such license is required and such other information as may,
from time to time, be prescribed. Said application shall also be accompanied by
the certificate of registration issued by the secretary of state covering said
vehicle as proof that the applicant is residing in the village, or a village
business license showing the operation of a business in the village, which
certificate of registration or village business license shall be returned to
the applicant upon the issuance of a vehicle license therefor. Upon the payment
of the license fee hereinafter provided, the clerk shall issue or cause to be
issued a license authorizing the use of such vehicle within the village until
the expiration of such license. Any vehicle which bears the name and/or an
address of a person within the corporate limits of the village, shall be
considered to be used, operated or parked upon the streets, avenues or alleys
of the village and shall be required to purchase such license. Any resident of
the village who is assigned a passenger car, a sport utility vehicle (SUV), a
van, or pick-up truck by their employer can be issued a village vehicle license
for such vehicle provided that the vehicle does not require an Illinois
registration plate greater than Class B (greater than 8,000 pounds). An
application for a village vehicle license for an employer-owned vehicle shall
include a copy of an Illinois driver's license proving village residency and
proof that the resident is an employee of such company. All signs, decals,
lettering, logos, and placards displaying the company's name shall be removed
from the vehicle when parking the vehicle overnight on village streets.
   (B)   Exemption: All vehicles registered under section 3-402.1 of the
Illinois vehicle code 1  shall be exempt from the licensing requirements. (Ord.
92-879, 11-5-1992; amd. Ord. 20-1625, 3-2-2020)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/3-402.1.

30, following the date of issue, except for the period from January 1, 1969, to
