be one-half (1/2) the annual rate fixed herein. In all other instances where a
license is issued for a period of less than one year, the fee to be paid for
the unexpired license period shall be the proportionate part of the annual rate
fixed herein, provided, however, that no fee shall be less than one-fourth (1/
4) the annual rate.
Unless a vehicle license for motor passenger vehicles or motor bicycles is
purchased prior to March 1, or unless a motor truck vehicle license is
purchased prior to September 1, a fifty percent (50%) penalty shall be added to
the normal fee of each class of vehicles hereinabove described; provided,
however, that this provision shall not apply to motor passenger vehicles or
motor bicycles purchased, transferred or relocated in the village after March 1
of the year, or motor trucks purchased, transferred or relocated in the village
after September 1 of the year. (Ord. 570, 8-21-1969)
CHAPTER 9
SALES AND RENTAL TAX
SECTION:
5-9-1: Service Occupation Tax
5-9-2: Rental Tax (Rep. by Ord. 04-1162, 7-15-2004)
5-9-3: Retailers' Occupation Tax
5-9-4: Storage Facilities Tax
5-9-5: Mineral Product Extraction Fee
5-9-1: SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this municipality in the
business of making sales of service at the rate of one percent (1%) of the cost
price of all tangible personal property transferred by said servicemen either
in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an
incident to a sale of service, in accordance with the provisions of section 8-
11-5 of the Illinois municipal code.
Every supplier or serviceman required to account for municipal service
occupation tax for the benefit of this municipality shall file, on or before
the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of
revenue required by section nine of the "service occupation tax act", approved
July 10, 1961, as amended.
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department
of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed. (Ord. 569, 9-18-1969, eff. 9-18-
1969)
5-9-2: RENTAL TAX 1 :
(Rep. by Ord. 04-1162, 7-15-2004)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 24 of this title.
5-9-3: RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
   (A)   Imposition of Tax: A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in
the business of selling tangible personal property, other than an item of
tangible personal property titled or registered with any agency of this state's
government, at retail in this municipality at the rate of one percent (1%) of
the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while
this section is in effect; and a tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged
in this municipality in the business of making sales of service, at the rate of
one percent (1%) of the selling price of all tangible personal property
transferred by such serviceman as an incident to a sale of service. Such “home
rule municipal retailers' occupation tax” and the “home rule municipal service
occupation tax” shall not be applicable to the sales of food for human
consumption which is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other
than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food that has been prepared for
immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs,
medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes and needles
used by diabetics.
The imposition of these home rule taxes is in accordance with the provisions of
sections 8-11-1 and 8-11-5, respectively, of the "Illinois municipal code" 1 .
   (B)   Collection Of Tax: The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties
that may be assessed as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by
the department of revenue of the state of Illinois in accordance with the
provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-1 and 5/8-11-5. The
department of revenue shall have full power to administer and enforce the
provisions of this section.
   (C)   Submission Of Ordinance To Illinois Department Of Revenue: The village
clerk is hereby directed to file a certified copy of the ordinance codified
herein with the Illinois department of revenue before April 1, 2002, whereupon
the department of revenue shall proceed to administer and enforce this section.
(Ord. 02-1111, 3-7-2002; amd. Ord. 19-1611, 8-1-2019)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/8-11-1, 5/8-11-5.
5-9-4: STORAGE FACILITIES TAX:
   (A)   A rental tax be and is hereby enacted in the amount of three percent
(3%) of the gross income that each and every facility derives from the leasing
of storage units in said facility operating within the geographical limits of
the village. The tax assessed is charged against the unit as a privilege for
the use and occupancy of said unit.
   (B)   Taxes collected by the village from this rental tax may be used by the
village for its general corporate purposes.
   (C)   The village shall handle the collection and administration of this tax
in the following manner:
      1.   On March 15, June 15, September 15 and December 15 of each and every
year, the storage facility shall remit to the Village Treasurer, P.O. Box 128,
6701 S. Archer Road, Bedford Park, Illinois 60501, a complete written summary
indicating the number of storage units leased, the length of each lease, and
the rate charged for each lease agreement during that quarter of the year. In
addition to the aforesaid written summary, the storage facility shall submit by
certified check the amount of rental tax that is due and owing the village via
the written summary.
      2.   Each and every check shall be made payable directly to the village.
      3.   The village, by and through its treasurer or auditor, or other
designated representative, may, upon written notice to the payor, examine the
written records being kept by the payor to ascertain that the appropriate
monies are being paid to the village.
   (D)   The village may, from time to time, modify, vary or alter the terms of
this section by written agreement with the storage facility. Absent a written
agreement varying the terms of this section or any portion thereof, this
section shall control in all respects. (Ord. 89-810, 9-21-1989)
5-9-5: MINERAL PRODUCT EXTRACTION FEE:
   (A)   Definitions: Whenever used in this section, the following words and
phrases shall have the meanings as described below:
EXTRACTOR: Any person engaged, operating or in the business of extracting,
mining or removing any mineral product within the village for use, consumption
or for retail purposes.
MINERAL PRODUCT: Any substance such as rock, sand, gravel, stone, limestone or
dolomite, which is the result of processing, fragmenting, crushing, grinding,
conveying, or treating any ore mined or extracted from the earth, but does not
include coal, oil, or gas.
MINERAL PRODUCT EXTRACTION LICENSE FEE: Any mineral product as described in
this section extracted, mined or removed by any means within the corporate
limits of the village of Bedford Park.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association,
corporation, limited liability company, joint venture, joint stock company,
receiver, trustee, conservator, legal representative, or other legally
recognized entity.
   (B)   Mineral Product Extraction License Fee: A mineral product extraction
license fee (fee) is hereby imposed at the rate of twelve cents ($0.12) per ton
for any mineral product extracted, removed or mined by an extractor within the
village corporate boundaries. Nothing in this section shall be construed to
impose an occupation tax.
   (C)   Responsibility Of Payment: The extractor of any and all mineral
products shall be responsible and liable for the payment of the mineral
extraction fee. Said fee shall be in addition to any other taxes which may be
due and owing in connection with the sale of the mineral product.
   (D)   Registration: Every extractor shall register with the village clerk
within ten (10) days of the passage of the ordinance codified herein. Every
person becoming an extractor thereafter shall register with the village clerk
within ten (10) days after the commencement of such business. Every extractor
shall file each month with the village clerk a remittance return containing a
report of mineral product extracted, removed or mined occurring in the prior
month. The return shall be filed on or before the last day of the month
following the month for which the report is due. Each such return shall be
accompanied by a remittance of the appropriate amount of fee applicable to the
volume of mineral product extracted, removed or mined.
   (E)   Collection Procedures: The extractor of any mineral product shall
submit the fees to the village clerk on a monthly basis. The remittance of the
fee shall be accompanied by a form prescribed by the village clerk.
   (F)   Failure To Remit Fee: It shall be a violation of this section for an
extractor to fail to submit the fee imposed herein. In the event the extractor
fails to submit the appropriate fee, the extractor shall be responsible for the
following:
      1.   Any fee not paid or remitted when due shall bear interest at the
rate of two percent (2%) per month, or fraction thereof, until the fee is paid
or remitted;
      2.   In addition to any interest charged, any person who fails to pay or
to remit the fee when due shall be subject to a late penalty of ten percent
(10%) of such fee;
      3.   In addition to any interest or penalty charged above, any person who
fails to file a remittance return when due shall be subject to a late filing
penalty of ten percent (10%) of the total fee liability due for the reporting
period.
Where the failure to pay or to remit the fee or to file the remittance return,
in a timely manner is due to reasonable cause beyond the control of the person
charged with filing and paying the fee, the penalties described in subsections
(F)2 and (F)3 of this section may be waived by the village clerk.
   (G)   Maintenance Of Records: The extractor required to collect and remit
the fee imposed herein shall keep accurate and complete books and records,
including the maintenance of all invoices and other source documents. All books
and records shall be subject to inspection by the village clerk or duly
authorized agents, at all times during regular business hours.
   (H)   Authorization: The village clerk is hereby authorized to prepare the
necessary remittance forms and publish rules and regulations in furtherance of
the purpose of this section.
   (I)   Penalty Clause:
      1.   Any person found guilty of violating, disobeying, neglecting or
refusing to comply with or resisting or opposing the enforcement of any
provision of this section, upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not
less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) per each offense. A separate offense shall be regarded as committed
each day upon which said person shall continue any such violation or permit
such violation to exist after notification thereof.
      2.   Whenever any person shall fail to pay fee due hereunder, the village
attorney shall, upon the request of the president of the village, bring or
cause to be brought an action to enforce the payment of said fee on behalf of
the village in any court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 03-1145, 8-7-2003)
CHAPTER 10
TAG DAYS
SECTION:
5-10-1: Definition
5-10-2: Permit Required
5-10-1: DEFINITION:
The term "tag days" is hereby defined to mean those days on which it shall be
lawful for charitable organizations to solicit funds for charitable purposes.
(Ord. 152, 10-4-1962)
5-10-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct tag days without first having
obtained approval from the president and board of trustees and a permit from
the clerk pursuant to such approval. Said tag days may only be conducted during
such periods of time and under such conditions as the president and board of
trustees may, from time to time, prescribe. (Ord. 152, 10-4-1962)
CHAPTER 11
CANVASSERS AND SOLICITORS
SECTION:
5-11-1: Definition
5-11-2: Registration Required
5-11-3: Fee
5-11-4: Certificate
5-11-5: Exceptions
5-11-6: Revocation
5-11-1: DEFINITION:
The words "canvassers" and "solicitors" are hereby defined to mean any
individual who calls at the residences, commercial establishments or industrial
plants, without the previous consent of the occupants thereof, for the purpose
of soliciting orders, sales, subscriptions, business or donations of any kind.
(Ord. 153, 10-4-1962)
5-11-2: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a canvasser or
solicitor, calling at the residences, commercial establishments or industrial
plants, without the previous consent of the occupants thereof, for the purpose
of soliciting orders, sales, subscriptions, business or donations of any kind,
without first having registered in the office of the clerk. The registrant
shall furnish to the clerk his complete identification, his signature, the name
of his employer, the name of the products or service in which he is interested,
the names of the manufacturers of such products, the organization which he is
representing, and the proposed method of operation. (Ord. 153, 10-4-1962)
5-11-3: FEE:
No charge shall be made by the village for such registration. (Ord. 153, 10-4-
1962)
5-11-4: CERTIFICATE:
Each applicant who shows evidence of good character and otherwise complies with
the provisions of this chapter, shall be furnished a certificate by the clerk
indicating that he or she has registered and showing the dates covered by such
registration. Each such registrant shall at all times while soliciting or
canvassing carry the registration certificate upon his person, and the same
shall be exhibited by such registrant whenever he is required so to do by any
police officer or by any person solicited. (Ord. 153, 10-4-1962)
5-11-5: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to officers or employees of the
village, county, state or federal government, or any subdivision thereof, when
on official business. (Ord. 153, 10-4-1962)
5-11-6: REVOCATION:
Any such registration may be revoked by the president of the board of trustees
or the police marshal because of any violation by the registrant of this
chapter or of any other provision of this code, or of any state or federal law,
or whenever the registrant shall cease to possess the qualifications and
character required in this chapter for the original registration. (Ord. 153,
10-4-1962)
CHAPTER 12
PEDDLERS
SECTION:
5-12-1: Definition
5-12-2: Registration Required
5-12-3: Fee
5-12-4: Certificate
5-12-5: Revocation
5-12-1: DEFINITION:
The word "peddler' is hereby defined to mean any individual who, going from
place to place, shall offer for sale, sell and deliver, barter or exchange any
goods, wares, merchandise produce, article or thing from a vehicle or
otherwise. (Ord. 154, 10-4-1962)
5-12-2: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddler of any
goods, wares, merchandise, produce, article or thing or to ply his vocation on
any street, sidewalk, park, parkway or any other public place without first
having registered in the office of the clerk. The registrant shall give his
complete identification, his signature, the name of his employer, if any, the
nature of the products in which he is interested and the names of the
manufacturers of such products, if any. (Ord. 154, 10-4-1962)
5-12-3: FEE:
No charge shall be made by the village for such registration. (Ord. 154, 10-4-
1962)
5-12-4: CERTIFICATE:
Each applicant who shows evidence of good character and otherwise complies with
the provisions of this chapter, shall be furnished a certificate by the clerk
indicating that he or she has registered and showing the dates covered by such
registration. Each such registrant shall at all times while so peddling, carry
the registration certificate upon his person, and the same shall be exhibited
by such registrant whenever he is required so to do by any police officer or by
any person solicited. (Ord. 154, 10-4-1962)
5-12-5: REVOCATION:
Any such registration may be revoked by the president of the board of trustees
or the police marshal because of any violation by the registrant of this
chapter or of any other provision of this code, or of any state or federal law,
or whenever the registrant shall cease to possess the qualifications and
character required in this chapter for the original registration. (Ord. 154,
10-4-1962)
CHAPTER 13
TRAILER CAMPS
SECTION:
5-13-1: Definitions
5-13-2: Prohibition
5-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter:
HOUSE CAR TRAILER: Any structure for, or used for, living or sleeping purposes,

TRAILER CAMP: Any plot of ground where the owner or person in control thereof,

5-13-2: PROHIBITION:

CHAPTER 14
PARKING LOTS
SECTION:
5-14-1: Definitions
5-14-2: Grading; Surfacing Required
5-14-1: DEFINITIONS:
Wherever in this chapter the following words or terms are used, they shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section:
BLACKTOPPING: A mixture of aggregates, mineral filler and asphalt cement,
commonly known as asphalt or bituminous concrete.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Any vehicle which is propelled otherwise than by muscular power,
including, but not limited to, automobiles, motorcycles, motor driven trailers,
special mobile equipment, specially constructed vehicles, trucks and truck
tractors.
PARKING LOT: Any open area or vacant property where motor vehicles are housed,
stored or parked in condition ready for use, and maintained, kept or used for
the accommodation of the owners, tenants, occupants, patrons or employees of
industrial plants, public utilities or business establishments, but excluding
any area or vacant property where any raw materials or products manufactured or
serviced on the premises of such owner, tenant or occupant are housed, stored
or parked, or where any product which is taken in on trade by such owner,
tenant or occupant is housed, stored or parked. (Ord., 6-17-1965; amd. Ord.
518, 12-16-1965)
5-14-2: GRADING; SURFACING REQUIRED:
In order to minimize atmospheric pollution and to reduce the amount of dirt,
mud, debris or other substances, whether liquid or solid, from being deposited
upon the streets and public ways in the village, it shall be unlawful for any
person, firm or corporation to maintain, keep or conduct, or cause to be
maintained, kept or conducted, any parking lot within the village unless the
entire surface thereof is graded and is covered with either blacktopping or
concrete. Such blacktopping or concrete shall be in accordance with the
specifications thereof prescribed by the commissioner of public works of the
village. (Ord., 6-17-1965)
CHAPTER 15
POLICE PROTECTION TAX
SECTION:
5-15-1: Police Protection Tax
5-15-1: POLICE PROTECTION TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed for the purpose of police protection in this village at
the rate of five-hundredths percent (0.05%) of the value, as equalized or
assessed by the department of revenue of all taxable property therein for the
first year in which this tax is levied, and at a rate of seventy five
thousandths percent (0.075%) of the value as equalized or assessed by the
department of revenue for all taxable property therein, in all succeeding
years, all in accordance with the provisions of section
11-1-3 of the Illinois municipal code. (Ord. 577, 2-19-1970)

FIRE PROTECTION TAX

5-16-1: FIRE PROTECTION TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed for the purpose of fire protection in this village at
the rate of five-hundredths percent (0.05%) of the value, as equalized or

CHAPTER 17
GASOLINE SERVICE STATIONS
SECTION:
5-17-1: License Required
5-17-2: Definition
5-17-3: Nonbusiness Filling Stations
5-17-4: Bulk Sales Prohibited
5-17-5: Regulation Of Self-Service Stations
5-17-6: Additional Regulations
5-17-7: Penalty
5-17-8: Invalidity
5-17-9: Conflict
5-17-10: Supersedes State Law
5-17-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a service station in the village
without first having obtained a business regulation certificate therefor. The
annual fee for such certificate shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) per pump.
No such certificate shall be issued unless the location and equipment to be
used fully complies with the ordinances of the village. (Ord. 662, 1-19-1978)
5-17-2: DEFINITION:
A "service station" is a place of business where gasoline, or any highly
volatile fuels for motor vehicles or internal combustion engines, are sold or
offered for sale at retail and dispensed into the fuel tanks of such motor
vehicles.
   (A)   This definition shall include also a private storage tank and
dispensing of such products for the same purposes as those served by a service
station, whether the storage is maintained for the use or benefit of the owner,
lessee, agents or employees of either, or of any others.
   (B)   The requirements covering service stations shall also govern
underground storage maintained at general storage plants and places other than
service stations, so far as applicable. (Ord. 662, 1-19-1978)
5-17-3: NONBUSINESS FILLING STATIONS:
Any person, firm or corporation maintaining or operating any storage tank for
gasoline for the use of automobiles for the owner, lessees, employees or agents
of such person, firm or corporation shall comply with all the provisions of
this chapter other than the requirement for the payment of a fee. (Ord. 662, 1-
19-1978)
5-17-4: BULK SALES PROHIBITED:
No motor fuel shall be dispensed at any service station except into the fuel
tank of motor vehicles, when such tanks are connected with the carburetion
system of such vehicles; provided, however that individual sales up to six (6)
gallons may be made in receptacles approved by the state of Illinois, division
of fire prevention when painted red and labeled, such individual sales to be
limited to six (6) gallons to any one person. (Ord. 662, 1-19-1978)
5-17-5: REGULATION OF SELF-SERVICE STATIONS:
   (A)   "Self-service station" shall mean that portion of property where
flammable and combustible liquids used as motor fuels are stored and
subsequently dispensed from fixed approved dispensing equipment into the fuel
tanks of motor vehicles by persons other than the service station attendant.
No gasoline service station shall be completely self- service. At least one
island shall be devoted to full service.
   (B)   Approved "self-service" dispensing devices are permitted at service
stations available and open to the public, provided that all dispensing of
motor fuels, except LPG, by a person other than the service station attendant
is under the supervision and control of a qualified attendant and the
dispensing nozzle is a listed automatic closing type without a latch open
device.
   (C)   "Person" means any individual, corporation, company, firm,
partnership, association or group, trust or beneficiary thereof.
   (D)   The following rules shall be followed and observed at all self-service
stations:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to provide for or use live-in facilities or
accommodations for the benefit of any owner, operator or employee of a self-
service station on the premises of such station.
      2.   All self-service stations shall have at least one attendant of the
age of eighteen (18) years or older on duty while the station is open to the
public. The attendant's primary function shall be to supervise, observe and
control the dispensing of flammable liquids while said liquids are actually
being dispensed. This shall not be interpreted as prohibiting split island type
of operation.
      3.   The dispensing area shall at all times be in clear view of the
attendant and the placing or allowing of any obstacle to come between the
dispensing area and the attendant control area shall be prohibited. The
attendant shall at all times be able to communicate with persons in the
dispensing area.
      4.   The attendant shall have immediate access to emergency cutoff
switches provided at a location remote from the dispensing devices, which
location shall be subject to approval by the department of public safety.
      5.   The attendant shall supervise the dispensing of motor fuels. The
attendant shall refuse service to any person who is smoking or who appears, for
any reason, to be unable to dispense the motor fuel safely and shall shut off
the dispensing unit if a patron fails to follow instructions in compliance with
this section.
      6.   All attendants and other employees shall be thoroughly instructed in
the operation and use of the communication system, the control station, the
fire extinguishing equipment, the operation of the dispensing units and safety
regulations for the dispensing of motor fuels.
      7.   No individual under the age of sixteen (16) years shall be permitted
to operate self-service pumps and a sign shall be prominently displayed
indicating this prohibition.
      8.   For minimum safety standards for the location and operation of self-
service dispensing units, dispensing pumps shall be located a minimum of twelve
feet (12') inside station property lines and a maximum of ten feet (10') from
any building opening.
      9.   Gasoline dispensing nozzles shall not be of the "latch open" type.
      10.   At least one type ABC fire extinguisher, with a capacity of ten
(10) pounds, shall be at the attendant's control station.
      11.   Conspicuous and legible signs, prohibiting smoking and directing
customers to turn off ignitions while dispensing motor fuel shall be posted and
maintained. The lettering on such signs shall be red on white background and
not less than four inches (4") in height. The signs shall be made of an all
weather rigid material. The wording, lettering, size, design, material,
mounting and location of such signs shall be subject to the approval of the
various designated committees of the village board of trustees.
      12.   Dispensing units shall be mounted either on a concrete island or
protected against collision damage by suitable means in a manner approved by
the village board of trustees.
      13.   No portable containers of more than six (6) gallons shall be filled
with gasoline, except as dispensed directly into the fuel tanks attached to a
motor vehicle. All portable receptacles for gasoline shall be red and shall be
labeled in letters of a contrasting color and a height of not less than one-
half inch (1/2"), and it shall be unlawful to put any other liquids or oils
except gasoline in such receptacles theretofore used for gasoline so long as
such receptacles are so painted red and labeled "gasoline". In all
circumstances, the container shall be of material approved by the state of
Illinois, division of fire protection. (Ord. 662, 1-19-1978)
5-17-6: ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall be in addition to any rules and
regulations relating to the operation, storage, transportation, sale and uses
of gasoline and volatile oils promulgated by the state of Illinois, department
of law enforcement, which are now or may be hereafter placed in effect. (Ord.
662, 1-19-1978)
5-17-7: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this chapter shall be
fined in a sum not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) for any one
offense. (Ord. 662, 1-19-1978)
5-17-8: INVALIDITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this chapter
is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent
provision; and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining
portion thereof. (Ord. 662, 1-19-1978)
5-17-9: CONFLICT:
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with any of the terms or
provisions of this chapter are hereby repealed. All ordinances or parts of
ordinances in respect to the regulating of activities not described or defined
in this chapter shall remain in full force and effect. (Ord. 662, 1-19-1978)
5-17-10: SUPERSEDES STATE LAW:
This chapter and each of its terms shall be the effective legislative act of a
home rule municipality without regard to whether such chapter should: a)
contain terms contrary to the provisions of current or subsequent nonpreemptive
state law; b) legislate in a manner or regarding a matter not delegated to
municipalities by state law. It is the intent of the corporate authorities that
to the extent that the terms of this chapter should be inconsistent with a
nonpreemptive state law, that this chapter shall supersede state law in that
regard within its jurisdiction. (Ord. 662, 1-19-1978)
CHAPTER 18
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR REGULATIONS
SECTION:
5-18-1: Definitions
5-18-2: License Required
5-18-3: Application For License
5-18-4: Restriction On Licenses
5-18-5: Term Of License; Prorating Fees
5-18-6: Classification; Fees
5-18-7: Disposition Of Fees
5-18-8: License Record To Be Kept
5-18-9: Transfer Of License
5-18-10: Change Of Location
5-18-11: Sanitary Conditions
5-18-12: Closing Hours
5-18-13: Revocation Of License
5-18-14: Sales To Persons Under Twenty One, Habitual Drunkards, Spendthrifts
And Mental Incompetents
5-18-15: Purchase Or Acceptance Of Gift Of Liquor By Persons Of Nonage;
Identification Cards; Rules And Regulations; Penalty
5-18-16: Local Liquor Control Commissioner
5-18-17: Consumption And Transportation Of Alcoholic Liquor
5-18-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise indicated, the following terms, as used in this chapter, shall
have the following meanings:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Any spirits, wine, beer, ale or other liquid containing more
than one-half (1/2) of one percent (1%) of alcohol by volume which is fit for
beverage purposes.
ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS: Any facility, including restaurants, whose
primary function is to provide food, meals, alcoholic liquor or entertainment
to the public.
PATRON: A customer of an entertainment establishment.
RETAIL SALE: The sale for use or consumption, and not for resale. (Ord. 687, 9-
6-1979; amd. Ord. 05-1172, 1-6-2005)
5-18-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail in the village any
alcoholic liquor without having a retail liquor dealer's license or in
violation of the terms of such license. (Ord. 687, 9-6-1979)
5-18-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applications for licenses shall be made to the president in writing, signed by
the applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof, if a
club or corporation, verified by oath, or affidavit, and shall contain the
following information and statements:
   (A)   The name, age, and address of the applicant in the case of an
individual; in the case of a copartnership, the persons entitled to share in
the profits thereof, and in the case of a corporation, for profit, or a club,
the date of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the names
and addresses of the officers and directors, and if a majority in interest of
the stock of such corporation is owned by one person or his nominees, the name
and address of the person.
   (B)   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and if a
naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.
   (C)   The character of business of the applicant; and in the case of a
corporation, the objects for which it was formed.
   (D)   The length of time that the applicant has been in business of that
character, or in the case of a corporation, the date on which its charter was
issued.
   (E)   The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time
application is made.
   (F)   The location and description of the premises or place of business
which is to be operated under the license.
   (G)   A statement whether applicant has made similar application for similar
license on premises other than described in this application, and the
disposition of the application.
   (H)   A statement that the applicant has never been convicted of a felony
and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing
contained in this chapter, laws of this state, or applicable provisions of this
code.
   (I)   Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof, or by
the federal government has been revoked, and the reasons therefor.
   (J)   A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the
state or of the United States, or any provisions of this code in the conduct of
his place of business. (Ord. 687, 9-6-1979)
5-18-4: RESTRICTION ON LICENSES:
No license shall be issued to:
   (A)   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community
in which he resides.
   (B)   A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
   (C)   A person who has been convicted of a felony of any federal or state
law, if the commissioner determines after investigation that such person has
not been sufficiently rehabilitated to warrant the public trust.
   (D)   A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or is keeping a
house of ill fame.
   (E)   A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality.
   (F)   A person whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked for
cause.
   (G)   A person who, at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued hereunder, would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application.
   (H)   A copartnership, unless all of the members of the copartnership shall
be qualified to obtain a license.
   (I)   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any
stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%)
of the stock of the corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license
hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the
political subdivision.
      1.   A corporation unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or unless it is
a foreign corporation which is qualified under the Illinois business
corporation act to transact business in Illinois.
   (J)   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless the manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the
licensee.
   (K)   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state
law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor,
subsequent to the passage of this chapter, or shall have forfeited his bond to
appear in court to answer charges for any such violation.
   (L)   A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a
license is sought or does not have a license thereon for the full period for
which the license is to be issued.
   (M)   Any law enforcing public official, any mayor, alderman, or member of a
city council or commission and president of a village board of trustees, or any
president or member of a county board; and no such official shall be interested
in any way, either directly or indirectly, in the manufacture, sale or
distribution of alcoholic liquor.
   (N)   Any person not eligible for a state retail liquor dealer's license.
   (O)   A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated
by the licensee.
   (P)   A person who has been convicted of a gambling offense.
   (Q)   A person to whom a federal gaming device stamp or a federal wagering
stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period.
   (R)   A copartnership to which a federal gaming device stamp or a federal
wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax
period, or if any of the partners have been issued a Federal gaming device
stamp or Federal wagering stamp by the Federal government for the current tax
period.
   (S)   A corporation, if any officer, manager, or director thereof, or any
stockholder owning in the aggregate more than twenty percent (20%) of the stock
of such corporation has been issued a Federal gaming device stamp or a Federal
wagering stamp for the current tax period.
   (T)   Any premises for which a Federal gaming device stamp or a Federal
wagering stamp has been issued by the Federal government for the current tax
period. (Ord. 687, 9-6-1979)
5-18-5: TERM OF LICENSE; PRORATING FEES:
Each license shall terminate on April 30 next following its issuance. The fee
to be paid shall be reduced in proportion to the full calendar months which
have expired in the year prior to the issuance of the license. (Ord. 687, 9-6-
1979)
5-18-6: CLASSIFICATION; FEES:
The following are the categories of liquor licenses that can be issued within
the Village:
   (A)   Class A Licenses:
      1.   Description: Authorizes the sale on the premises of alcoholic liquor
only for on site consumption within the walls of an establishment in which food
is being prepared, served and consumed.
      2.   Annual Fee: Six hundred dollars ($600.00). (Ord. 15-1475, 4-16-2015)
      3.   Number Allowed: Maximum number authorized at any one time: Fourteen
(14). (Ord. 18-1555, 1-11-2018; amd. Ord. 20-1640, 10-1-2020)
   (B)   Class B Licenses:
      1.   Description: Authorizes the sale, by catering businesses only, of
alcoholic beverages or packaged quantities of alcohol for use in conjunction
with catered food and beverage events, either within the Village or outside the
Village.
      2.   Annual Fee: Three hundred dollars ($300.00).
      3.   Number Allowed: Maximum number authorized at any one time: Three
(3).
   (C)   Class C Licenses:
      1.   Description: Authorizes the retail sale by retail businesses of
alcoholic beverages to the general public; however, no consumption of alcoholic
beverages will be permitted at said businesses.
      2.   Annual Fee: Six hundred dollars ($600.00).
      3.   Number Allowed: Maximum number authorized at any one time: Seven
(7).
   (D)   Class D Licenses:
      1.   Description: Authorizes the sale of alcoholic beverages for on site
consumption to the guests and patrons of a hotel who are utilizing the meeting
rooms or guestrooms within the Midway/Bedford Park Hotel Conference Center.
      2.   Annual Fee: Six hundred dollars ($600.00).
      3.   Number Allowed: Maximum number of such licenses which may be issued:
Three (3).
   (E)   Class E Licenses:
      1.   Description: Authorizes the sale on the premises of alcoholic liquor
only for on site consumption within the walls of an adult use facility in which
food is being prepared, served and consumed.
      2.   Annual Fee: Six hundred dollars ($600.00).
      3.   Number Allowed: Maximum number authorized at any one time: One.
   (F)   Class F Licenses:
      1.   Description: Authorizes the manufacturing and distribution of a
craft beer as defined by the Illinois Liquor Control Commission. The
consumption and retail sale of the craft beer shall be permitted on the
premises.
      2.   Annual Fee: Six hundred dollars ($600.00).
      3.   Number Allowed: Maximum number allowed at any one time: Two. (Ord.
15-1475, 4-16-2015; amd. Ord. 19-1614, 11-7-2019)
5-18-7: DISPOSITION OF FEES:
All fees shall be paid to the President at the time application is made, and
shall be forthwith turned over to the Treasurer. In the event the license
applied for is denied, the fee shall be returned to the applicant; if the
license is granted, then the fee shall be deposited in the General Corporate
Fund or in such other fund as shall have been designated by the Board of
Trustees, by proper action. (Ord. 687, 9-6-1979)
5-18-8: LICENSE RECORD TO BE KEPT:
The President shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all such
licenses issued by him; and shall furnish the Clerk, and Chief of Police each
with a copy thereof upon the issuance of any new license, or the revocation of
any old license, the President shall give written notice of such action to each
of these officers within forty eight (48) hours of such action. (Ord. 687, 9-6-
1979)
5-18-9: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed one year
after issuance unless sooner revoked as in this chapter provided, and shall not
constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or
execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily, or
involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such license
shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution, but it shall
cease upon the death of the licensee; provided, that executors or
administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the trustee of any
insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic
liquor, may continue the business of the sale or manufacture of alcoholic
liquor under order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of
the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of the decedent,
or such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of the license but not
longer than six (6) months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of the
licensee. A refund shall be made of that portion of the license fees paid for
any period in which the licensee shall be prevented from operating under the
license in accordance with the provisions of this section.
Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof; provided, he is
then qualified to receive a license and the premises for which the renewal
license is sought is suitable for such purpose. (Ord. 687, 9-6-1979)
5-18-10: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
A retail liquor dealer's license shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only
in the premises described in the application and license. The location may be
changed only upon the written permit to make such change issued by the
President. No change of location shall be permitted unless the proposed new
location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor under the laws
of this State and the provisions of this Code. (Ord. 687, 9-6-1979)
5-18-11: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, or for the storage
of liquor for such sale shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and
shall be kept in full compliance with the provisions of this Code regulating
the condition of premises used for the storage or sale of goods for human
consumption. (Ord. 687, 9-6-1979)
5-18-12: CLOSING HOURS:
   (A)   1. It shall be unlawful for any holder of a Class A liquor license to
sell or offer for sale, or to serve or permit the consumption of any alcoholic
liquor in the Village in all areas during the following hours:
         (a)   Between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and seven o'clock
(7:00) A.M. on Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays; and
         (b)   Between the hours of three o'clock (3:00) A.M. and seven o'clock
(7:00) A.M. on Fridays and Saturdays; and
         (c)   Between the hours of three o'clock (3:00) A.M. and seven o'clock
(7:00) A.M. on Sundays.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any holder of a Class B, C, D liquor
license to sell or offer for sale, or to serve or permit the consumption of any
alcoholic liquor in the Village in all areas during the following hours:
         (a)   Between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and seven o'clock
(7:00) A.M. on Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays; and
         (b)   Between the hours of three o'clock (3:00) A.M. and seven o'clock
(7:00) A.M. on Fridays and Saturdays; and
         (c)   Between the hours of three o'clock (3:00) A.M. and twelve
o'clock (12:00) noon on Sundays.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any holder of a Class E liquor license to
sell or offer for sale or to serve or permit the consumption of any alcoholic
liquor in the Village in all areas during the following hours:
      1.   Between the hours of two thirty o'clock (2:30) A.M. and eleven
o'clock (11:00) A.M. on Sundays to Thursdays; and
      2.   Between the hours of three thirty o'clock (3:30) A.M. and eleven
o'clock (11:00) A.M. on Fridays and Saturdays.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any holder of a class F liquor license to
sell or offer for sale or to serve or permit the consumption of any alcoholic
liquor in the village in all areas during the following hours:
      1.   Between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. to twelve o'clock
(12:00) noon on Mondays through Saturdays. No sales of any kind are permitted
on Sundays.
   (D)   That upon the adoption of this chapter, it shall be prohibited to
issue any liquor license of any class that permits the sale, serving or
consumption of alcoholic liquor beyond two o'clock (2:00) A.M. Any and all
sales, serving or consumption of alcohol must cease by two o'clock (2:00) A.M.
daily. This provision will not be effective for any liquor licenses issued
prior to the adoption of this chapter. (Ord. 15-1478, 5-7-2015; amd. Ord. 17-
1535, 2-2-2017; Ord. 18-1567, 5-17-2018; 22-1697, 4-7-2022)
5-18-13: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   (A)   The president shall hold hearings as provided by the state statutes
and further, may hold hearings after any disturbances which take place:
      1.   In a licensed establishment,
      2.   Outside a licensed establishment,
      3.   As a result of anyone drinking in a licensed establishment.
A "disturbance" is any event wherein the police are called or wherein the
police make an investigation or someone is injured or property is damaged.
   (B)   At said hearing the owner must appear as well as all employees of the
licensed establishment which were working the day of the disturbance. (Ord.
687, 9-6-1979; amd. Ord. 00-1069, 10-19-2000, eff. 1-1-2001)
   (C)   Within five (5) business days following a hearing, the village
president shall enter an order setting forth his findings. The village
president shall have the right to impose the following penalties for the
violation of any state, federal or village law or ordinance relative to the
sale of alcoholic liquor, or for any material facts set forth in the liquor
license application or for any violation of this chapter:
      1.   Suspension of liquor license;
      2.   Revocation of liquor license;
      3.   Issuance of a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for a first
violation, one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for a second violation
and two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for a third violation all
within a twelve (12) month period of time. The maximum annual amount of fines
that may be imposed is fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00). (Ord. 00-1069,
10-19-2000, eff. 1-1-2001)
5-18-14: SALES TO PERSONS UNDER TWENTY ONE, HABITUAL DRUNKARDS, SPENDTHRIFTS
AND MENTAL INCOMPETENTS:
   (A)   No licensee nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent
or employee of such licensee shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to
any person under the age of twenty one (21), or to any intoxicated person or to
any person known by him to be an habitual drunkard, spendthrift, insane,
mentally ill, mentally deficient or in need of mental treatment. No person,
after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor, shall sell, give or
deliver such alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of twenty one
(21) years except in the performance of a religious ceremony or service. (Ord.
687, 9-6-1979)
5-18-15: PURCHASE OR ACCEPTANCE OF GIFT OF LIQUOR BY PERSONS OF NONAGE;
IDENTIFICATION CARDS; RULES AND REGULATIONS; PENALTY:
Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of alcoholic liquor is prohibited
because of age shall not purchase, or accept a gift of alcoholic liquor or have
alcoholic liquor in his possession.
If a licensee or his agents or employees believes or has reason to believe that
a sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of the nonage of
the prospective recipient he shall, before making such sale or delivery demand
presentation of some form of positive identification, containing proof of age,
issued by a public officer in the performance of his official duties.
No person shall transfer, alter or deface an identification card; use the
identification card of another; carry or use a false or forged identification
card; or obtain an identification card by means of false information. No person
shall purchase, accept delivery or have possession of alcoholic liquor in
violation of this section. The consumption of alcoholic liquor by any person
under twenty one (21) years of age is forbidden.
The possession and dispensing, or consumption by a minor of alcoholic liquor in
the performance of religious service or ceremony, or the consumption by a minor
under the direct supervision and approval of the parents of such minor in the
privacy of a home, is not prohibited by this act.
Every liquor store in the village where alcoholic liquor is sold for beverage
purposes shall display at all times, in a prominent place, a printed card which
shall be issued by the clerk and which shall read substantially as follows:
   WARNING TO THOSE UNDER 21
YOU ARE SUBJECT TO A FINE UP TO FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS UNDER THE ORDINANCES OF
THE VILLAGE OF BEDFORD PARK IF YOU PURCHASE ALCOHOLIC LIQUORS, OR MISREPRESENT
YOUR AGE FOR THE PURPOSE OF PURCHASING OR OBTAINING LIQUOR.
Nothing contained in this chapter shall excuse or relieve the owner,
proprietor, or person in charge of any liquor store in the village where
alcoholic liquor is sold, from the restrictions and requirements of any other
applicable provisions of this code or of the statutes of the state.
Any holder of a retail liquor dealer's license, or any agent or employee of the
licensee, who shall violate the provisions of this section shall, upon
conviction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to the general
penalty regulations of this code, or to the revocation of his retail liquor
license, or to both such penalty and revocation of license.
Any parent or guardian who shall knowingly suffer or permit anyone under age
twenty one (21) of which he may be the parent or guardian, to violate any
provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be subject to the general
penalty provisions of this code. (Ord. 687, 9-6-1979)
5-18-16: LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
The president of the board of trustees of the village, shall be the local
liquor control commissioner and shall be charged with the administration of the
appropriate provisions of this chapter and such ordinances or resolutions as
may be hereinafter enacted. His salary as such commissioner shall be the sum of
two hundred dollars ($200.00) per annum in addition to his salary as president.
(Ord. 687, 9-6-1979)
5-18-17: CONSUMPTION AND TRANSPORTATION OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR:
   (A)   Public Ways, Parking Lots:
      1.   Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to drink, consume,
transport, carry or possess any alcoholic liquor, except in the original
package and with the seal unbroken, on a public street, sidewalk, parkway,
public parking lot or semipublic parking lot. The term "semipublic parking lot"
shall include any area wherein motor vehicles are parked by the public in
conjunction with any business, enterprise, or commercial establishment.
      2.   Penalties: Any person violating any of the provisions of this
section shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall
be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues. (Ord. 89-813, 11-16-1989; amd. Ord. 05-1172, 1-6-2005)
   (B)   Entertainment Establishments:
      1.   Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to transport or
carry an alcoholic liquor beverage to an entertainment establishment for the
purpose of consumption by said person on the premises.
      2.   Posting Of Signs: Every owner or operator of an entertainment
establishment shall post a warning sign in plain view informing patrons of this
subsection (B).
      3.   Penalties: Any person violating the provisions of this subsection
(B) shall be fined not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense and a separate offense shall
be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs.
Any owner or operator of an entertainment establishment should also be fined
not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) for every offense in which a patron has been found to be in
violation of this subsection (B). (Ord. 05-1172, 1-6-2005)
CHAPTER 19
HOTEL/MOTEL ROOM TAX
SECTION:
5-19-1: Tax Enacted
5-19-2: Use Of Tax
5-19-3: File Tax Return; Payment Of Tax
5-19-4: Failure To Pay Taxes; Action Taken
5-19-5: Patrons
5-19-6: Chapter Review
5-19-1: TAX ENACTED:
A Hotel/Motel Room Tax has been enacted in the amount of ten and one-half
percent (10.50%) of the one-night room charge for the use and privilege of a
room at any hotel, motel or other similar lodging facility operating within the
corporate geographical limits of the Village. Provided, however, any patron who
uses and occupies an extended stay hotel facility, as defined herein, shall be
exempt for payment of the Room Tax after the thirty first (31) consecutive day
of use and occupancy. This exemption shall not apply to the initial thirty (30)
day use and occupancy wherein the Hotel Tax of ten and one-half percent
(10.50%) shall remain in full force and effect. An extended stay facility shall
be defined as a hotel that has rooms specifically designed for extended stays
for patrons improved with the customary sleeping and bathroom areas and
dedicated kitchen areas with cooking appliances, refrigerator and sink.
The charge shall be effective on each night that a room is reserved, occupied,
or otherwise used in a hotel, motel or other lodging facility within the
Village. The tax assessed is charged against the room as a privilege for the
use of said room. The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of said
tax is to be borne by the person or persons who seek the privilege of occupying
the hotel or motel room. Said tax shall be applicable to all on-line travel
agencies (an "OTA"). (Ord. 18-1581, 10-4-2018)
5-19-2: USE OF TAX:
Taxes collected by the Village from the Hotel/Motel Tax may be used by the
Village for its general corporate purposes. (Ord. 88-802, 10-6-1988)
5-19-3: FILE TAX RETURN; PAYMENT OF TAX:
The person or persons who own a hotel or motel room within the Village shall
collect the tax from the person or persons who seek the privilege of occupying
the hotel or motel room. The tax shall be paid to such person and/or OTA
required to collect it as trustee for and on account of the Village. The person
or persons who own a hotel or motel room within the Village shall file tax
returns, in a form to be provided or approved by the Village, reflecting tax
receipts received with respect to each separate hotel or motel during each
month. Remittance of the tax shall be made to the Village Treasurer by
certified or cashier's check on or before the twenty fifth day of the month for
which the tax was due.
Notwithstanding the above provision, the first taxing period for the purpose of
this chapter shall commence on September 1, 1990. All subsequent reporting
periods shall be full calendar months. At the time of filing said tax returns,
the persons required to collect the tax shall remit to the Village Treasurer
all taxes due for the period to which the tax return applies.
If for any reason any tax is not paid when due, a penalty at the rate of one
and one-half percent (11/2%) per thirty (30) day period, or portion thereof,
from the date of delinquency shall be added and collected.
The Village, by its Treasurer, Auditor, or other designated representative may,
upon forty eight (48) hour written notice to the collector of said tax, examine
the written records being kept by such person or perform whatever functions it
deems necessary to verify the collection of the tax or any amounts associated
therewith. (Ord. 18-1581, 10-4-2018)
5-19-4: FAILURE TO PAY TAXES; ACTION TAKEN:
The tax herein imposed shall be in addition to all other taxes imposed by the
Village, or by any Municipal corporation or political subdivision thereof.
Whenever any person shall fail to remit any tax as herein provided, the Village
Attorney shall, upon request of the President of the Village, bring or cause to
be brought an action to enforce the remittance of said tax on behalf of the
Village in any court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 00-1072, 11-30-2000)
5-19-5: PATRONS:
Any patron or guest who uses and occupies an extended stay hotel facility shall
not be considered a resident of the Village of Bedford Park and shall be
required to reexecute a written hotel occupancy agreement every thirty (30)
days. (Ord. 09-1291, 3-5-2009)
5-19-6: CHAPTER REVIEW:
The terms and provisions of this chapter shall be reviewed by the Municipal
authorities on an annual basis. The Village shall have the right to amend,
alter or modify the terms and conditions as deemed appropriate and reasonable.
(Ord. 09-1291, 3-5-2009)
CHAPTER 20
EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM (911)
SECTION:
5-20-1: Surcharge
5-20-2: Referendum
5-20-3: Surcharge Rate, Collection
5-20-4: Definitions
5-20-5: Exemption From Surcharge
5-20-6: When Surcharge Imposed
5-20-7: Accounting And Collection Charges
5-20-8: Payment Of Surcharge
5-20-9: Surcharge Return Required
5-20-10: Surcharge Payments, Credit
5-20-11: Recovery Of Surcharge, Time Limit
5-20-12: Emergency Telephone System Board Established
5-20-1: SURCHARGE:
A surcharge is hereby imposed, subject to the provisions of section
5-20-2 of this chapter, upon all telephone subscribers passed through
telecommunication carriers engaged in the business of transmitting messages by
means of electricity originating within the corporate limits of the village and
terminating within the state of Illinois for funding of a "911" emergency
telephone system. (Ord. 91-850, 9-3-1991)
5-20-2: REFERENDUM:
A referendum shall be placed by the village clerk on the November 5, 1991,
ballot for all legal voters residing in the village to vote upon the following
question:
Shall the Village of Bedford Park impose a surcharge not to exceed seventy five
cents ($0.75) per month per network connection, which surcharge will be added
to the monthly bill you receive for telephone or telecommunications charges for
the purposes of installing a 911 emergency system?
                Yes                 No
(Ord. 91-850, 9-3-1991)
5-20-3: SURCHARGE RATE, COLLECTION:
If a majority of the votes cast upon the question are in favor thereof, a
surcharge is hereby imposed at a rate not to exceed seventy five cents ($0.75)
per month per in-service network connection, as hereinafter defined. A network
connection shall not be deemed to be in service where a subscriber's account is
uncollectible. (Ord. 91-850, 9-3-1991)
5-20-4: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply:
NETWORK CONNECTION: The number of voice grade communication channels directly
between a subscriber and a telecommunications carrier's public switched network
without the intervention of any other telecommunications carriers switched
network which would be required to carry the subscriber's interpremises
traffic.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS CARRIER: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate,
partnership, association, joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation,
municipal corporation or political subdivision of this state, or a receiver,
trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court
engaged in the business of transmitting messages by means of electricity.
For the purposes of this chapter, "telecommunication carrier" does not include
a cellular or other mobile communication carrier.
TRANSMITTING MESSAGES: The meaning ascribed to the term in section 8-11-2 of
the Illinois municipal code 1 . (Ord. 91-850, 9-3-1991)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/8-11-2.
5-20-5: EXEMPTION FROM SURCHARGE:
The village clerk shall provide any telecommunication carrier subject to the
surcharge with a certified list of those network connections assigned to the
village to be exempt from imposition of the surcharge. The certified list may
be revised by the Village on sixty (60) days prior written notice provided to
the telecommunication carriers. (Ord. 91-850, 9-3-1991)
5-20-6: WHEN SURCHARGE IMPOSED:
The surcharge shall be imposed on the first day of the month following the
expiration of ninety (90) days from the date the Village Clerk certifies to the
individual telecommunication carriers subject to the surcharge that the
referendum referred to in section
5-20-2 of this chapter has passed. (Ord. 91-850, 9-3-1991)
5-20-7: ACCOUNTING AND COLLECTION CHARGES:
In lieu of the telecommunication carriers imposing a three percent (3%)
accounting and collection charge on its subscribers as permitted under the Act
1 , each telecommunications carrier is hereby authorized and instructed to
recover said accounting and collection charge by deducting three percent (3%)
from the gross amount of surcharge collected otherwise due and owing the
Village prior to remittance under section
5-20-8 of this chapter. (Ord. 91-850, 9-3-1991)
 
Notes
1 1. 50 ILCS 750/0.01.
5-20-8: PAYMENT OF SURCHARGE:
The amount of surcharge collected by the telecommunications carrier shall be
paid to the particular municipality not later than thirty (30) days after the
surcharge is collected, net of any network or other 911 or sophisticated 911
system charges then due the particular telecommunication carrier, as shown on
an itemized bill and the three percent (3%) accounting and collection charge
described in section
5-20-7 of this chapter. (Ord. 91-850, 9-3-1991)
5-20-9: SURCHARGE RETURN REQUIRED:
Simultaneously with the remittance described in section
5-20-8 of this chapter, each telecommunication carrier shall make a return to
the Village Treasurer for the period to which the remittance applies stating as
follows:
   (A)   The name of the telecommunication carrier.
   (B)   The telecommunication carrier's principal place of business.
   (C)   The number of network connections to which the surcharge applies.
   (D)   The amount of surcharge due.
   (E)   Such other reasonable and related information as the Corporate
Authorities may require. (Ord. 91-850, 9-3-1991)
5-20-10: SURCHARGE PAYMENTS, CREDIT:
If it shall appear that an amount of surcharge has been paid which was not due
under the provisions of this chapter, whether as the result of a mistake of
fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be credited against any
surcharge due, or to become due, under this chapter from the telecommunication
carrier who made the erroneous payments; provided that no amounts erroneously
paid more than three (3) years prior to the filing of a claim therefore shall
be so credited. Ninety (90) days prior notice shall be given to the Emergency
Telephone System Board on any credit against a surcharge due. (Ord. 91-850, 9-
3-1991)
5-20-11: RECOVERY OF SURCHARGE, TIME LIMIT:
No action to recover any amount of surcharge due under the provisions of this
chapter shall be commenced more than three (3) years after the due date of such
amount. (Ord. 91-850, 9-3-1991)
5-20-12: EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM BOARD ESTABLISHED:
There shall be established, by ordinance of the Village, an Emergency Telephone
System Board (ETSB), to administer the 911 Program in accordance with the
statutory provisions and rules relating thereto. (Ord. 91-850, 9-3-1991)
CHAPTER 21
REAL ESTATE TRANSFER TAX
SECTION:
5-21-1: Definitions
5-21-2: Transfer Of Title By Deed
5-21-3: Transfer Of Beneficial Interest
5-21-4: General Provisions
5-21-5: Penalties
5-21-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings
hereinafter ascribed to them:
BENEFICIAL INTEREST: Any interest, regardless of how small or minimal such
interest may be, in a land trust, held by a trustee for the benefit of
beneficiaries of such land trust.
PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, assignee, joint
stock company, joint venture, public or private corporation, domestic or
foreign corporation, profit or not for profit corporation, trust, or a
receiver, administrator, executor, trustee, conservator, or other
representative appointed by order of any court.
REAL ESTATE: Any residential, industrial, commercial property located within
the village boundaries whether improved or unimproved.
RECORDATION: The recording of deeds by the recorder of deeds of Cook County,
Illinois. (Ord. 96-977, 3-21-1996)
5-21-2: TRANSFER OF TITLE BY DEED:
   (A)   Imposition Of Transfer Tax: A real estate transfer tax of fifty
dollars ($50.00) is hereby imposed upon the transfer of title to any real
estate within the corporate limits of the village. This tax levied shall be in
addition to any and all other taxes which may be due and owing.
   (B)   Liability For Tax: The grantor shall be responsible and liable for the
tax imposed herein.
   (C)   Purchase Of Stamps: The tax imposed herein shall be paid via the
purchase of a transfer tax stamp. The transfer tax stamp shall be placed on the
deed prior to recording. The stamps shall be purchased by the grantor, his
attorney or designated agent from the village clerk. Any transfer of title
which may occur without the transfer tax stamp will be in violation of this
code.
   (D)   Exemption: The following deeds shall be exempt from the tax levied
herein:
      1.   Deeds to property acquired by any governmental body or from any
governmental body or deeds to property between governmental bodies, or by or
from any corporation, society, association, foundation or institution organized
and operated exclusively for charitable, religious or educational purposes;
      2.   Deeds which secure debt or other obligation;
      3.   Deeds where the actual consideration is less than one hundred
dollars ($100.00);
      4.   Tax deed;
      5.   Deeds of release of property which is security for a debt or other
obligations;
      6.   Deeds of partition;
      7.   Deeds made pursuant to mergers, consolidations, or transfers or
sales of substantially all of the assets of corporations pursuant to plans of
reorganization;
      8.   Deeds made by a subsidiary corporation to its parent corporation for
no consideration other than the cancellation or surrender of the subsidiary's
stock;
      9.   Deeds wherein there is an actual exchange of real estate except that
money difference or money's worth paid from one to the other shall not be
exempt from the tax;
      10.   Deeds representing transfers subject to the imposition of a
documentary stamp tax imposed by the government of the United States, except
that such deeds shall not be exempt from filing the declaration.
Every deed which is tax exempt pursuant to this section shall be presented to
the village clerk so as to be appropriately marked by said village clerk as an
exempt deed eligible for recordation without the payment of tax. At such time
as a deed is presented to the comptroller pursuant to this section, there shall
be filed with the village clerk a certificate setting forth the facts which
justify the exemption of the deed presented. The certificate shall be executed
on behalf of either the grantor or grantee, and shall be on a form provided by
the village clerk. (Ord. 96-977, 3-21-1996)
5-21-3: TRANSFER OF BENEFICIAL INTEREST:
   (A)   Imposition Of Transfer Tax: A real estate transfer tax of fifty
dollars ($50.00) is hereby imposed upon the transfer of any beneficial interest
in any real estate within the corporate limits of the village. This tax levied
shall be in addition to any and all other taxes which may be due and owing.
   (B)   Liability For Tax: The grantor or assignor of any instrument conveying
the beneficial interest in the real estate within the corporate limits shall be
responsible and liable for the tax imposed herein.
   (C)   Purchase Of Stamps: The tax imposed herein shall be paid via the
purchase of a transfer tax stamp. The transfer tax stamp shall be placed on the
deed prior to recording. The stamp shall be purchased by the grantor, his
attorney or designated agent from the village clerk. Any transfer of title
which may occur without the transfer tax stamp will be in violation of this
code.
   (D)   Filing Of Declaration: At such time as the tax levied by this section
is paid, there shall be filed with the village clerk a declaration of actual
consideration paid for the transfer of beneficial interest, which declaration
shall be on a form provided by the village clerk and executed by the person
liable for the tax.
   (E)   Real Estate Transfer Tax Stamps: The tax herein levied and imposed
shall be collected by the village clerk through the sale of real estate
transfer tax stamps.
   (F)   Duty Of Trustee: No trustee of real estate shall accept an assignment
of beneficial interest in real estate located in the village unless tax stamps
in the required amount, as set forth in this section, have been affixed to the
assignment. (Ord. 96-977, 3-21-1996)
5-21-4: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   (A)   Notification To Village Building Coordinator: At the time an
application is made for the purchase of tax stamps, the village clerk shall
notify the building coordinator so that an inspection of the subject real
estate can be scheduled. The building coordinator shall notify the seller of
any village code violations and said violations shall be properly rectified
prior to any sale of the real estate.
   (B)   Notification To Water Department: At the time an application is made
for the purchase of tax stamps, the village clerk shall notify the
superintendent of water who shall determine if there are any outstanding water
charges due the village. If there is an outstanding balance due the village,
the same shall be paid prior to the sale of the real estate.
   (C)   Proceeds Of Tax: All proceeds from the collection of this real estate
transfer tax shall be paid into the general corporate fund. (Ord. 96-977, 3-21-
1996)
5-21-5: PENALTIES:
The following penalties shall be imposed upon any person who fails to comply
with the conditions of this chapter:
   (A)   In the event of failure by any person to pay the village clerk the tax
required hereunder when the same is due, said person shall be liable to the
village for such tax together with any fines which may be imposed as set forth
in subsection (B) of this section.
   (B)   Any person found guilty in a court of competent jurisdiction of
violating, omitting, or refusing to comply with any of the terms of this
chapter, shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00)
nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. (Ord. 96-977,
3-21-1996)
CHAPTER 22
ALARM SYSTEMS
SECTION:
5-22-1: Definitions
5-22-2: Application For Alarm Systems Authorization; Alarm Licenses
5-22-3: Permits
5-22-4: Revocation Of Permit
5-22-5: False Alarms; Service Charges
5-22-6: Local Alarms
5-22-7: Installation Of Fire Alarms
5-22-8: Special Alarm Provisions
5-22-9: Liability
5-22-10: Penalty
5-22-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
ALARM BUSINESS: A business by any individual, partnership, corporation, or
other entity selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering,
replacing, moving or installing any alarm system or causing any of the above to
occur in or on any building, structure or facility.
ALARM RECEIPT POINT: That facility whose purpose is to monitor incoming alarm
signals twenty four (24) hours a day and relay the signal information to the
appropriate authorities.
ALARM SYSTEM: Any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, arranged to
signal the occurrence of a fire, medical or police emergency such as illegal
entry or other activity or condition requiring urgent attention and to which
the fire and/or police departments are expected to respond; however, this does
not include audible alarms or fire detectors affixed to automobiles, or other
motor vehicles, nor does it include audible alarm signals which may be heard
only within a building, such as a smoke detector.
ALARM USER: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, or other
organization of any kind in control of any building, structure, or facility
where an alarm system is maintained or activated within the municipality,
except for alarm systems on motor vehicles. Also included are those systems
which employ an audible signal emitting sounds, or a flashing light or beacon
designed to alert or signal persons outside the premises of an alarm
activation.
AUTOMATIC RECORDED VOICE DEVICE: Any electrically operated instrument composed
of sensory apparatus and related hardware which automatically sends over
regular telephone lines (dialer), by direct connection or otherwise, a
prerecorded voice alarm on receipt of a stimulus from the sensory apparatus
that has detected a physical force or condition inherently characteristic of a
fire or unauthorized intrusion. Also included are devices which are stimulated
by direct action by the alarm user or his employees.
EMERGENCY ALARMS: An alarm signal indicating an emergency requiring immediate
action is received when sprinkler system water flow, automatic fire detection,
manual fire alarm box, or other emergency device functions; a supervisory
signal, which is a signal that is produced when a monitored device such as
control valve position, pressure, water level, or fire pump running switch
functions or varies from normal; a trouble signal which indicates a malfunction
in the signaling system circuitry or power failure.
FALSE ALARM: Any emergency alarm signal, either audible outside or delivered to
an alarm receipt point (including the police communications center), or
delivered from an alarm receipt point that requires a response by emergency
equipment where a "no emergency" exists, as a result of equipment malfunction,
improper installation or human error. Failure to follow village ordinances and
directives shall be treated as a false alarm. The initial classification of
alarms as false shall be the responsibility of the fire department or police
department as deemed appropriate. Provisions of other codes, standards and
ordinances shall apply.
FIRE CHIEF: The chief of the fire department of the village of Bedford Park,
Illinois, or his authorized representative.
LICENSE DIVISION: The village clerk's office of the village of Bedford Park
which will be authorized to issue permits and collect the fees as set forth in
this chapter.
LOCAL ALARM: Any signaling system which, when activated, causes an audible
signaling device to be activated in or on the premises within which the system
is installed.
POLICE CHIEF: The chief of police of the village of Bedford Park or his
authorized representative.
PRIMARY TRUNK LINE: A telephone line leading directly into the village of
Bedford Park for the purpose of handling emergency calls on a person to person
basis, or which is identified by a specific number in the telephone direction.
(Ord. 00-1051, 4-20-2000)
5-22-2: APPLICATION FOR ALARM SYSTEMS AUTHORIZATION; ALARM LICENSES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation or other organization, either directly or indirectly to conduct any
business or not for profit enterprise that installs, connects, repairs or
otherwise does any work on emergency alarms without first obtaining a license
to do business as required by the state of Illinois.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person, corporation, firm or other entity
to install or have installed any emergency alarm designed to protect any
residential, commercial or business premises, or any other building either by
local alarm or by any system that connects to an alarm receipt point without
first obtaining a permit to install and operate said system as required
hereunder.
   (C)   Application for permits shall be made in writing to the village clerk
on or before June 1, unless the permit holder submits a permit application
accompanied by the renewal fee of twenty dollars ($20.00).
   (D)   All permits issued shall be renewed at the end of each permit year.
(Ord. 00-1051, 4-20-2000)
5-22-3: PERMITS:
   (A)   Permit Required: Every alarm user located within the village of
Bedford Park, Illinois, shall apply to the village clerk of Bedford Park for an
alarm user permit for each and every alarm system that is being used. In the
event an alarm system is already in use prior to the effective date hereof, an
application for a permit must be filed within thirty (30) days from the
effective date hereof and if said application is not filed within the thirty
(30) days, the use of that alarm system shall be unlawful until such time that
the permit has been secured.
   (B)   Permit Application; Fee: The application for the permit shall be
accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for each
application that is filed with the village clerk. The application shall include
the following information:
      1.   Name and address of the residence or business or businesses in or on
which the alarm system has been or will be installed;
      2.   Telephone number of applicant;
      3.   Type of alarm system to be installed;
      4.   Name, address and telephone number of the company responsible for
the installation and maintenance of the alarm system.
   (C)   Confidentiality: The information contained in an application shall be
maintained and restricted to inspection only by the chief of police, fire
chief, or other municipal employees who are assigned the responsibility of
processing said application.
   (D)   Annual Renewal Permit: Each alarm user shall obtain an annual renewal
permit from the village clerk on or before June 1 of each year. The renewal fee
shall be twenty dollars ($20.00). In the event the renewal application is not
made by May 1, the village clerk shall notify the permit holder by certified
mail that revocation shall take place on June 1, unless the permit holder
submits a permit application accompanied by the renewal fee of twenty dollars
($20.00).
   (E)   Inspection: The police chief or his delegate, may inspect burglary
alarm systems and the fire chief or his delegate may inspect all fire alarm
systems located within the village of Bedford Park, both prior to and
subsequent to the issuance of a permit. (Ord. 00-1051, 4-20-2000)
5-22-4: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
   (A)   The police chief and/or fire chief may revoke any permit issued
pursuant to the terms and provisions of this chapter upon finding any one or
more of the following violations:
      1.   False information submitted in the alarm permit application;
      2.   Failure to comply with any provision of this chapter;
      3.   Failure to pay any fine charged herein;
      4.   Failure to adhere to any order of the police and/or fire chief;
      5.   Excessive false alarms, (13 or more), within a one year period of
time.
   (B)   Prior to revocation of a permit, the village clerk shall first give
written notice to the alarm user describing the violation and warning them of
said revocation unless the following steps are implemented:
      1.   The alarm user shall have not more than seven (7) days to correct
the violation; or
      2.   The alarm user shall provide to the police chief and/or fire chief
any information or documentation to prove that the violation should be excused.
   (C)   Any alarm user may appeal a decision made either by the police chief
and/or fire chief by filing a written appeal within ten (10) days after the
said decision. The appeal shall be heard either by the fire committee or police
committee at a time designated by it. The committee, in its sole discretion,
may hold a public hearing pertaining to the appeal. The committee shall review
