Chapter 7
Chapter 7. FIRE RESISTANCE RATED MATERIALS AND CONSTRUCTION is hereby amended
by the following:
Section 704. EXTERIOR WALLS
Subsection 704.5. Exterior walls shall be fire resistance rated on both sides
in accordance with Table 601 and Table 602.
Subsection 704.8. Allowable area of openings. Allowable area of openings shall
be in accordance with the required fire rating and listings.
Subsection 704.8. Delete.
Section 705. FIRE WALLS. Revised to read as follows:
Subsection 705.3. Materials. Fire Walls shall be of approved solid masonry
construction.
Subsection 705.4. Fire Resistance Rating. Firewalls shall have a four-hour fire
resistance rating. Table 705.4 is deleted.
Subsection 708.1.5: Tenant Separation
708.1.5-A: Each tenant space in a multiple tenant building shall be separated
from each other and from corridors, hallways, or passageways, by walls,
partitions, and floor- ceiling assemblies having a fire resistance rating of
not less than one hour.
708.1.5-B: For the purpose of applying "A" above, the following definitions
shall apply:
   1.) Tenant: A person, corporation, company, or similar organization, however
organized, operating as one business and occupying space within a building.
708.1.5-C: Tenant space: The area of square footage used and occupied by a
tenant in a single tenant or multi-tenant building.
Subsection 708.4 of Section 708.0. "Fire Partitions" are hereby amended to read
as follows:
Subsection 708.4. Continuity: All fire partitions shall extend from the top of
the floor assembly below to the underside of the floor/roof slab and shall be
securely attached thereto. The supporting construction shall be protected to
afford the required fire resistance rating of the wall supported. All hollow
vertical spaces shall be fire-stopped at every floor level with an approved
fire resistive material(s).
Chapter 9
Chapter 9. FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS is hereby added to, amended and/or deleted
as follows:
Section 903. "Automatic Sprinkler Systems" is hereby amended by adding to such
Section.
Subsections 903.1.0 and 903.02.12.1.4 shall read as follows:
903.1.0. All Use Groups. Supplementing those locations listed in this Code, any
building when more than 5,000 square feet (gross) in area or when more than
three stories in height shall be provided with an approved automatic fire
sprinkler system.
903.2.12.1.4. Basements. If the area of a basement exceeds 2,000 square feet
(gross) an automatic fire sprinkler systems shall be required.
Subsections 903.3.1.2. and 903.3.1.3 of Section 903.0. "Automatic Sprinkler
Systems" is hereby deleted.
Subsection 903.3.5. Subsections 1.1 and 903.4.2 of Section 903. "Limited Area
Sprinkler Systems" are hereby deleted.
Subsection 907.2 of Section 907 "Fire Alarm and Detection Systems" is hereby
amended by inserting the following:
907.2.0.1. Residential Uses. An automatic fire detection system shall be
installed and maintained in all buildings of Use Groups R-1 and R-2. All
buildings having multiple uses including residential use shall be equipped with
an approved automatic fire alarm and fire detection system.
907.2.0.2. Other Uses: All other buildings including educational, high hazard,
institutional, mercantile, factory or industrial, assembly, storage, or
business occupancies including any other buildings housing combustible
materials and products, over one story I height, and such one-story building
over 1,000 square feet (gross) in area shall be equipped with an approved fire
alarm system.
Subsection 907.2.12.1.4 of Section 907.0. "Fire Alarm and Detection Systems" is
hereby amended by adding said subsection.
907.2.12.1.4. The automatic fire alarm system shall be approved for the
particular application and shall be used for detection and signaling in the
event of fire. Automatic detecting devices shall be approved for use in which
they are intended. Smoke detectors, as part of the fire alarm system, shall be
used where assembly, institutional, residential and educational uses exist.
The following Subsection 909.1.1 is hereby added to Section 909, "Smoke Control
Systems" and Section 910, "Smoke and Heat Vents" shall read as follows:
909.1.1. Village requirements. An emergency smoke control system and/or smoke
and heat vents shall be provided:
      1.   In all sprinklered buildings with a gross (combined floor area of
all floors) floor area exceeding 50,000 square feet.
      2.   In all non- sprinklered buildings with a gross floor area exceeding
5,000 square feet.
      3.   In all buildings over one-story or 15 feet in height. Basements are
considered a story. Residential R-3 and R-4 use groups are exempt from this
subsection.
909.1.2. Design Criteria. All systems shall be designed in accordance with
nationally recognized standards for the design of such systems. Also, refer to
Sections 909 and 910.
909.1.2.1. Air Changes. The system shall be designed to provide a minimum of
four (4) to six (6) air changes per hour throughout the fire area.
909.1.2.1.1. The mechanical smoke management system shall have an adequate
supply and/or return air source to allow the system to operate properly.
909.1.2.1.2. The smoke management system shall be operated manually except for
buildings over three stories in height. It may also be designed to operate
automatically.
909.1.2.3.1. The location and design of controls for the mechanical smoke
management system including the pressurization of areas of a building shall be
at a location approved by the Bureau of Fire Prevention and shall be at a
location easily accessible.
909.1.2.3.1. Building Over Three Stories. In buildings over three stories in
height, interior access corridors, stairs and exit ways shall be provided with
positive pressure.
909.1.2.3.1.1. The pressurization system may operate continuously or be
activated by the alarm signal of the fire alarm of fire suppression system.
Manual controls shall be provided.
Subsection 901.6.4. of Section 901 "General" is hereby amended by deleting said
section and inserting in lieu thereof the following:
907.14.1. Fire Suppression System/Fire Alarm System Supervision. Each fire
suppression system and/or each fire alarm system shall be supervised at an
approved, constantly attended location from which the fire department will be
immediately notified.
907.14.2. Alarm Supervisory and Trouble Signals. The following signals shall be
supervised.
907.14.2.1. Alarm. All flow and all active alarm signals from any fire
suppression and/or fire alarm system in service shall be supervised.
907.14.3. Supervisory and Trouble Signals. All system components which are
normally supervised including valves, pressures and levels where critical to
the system operation, National Fire Protection standards required signals and
any other component deemed necessary for the proper operation of the system
shall be supervised.
Chapter 10.
Chapter 10. MEANS OF EGRESS is hereby amended as follows:
Add to Subsection 1005.2.2.4 of Section 1005, "Exits".
1005.2.2.4. Village Requirements. Two or more remotely located exits are
required when any of the following are not met. Space is under 2000 square
feet, space with an occupancy load of 20 or less or travel distance of 75 feet
or less.
Chapter 11.
Chapter 11. ACCESSIBILITY is hereby amended as follows:
Subsection 1101.1.1 of Section 1101.0, "General" is hereby added to include the
following:
   1.   Business Signs and Street Numbers: All buildings, tenant spaces, places
of business, licensed to do business within the Village of Bedford Park shall
have a business sign for identification of the establishment along with the
numbered address (not less than six inches in height) posted on the front or
street side of said establishment, front and rear access or entrance points of
the building or facility.
   2.   Occupancy Certificates.
   3.   Maintenance of Exterior Property:
A. Sanitation: All exterior property or premises shall be maintained, clean,
safe, sanitary and free from any accumulation of rubbish, wood or garbage,
unusable metals, machinery, tanks, miscellaneous scrap, appliances, motor
vehicle parts, furniture and junk is prohibited.
B. Sidewalks and Driveways: All sidewalks, walkways, driveways, paved areas and
concrete areas shall be kept in a proper state of repair and maintained free
from hazardous conditions.
C. Rat and Rodent Harborage: All structures and exterior of properties shall be
kept free from rat and rodent harborage, where infestation occurs, the property
owner or owners shall be responsible for elimination of the infestation
problem. Whereas, if a business has caused to attract the rodent nuisance, the
said business is responsible to remedy the infestation problem.
   4.   Drainage Ditches or Sewers: No persons(s), companies, corporations,
businesses, etc. shall obstruct any drainage ditch or sewer or shall deposit,
dump or pour any substance or materials into a storm or sanitary sewer system
other than normal sanitary waste or storm/rain water.
   5.   Exterior of Structures - Appearance: The exterior of a structure shall
be maintained in good repair, structurally sound and sanitary so as not to pose
a threat to the public health, safety and welfare. Any painted surface must be
maintained free of scaling or chipping paint and must have a uniform surface
appearance.
   6.   Vacant Structures: All vacant structures shall be maintained in a
clean, safe, secure and sanitary condition so as to not adversely affect the
public health or safety. No vacant structure may have any broken windows,
broken doors, structural openings or other means of access thereto.
   7.   Exterior Walls: All exterior walls shall be free of holes, breaks,
loose or rotted materials and maintained weather proof and properly surface
coated where required to prevent deterioration.
   8.   Roofs and Drainage: The roof and flashing shall be sound, tight and not
have defects which would admit rainwater, leakage or any other type of liquids,
etc. that would affect or present a hazard within the building.
   9.   Doors and Locks: All exterior and interior doors and the associated
hardware shall be maintained in good condition for ingress and egress purposes.
All locks and latches used shall be the proper hardware, not to be operated
with the use of keys or other special knowledge.
   10.   Interior Surfaces: All interior surfaces, including concrete floors,
windows and doors, shall be maintained in good, clean and sanitary condition.
Peeling paint, cracked or loose plaster, decayed wood and other defective
surface conditions shall be corrected (repaired properly).
   11.   Accumulation of Rubbish or Garbage: The interior of every structure
shall be free from any accumulation of rubbish or garbage.
1101.1.1. Illinois Accessibility Code. The provisions of the Illinois
Accessibility apply.
   (Ord. 01-1103, 11-29-2001; amd. Ord. 02-1125, 10-18-2002)
7-5-12: PENALTY:
Any person or persons found to be in violation of this chapter shall be fined
not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed to be
committed for each day that a violation exists. In addition to the imposition
of fines, the person or persons may be directed to correct and remedy the code
violation. Noncompliance with this chapter is also a basis for the revocation
of a business certificate per the terms of the village code. (Ord. 01-1103, 11-
29-2001)
7-5-13: CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY:
   (A)   Definitions: The following definitions shall be used throughout this
section:
   CONSTRUCTION: Any modifications, alterations, rehabilitation or new
construction.
   STRUCTURES: Any building, structure, residence, garage or accessory
building.
   (B)   Issuance Of Certificate: It shall be unlawful to use, occupy or reside
in any structure or any portion thereof until the building official or fire
department has issued a certificate of occupancy. No such certificate shall be
issued unless there is full compliance with all applicable village rules and
regulations. This provision shall apply to any and all construction and/or
structures within the village of Bedford Park.
   (C)   Penalty: Any person found to be in violation of this section shall be
fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Every day that a violation is allowed to
exist shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 01-1094, 10-18-2001)
CHAPTER 6
ELECTRICAL CODE
SECTION:
7-6-1: Adoption Of Code
7-6-2: Definitions
7-6-3: Electrical Inspector; Office Created
7-6-4: Electrical Inspector; Qualifications
7-6-5: Electrical Inspector; Oath And Bond, Duties, Powers
7-6-6: Electrical Permit Fees
7-6-7: Appeals
7-6-8: Penalty
7-6-1: ADOPTION OF CODE:
The current Chicago Electrical Code with amendments is hereby adopted in full.
(Ord. 18-1568, 5-17-2018)
7-6-2: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the words "administration authority" or the "authority having
jurisdiction" are used in the Chicago Electrical Code it shall mean the Village
of Bedford Park or such person or persons that may be appointed and authorized
by the Village to carry out the provisions of the code. (Ord. 96-984, 11-7-
1996; amd. Ord. 01-1104, 11-29-2001)
7-6-3: ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR; OFFICE CREATED:
There shall be created the office of electrical inspector who shall be
appointed by the President, by and with the consent of the Board of Trustees of
the Village whose duty it shall be to inspect all electrical equipment in the
Village which is either altered or installed at any building or facility and
residential homes in the Village. The electrical inspector shall so certify
that the foregoing equipment is in a safe and operable condition pursuant to
the applicable codes and standards and specifications adopted by the Village.
Upon inspection or reinspection of a building or facility in the Village, the
electrical inspector shall report his findings as to the condition of the
electrical equipment in said building to the Building Department at which time
the Building Coordinator shall administer and execute the necessary regulations
and procedures within the department to effectively administer the issuance of
permits. Whenever electrical equipment has been installed, altered or repaired,
no electrical current shall be supplied to or used on any building or equipment
prior to the inspection of said equipment or building by the electrical
inspector and review by the Building Coordinator. The electrical inspector
shall be compensated for his duties as set forth by the Board of Trustees. If
the President and Board of Trustees desire to employ the electrical inspector
in his capacity as an electrician to either work for the Village in said
capacity or for an official or employee of the Village in his capacity as an
electrical contractor, the Village or individual wishing to employ the
electrical inspector may do so; except that any installation or alteration of
electrical equipment to be performed by the electrical inspector pursuant to
the foregoing provisions shall require the approval of the Board of Trustees
whenever the amount of compensation to be paid to the electrical inspector for
electrical contractor work exceeds the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
(Ord. 96-984, 11-7-1996)
7-6-4: ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR; QUALIFICATIONS:
The person certified to fill the position of electrical inspector shall be a
licensed electrician or electrical contractor with at least two (2) years of
experience in electrical installation work. (Ord. 96-984, 11-7-1996)
7-6-5: ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR; OATH AND BOND, DUTIES, POWERS:
   (A)   Oath And Bond: Before entering upon the duties of his office, the
electrical inspector shall take and subscribe the oath of office and shall
execute, acknowledge and deliver to the Village a good and sufficient bond with
two (2) or more sureties conditioned for the faithful discharge of his duties
in his office. The bond shall meet with the approval of the Village Board.
   (B)   Duties: It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to ensure
compliance with all of the ordinances of the Village relating to electrical
work and electrical equipment; and to make such investigations and perform such
duties as may be necessary in the enforcement of such ordinances.
   (C)   Powers: The electrical inspector is hereby authorized and empowered to
enforce all ordinance provisions relating to electrical work and electrical
systems. Said inspector is authorized and directed to do the following work on
behalf of the Village:
      1.   Inspection: No electrical installation or alteration shall be
covered, enclosed or closed in until an approved seal of inspection shall have
been applied to the installation by the electrical inspector.
      2.   Stop Order: The electrical inspector shall have the power to order
work stopped on the construction, alteration or repair of electrical equipment
when such work is being done in violation of any ordinance. Work shall not be
resumed after the issuance of such a stop order except on written permission.
      3.   Employees Not Liable: Any employee charged with the enforcement of
this chapter, acting in good faith and without malice for the Village in the
discharge of his duties, shall not thereby render himself liable personally and
is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue
to persons or property as a result of any act required or by reason of any act
or omission in the discharge of his duties. Any suit brought against any
building official or employee because of such act or omission performed by him
in the enforcement of any provisions of this chapter shall be defended by the
Legal Department of the Village until final termination of the proceedings.
      4.   Stop Work Notice: Whenever any electrical work is being done
contrary to the provisions of this chapter, the enforcing officers may order
the work stopped by notice, in writing, served on the contractor or persons
doing or causing such work to be done, and any such person shall forthwith stop
such work until authorized by the enforcing officer to proceed with the work.
      5.   Reports: The enforcing officer shall prepare and submit all reports
requested by the Village Board on any work covered by this chapter and shall
incorporate in said report a summary of his recommendations as to desirable
amendments to this Code. (Ord. 96-984, 11-7-1996)
