   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, or cause to be placed,
graffiti upon the property of another, whether publicly or privately owned,
without the express written consent of the owner of said property.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant, or lessee of property
which is in the public view to grant such written consent to place any graffiti
if such graffiti refers to gang criminal activity, contains defamatory language
or symbolism or depicts obscene sexual conduct in that such graffiti
constitutes a nuisance.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to possess spray paint containers,
paint, ink, marking pens, or other similar materials for marking or etching
with the intent of using said items in violation of subsections (A) and/or (B)
of this section. (Ord. 93-897, 12-16-1993)
9-15-3: REMOVAL OF GRAFFITI:
Upon receiving written notice by a police officer of the village, the owner of
the property upon which graffiti has been illegally placed shall remove said
graffiti within ten (10) days of the date of the notice. Failure to remove the
graffiti within said time frame shall be a violation of this chapter. The
penalty upon a conviction shall be not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per offense for each day from the date
that the notice is given to remove the graffiti. (Ord. 93-897, 12-16-1993)
9-15-4: PENALTIES:
Any individual who is found to be in violation of subsection
9-15-2(A) of this chapter, shall be assessed a fine of not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). In addition to
said fine, the offender may be ordered by the court to pay appropriate
restitution to the property owner for any costs incurred as a result of
restoring their property to its original state prior to the application of the
graffiti.
Any individual who is found to be in violation of subsection
9-15-2(B) of this chapter, shall be assessed a fine of not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day during or on which a
violation occurs. Any individual who is found to be in violation of subsection
9-15-2(C) of this chapter shall be assessed a fine of not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 93-897,
12-16-1993)
CHAPTER 16
GAMBLING AMUSEMENT DEVICES
SECTION:
9-16-1: Prohibition
9-16-2: Violation, Penalty
9-16-1: PROHIBITION:
   (A)   No gambling amusement device shall be able to accept any currency in
an amount greater than twenty five cents ($0.25) or a quarter. Said machine may
be able to accept unlimited amounts of United States currency in the amount of
twenty five cents ($0.25) or a quarter however no larger currency denomination
may be accepted by the gambling amusement device at one time.
   (B)   No person may make payment in an effort to circumvent the twenty five
cents ($0.25) or quarter limitation whereby credits said machine are added to
the machine.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any device subject to this section to have
credit points or any other indication of payment added to the device, by
payment or other than by the insertion of twenty five cents ($0.25) or a
quarter, or for the device to be able to have such credit administered or added
manually. (Ord. 98-1007, 3-5-1998)
9-16-2: VIOLATION, PENALTY:
Any person found in violation of subsection
9-16-1(A) or (B) of this chapter shall be subject to a minimal fine of five
hundred dollars ($500.00) per offense, with each day constituting a separate
and chargeable offense as well as each incident. (Ord. 98-1007, 3-5-1998)
CHAPTER 17
RETAIL THEFT
SECTION:
9-17-1: Definitions
9-17-2: Acts Of Retail Theft
9-17-3: Full Retail Value Of Property
9-17-4: Presumptions
9-17-5: Repeat Offenders
9-17-6: Penalties
9-17-7: Failure To Attend Court Hearing
9-17-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words shall be defined as indicated:
CONCEAL: To "conceal" merchandise means that, although there may be some notice
of its presence, the merchandise is not visible through ordinary observation.
FULL RETAIL VALUE: The merchant's stated or advertised price of the
merchandise.
MERCHANDISE: Any item of tangible personal property.
MERCHANT: An owner or operator of any retail mercantile establishment or any
agent, employee, lessee, consignee, officer, director, franchisee or
independent contractor of such owner or operator.
PERSON: Any natural person or individual.
PREMISES OF A RETAIL MERCANTILE ESTABLISHMENT: Includes, but is not limited to,
the retail mercantile establishment, any common use areas in shopping centers
and all parking areas set aside by a merchant or on behalf of a merchant for
the parking of vehicles for the convenience of the patrons of such retail
mercantile establishment.
RETAIL MERCANTILE ESTABLISHMENT: Any place where merchandise is displayed,
held, stored or offered for sale to the public. (Ord. 01-1078, 1-18-2001)
9-17-2: ACTS OF RETAIL THEFT:
A person shall be deemed to have committed retail theft upon any of the
following acts:
   (A)   Takes possession of, carries away, transfers or causes to be carried
away or transferred, any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for
sale in a retail mercantile establishment with the intention of retaining such
merchandise or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the
possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full retail
value of such merchandise; or
   (B)   Alters, transfers, or removes any label, price tag, marking, indicia
of value or any other markings which aid in determining value affixed to any
merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale, in a retail mercantile
establishment and attempts to purchase such merchandise personally or in
consort with another at less than the full retail value with the intention of
depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; or
   (C)   Transfers any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale,
in a retail mercantile establishment from the container in or on which such
merchandise is displayed to any other container with the intention of depriving
the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; or
   (D)   Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner and
thereby intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the
property when a lessee of the personal property of another fails to return it
to the owner, or if the lessee fails to pay the full retail value of such
property to the lessor in satisfaction of any contractual provision requiring
such, within thirty (30) days after written demand from the owner for its
return. A notice in writing, given after the expiration of the leasing
agreement, by registered mail, to the lessee at the address given by the lessee
and shown on the leasing agreement shall constitute proper demand. (Ord. 01-
1078, 1-18-2001)
9-17-3: FULL RETAIL VALUE OF PROPERTY:
The value of the property as described in section
9-17-2 of this chapter shall be less than three hundred dollars ($300.00).
(Ord. 16-1512, 7-7-2016)
9-17-4: PRESUMPTIONS:
If any person:
   (A)   Conceals upon his or her person or among his or her belongings,
unpurchased merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail
mercantile establishment; and
   (B)   Removes that merchandise beyond the last known station for receiving
payments for that merchandise in that retail mercantile establishment;
such person shall be presumed to have possessed, carried away or transferred
such merchandise with the intention of retaining it or with the intention of
depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such
merchandise without paying the full retail value of such merchandise. (Ord. 01-
1078, 1-18-2001)
9-17-5: REPEAT OFFENDERS:
Any person arrested for or convicted of retail theft under this chapter or
State Statute, who is arrested for retail theft a second or further time, shall
not be charged under this chapter, but shall be charged under the State Statute
provisions relating to retail theft, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/16A-1 et
seq. (Ord. 01-1078, 1-18-2001)
9-17-6: PENALTIES:
Any person convicted of violating this chapter shall be fined not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
Furthermore, any person found guilty of the offense of retail theft in addition
to the imposition of a fine or in lieu of a fine, may be required by the court
to perform community service. (Ord. 01-1078, 1-18-2001)
9-17-7: FAILURE TO ATTEND COURT HEARING:
   (A)   Attendance Required: Retailers or vendors who seek the Police
Department's assistance with respect to individuals accused of retail theft
shall fully cooperate with the Police Department in connection with the
prosecution of the case. A retailer or vendor shall be obligated to attend each
and every court assigned hearing date relative to the case.
A failure to attend a court hearing resulting in the dismissal of the case
shall be a violation of this section.
   (B)   Violation: Any retailer or vendor found to be in violation of this
section shall be subject to a fine of not less than five hundred dollars
($500.00) and no more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 16-
1514, 8-15-2016)
CHAPTER 18
SOUND AMPLIFICATION DEVICES
SECTION:
9-18-1: Noise Restrictions
9-18-2: Exception
9-18-3: Penalties
9-18-1: NOISE RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for a person to play, use, operate or permit to be played,
used or operated, any radio, tape recorder, cassette player or other similar
device for receiving broadcast sound or reproducing recorded sound if such
device is located:
   (A)   On a public way; or
   (B)   In any motor vehicle on a public way;
and if the sound generated by the device is clearly audible to a person with
normal hearing at a distance greater than seventy five feet (75'). (Ord. 02-
1124, 10-3-2002)
9-18-2: EXCEPTION:
This chapter shall not apply to any person participating in a parade or public
assembly in which a permit has been issued or to authorized emergency vehicles.
(Ord. 02-1124, 10-3-2002)
9-18-3: PENALTIES:
Any person convicted of violating the provisions of this chapter shall be fined
not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than three hundred dollars
($300.00) per offense. (Ord. 02-1124, 10-3-2002)
CHAPTER 19
ICE CREAM VEHICLES
SECTION:
9-19-1: Prohibition Of Ice Cream Vehicles
9-19-2: Penalty
9-19-1: PROHIBITION OF ICE CREAM VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful to operate, or cause to operate, any vehicle including
vehicles by human power, designed for the storage and carrying of ice cream or
similar products for resale within the entire residential section of the
village. (Ord. 03-1143, 7-3-2003)
9-19-2: PENALTY:
Any person, company or other entity convicted of violating this chapter shall
be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) per offense. (Ord. 03-1143, 7-3-2003)
CHAPTER 20
MOTOR DRIVEN SCOOTERS
SECTION:
9-20-1: Definition
9-20-2: Restrictions
9-20-3: Exemptions
9-20-4: Applicability
9-20-5: Penalty
9-20-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this chapter, a "motor driven scooter" is defined as any
electric or gas driven wheeled scooter, motor driven cycle or other similar
motor driven vehicle for which the state of Illinois does not issue a title
document, and does not issue license plates or registration documents. (Ord.
04-1168, 10-21-2004)
9-20-2: RESTRICTIONS:
No person shall operate a motor driven scooter upon any public street,
sidewalk, parking lot, bike path, park or on any other public property. (Ord.
04-1168, 10-21-2004)
9-20-3: EXEMPTIONS:
The following shall be exempt from the prohibitions contained in this chapter:
   (A)   Any police vehicle, fire vehicle, municipal vehicle, special district
vehicle, operated by an employee in the course of his or her duties.
   (B)   Motorized wheelchairs. For purposes of this chapter, a "motorized
wheelchair" means any motorized vehicle designed for and used by a person with
disabilities.
   (C)   Electric personal assistive mobility devices, as defined in section 5/
1-117.7 of the Illinois vehicle code 1 . (Ord. 04-1168, 10-21-2004)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.
9-20-4: APPLICABILITY:
This chapter shall apply to the entire area located within the corporate limits
of the village. (Ord. 04-1168, 10-21-2004)
9-20-5: PENALTY:
Any person eighteen (18) years of age or older who violates any of the
provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than two
hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for
each offense. An offense committed by a minor under the direct control or with
the consent of a parent or guardian may subject the parent or guardian to the
penalties provided in this section. (Ord. 04-1168, 10-21-2004)
CHAPTER 21
CANNABIS AND DRUG PARAPHERNALIA
SECTION:
9-21-1: Definitions
9-21-2: Personal Use Of Cannabis
9-21-3: Personal Use Of Cannabis; Restrictions On Cultivation; Penalties
9-21-4: Persons Under 21 Years Of Age
9-21-5: Identification And False Identification
9-21-6: Prohibited Conduct
9-21-7: Cannabis Waste
9-21-8: Possession Of Adult Use Cannabis In A Motor Vehicle
9-21-9: Preemption
9-21-10: Schedule Of Fines; Penalties
9-21-11: Drug Paraphernalia
9-21-1: DEFINITIONS:
All defined terms used in this chapter which are not expressly defmed herein
shall have the meaning ascribed to such term in the Drug Paraphernalia Control
Act, Illinois Controlled Substances Act* the Cannabis Control Act, or the
Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act As used in this subsection, unless the context
otherwise requires:
CANNABIS:      The meaning ascribed to it in section 3 of the Cannabis Control Act, as if that

               All equipment, products and materials of any kind, other than methamphetamine

               and Community Protection Act and cannabis paraphernalia as defined in Section 1-
               10 of the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, which are intended to be used

               substances.
               B.   Isomerization devices used, intended for use or designed for use in

               E.   Objects intended to be used unlawfully in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise

                  9.   Ice pipes or chillers;
               F.   Any item whose purpose, as announced or described by the seller, is for use
               in violation of this Drug Paraphernalia Control Act.
DRUG           “Drug paraphernalia” does not include:
PARAPHERNALIA: A.   Items used in the preparation, compounding, packaging, labeling, or other
               use of cannabis or a controlled substance as an incident to lawful research,
               teaching, or chemical analysis and not for sale.
               B.   Items historically and customarily used in connection with the planting,
               propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding,
               converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging,
               repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, or inhaling
               of cannabis, tobacco, or any other lawful substance. Items exempt under this
               subsection include, but are not limited to, garden hoes, rakes, sickles, baggies,
               tobacco pipes, and cigarette-rolling papers.
               C.   Items listed in this subsection which are used for decorative purposes, when
               such items have been rendered completely inoperable or incapable of being used
               for any illicit purpose prohibited by the Drug Paraphernalia Control Act and this
               subsection.
               D.   A person who is legally authorized to possess hypodermic syringes or needles
               under the Hypodermic Syringes and Needles Act
               In determining whether or not a particular item is exempt from the definition of
               "drug paraphernalia," the trier of fact should consider, in addition to all other
               logically relevant factors, the following:
               A.   The general, usual, customary, and historical use to which the item involved
               has been put;
               B.   Expert evidence concerning the ordinary or customary use of the item and the
               effect of any peculiarity in the design or engineering of the device upon its
               functioning;
               C.   Any written instructions accompanying the delivery of the item concerning
               the purposes or uses to which the item can or may be put;
               D.   Any oral instructions provided by the seller of the item at the time and
               place of sale or commercial delivery;
               E.   Any national or local advertising concerning the design, purpose or use of
               the item involved, and the entire context in which such advertising occurs;
               F.   The manner, place and circumstances in which the item was displayed for
               sale, as well as any item or displayed for sale or otherwise exhibited upon the
               premises where the sale was made;
               G.   Whether the owner or anyone in control of the object is a legitimate
               supplier of like or related items to the community, such as a licensed
               distributor or dealer of cannabis or tobacco products;
               H.   The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the community.
               The production, preparation, propagation, compounding, conversion or processing
               of controlled substances, either directly or indirectly, by extraction from
               substances of natural origin, or independently by means of chemical synthesis, or
MANUFACTURER:  by a combination of extraction and chemical synthesis, and includes any packaging
               or repackaging of controlled substances or labeling of its container; except,
               that "manufacturer" does not include the preparation, compounding, packaging or
               labeling of controlled substances as an incident to lawful research, teaching or
               chemical analysis and not for sale.
PERSON:        Any individual, corporation, government or governmental subdivision or agency,
               business trust, estate, trust, partnership or association, or any other entity.
PRODUCE OR     Planting, cultivating, tending or harvesting.

9-21-2: PERSONAL USE OF CANNABIS:
   (A)   Except as otherwise provided in the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act
(the "Act"), the following acts are prohibited in the Village:
      1.   Possession, consumption, use, purchase, obtaining, or transporting
an amount of cannabis for personal use that exceeds the possession limit under
Section 10-10 of the Act or otherwise not in accordance with the requirements
of the Act;
      2.   Cultivation of cannabis for personal use not in accordance with the
requirements of the Act; and
      3.   Controlling property if actions that are authorized by the Act occur
on the property not in accordance with the Act
   (B)   Except as otherwise provided in the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act,
it is unlawful for any person knowingly to possess cannabis.
   (C)   Except as otherwise provided in the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act,
it is unlawful for any person knowingly to manufacture, deliver, or possess
with intent to deliver or manufacture cannabis. (Ord. 20-1630, 4-2-2020)
9-21-3: PERSONAL USE OF CANNABIS; RESTRICTIONS ON CULTIVATION; PENALTIES:
   (A)   Any person other than a registered qualifying patient under the
Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Program Act who cultivates cannabis
plants is liable for penalties provided by this chapter.
   (B)   Any registered qualifying patient under the Compassionate Use of
Medical Cannabis Program Act who:
      1.   Cultivates cannabis plants in violation of Section 10-5 of the
Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act;
      2.   Cultivates more than the allowable number of cannabis plants; or
      3.   Sells or gives away cannabis plants, cannabis, or cannabis-infused
products produced under Section 10-5 of the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, is
liable for penalties as provided by this chapter. (Ord. 20-1630, 4-2-2020)
9-21-4: PERSONS UNDER 21 YEARS OF AGE:
   (A)   The transfer of cannabis, with or without remuneration, to a person
under twenty-one (21) years of age, or allowing a person under twenty-one (21)
years of age to purchase, possess, use, process, transport, grow, or consume
cannabis except where authorized by the Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis
Program Act or by the Community College Cannabis Vocational Program is
prohibited.
   (B)   It is unlawful for any person under twenty-one (21) years of age to
knowingly possess cannabis or cannabis paraphernalia, except under provisions
of law authorizing the possession of medical cannabis.
   (C)   It is unlawful for any parent or guardian to knowingly permit his or
her residence, any other private property under his or her control, or any
vehicle, conveyance, or watercraft under his or her control to be used by an
invitee of the parent's child or the guardian's ward, if the invitee is under
the age of twenty-one (21), in a manner that constitutes a violation of this
Section. A parent or guardian is deemed to have knowingly permitted his or her
residence, any other private property under his or her control, or any vehicle,
conveyance, or watercraft under his or her control to be used in violation of
this Section if he or she knowingly authorizes or permits consumption of
cannabis by underage invitees. In this subsection, where the residence or other
property has an owner and a tenant or lessee, the trier of fact may infer that
the residence or other property is occupied only by the tenant or lessee. (Ord.
20-1630, 4-2-2020)
9-21-5: IDENTIFICATION AND FALSE IDENTIFICATION:
   (A)   A person who is under twenty-one (21) years of age may not present or
offer to a cannabis business establishment or the cannabis business
establishment's principal or employee any written or oral evidence of age that
is false, fraudulent, or not actually the person's own, for the purpose of:
      1.   Purchasing, attempting to purchase, or otherwise obtaining or
attempting to obtain cannabis or any cannabis product; or
      2.   Gaining access to a cannabis business establishment
   (B)   An agent or employee of a cannabis business establishment must demand
and be shown adequate written evidence of age and identity of a person before
furnishing cannabis or cannabis products to the person.
   (C)   An agent or employee of a cannabis business establishment cannot
knowingly accept false or fraudulent written evidence of age and identity of a
person before furnishing cannabis or cannabis products to the person.
   (D)   Adequate written evidence of age and identity of the person is a
document showing a person is twenty-one (21) years of age or older, issued by a
Federal, state, county, or municipal government, or subdivision or agency
thereof including, but not limited to, a motor vehicle operator's license, a
registration certificate issued under the Military Selective Service Act, or an
identification card issued to a member of the Armed Forces.
   (E)   Proof that the cannabis business establishment or its employee or
agent was shown and reasonably relied upon such written evidence in any
transaction forbidden by this section is an affirmative defense in any
prosecution under this section. (Ord. 20-1630, 4-2-2020)
9-21-6: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
   (A)   No person may engage in the following conduct
      1.   Possessing cannabis:
         (a)   In a school bus, unless permitted for a qualifying patient or
caregiver pursuant to the Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Program Act;
         (b)   On the grounds of any preschool or primary or secondary school,
unless permitted for a qualifying patient or caregiver pursuant to the
Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Program Act;
         (c)   In any correctional facility;
         (d)   In a vehicle not open to the public unless the cannabis is in a
reasonably secured, sealed container and reasonably inaccessible while the
vehicle is moving; or
         (e)   In a private residence that is used at any time to provide
licensed child care or other similar social service care on the premises;
      2.   Using cannabis:
         (a)   In a school bus, unless permitted for a qualifying patient or
caregiver pursuant to the Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Program Act;
         (b)   On the grounds of any preschool or primary or secondary school,
unless permitted for a qualifying patient or caregiver pursuant to the
Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Program Act;
         (c)   In any correctional fecility;
         (d)   In any motor vehicle;
         (e)   In a private residence that is used at any time to provide
licensed child care or other similar social service care on the premises;
         (f)   In any public place; or
         (g)   Knowingly in close physical proximity to anyone under twenty-one
(21) years of age who is not a registered medical cannabis patient under the
Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Program Act;
      3.   Smoking cannabis in any place where smoking is prohibited under the
Smoke Free Illinois Act;
      4.   Operating, navigating, or being in actual physical control of any
motor vehicle, aircraft, watercraft, or snowmobile while using or under the
influence of cannabis in violation of Section 11-501 or 11-502.1 of the
Illinois Vehicle Code, Section 5-16 of the Boat Registration and Safety Act, or
Section 5-7 of the Snowmobile Registration and Safety Act;
      5.   Facilitating the use of cannabis by any person who is not allowed to
use cannabis under this Act or the Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis
Program Act;
      6.   Transferring cannabis to any person contrary to the Act or the
Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Program Act;
      7.   The use of cannabis by a law enforcement officer, corrections
officer, probation officer, or firefighter while on duty; or
      8.   The use of cannabis by a person who has a school bus permit or a
Commercial Driver's License while on duty.
As used in this Section, "public place" means any place where a person could
reasonably be expected to be observed by others. "Public place" includes all
parts of buildings owned in whole or in part, or leased, by the State or a unit
of local government. "Public place" includes all areas in a park, recreation
area, wildlife area, or playground owned in whole or in part, leased, or
managed by the State or a unit of local government "Public place" does not
include a private residence unless the private residence is used to provide
licensed child care, foster care, or other similar social service care on the
premises. (Ord. 20-1630, 4-2-2020)
9-21-7: CANNABIS WASTE:
   (A)   Any recyclable waste generated by a cultivator for personal use,
cannabis cultivation facility, craft grower facility, or infuser must be
recycled per applicable state and local laws, ordinances, and rules.
   (B)   Any cultivator for personal use, cannabis cultivation facility, craft
grower facility, or infuser must store, secure, and manage all recyclables and
waste, including organic waste composed of or containing finished cannabis and
cannabis products, in accordance with applicable State and local laws,
ordinances, and rules.
   (C)   Cannabis and cannabis-infused product waste must be destroyed by
rendering it unusable following the methods set forth in this Section or state
law. The allowable method to render cannabis waste unusable is by grinding and
incorporating the cannabis waste with other ground materials so the resulting
mixture is at least 50% non-cannabis waste by volume. Material used to grind
with the cannabis falls into two categories, compostable waste and non-
compostable waste.
      1.   Compostable Mixed Waste: Cannabis waste to be disposed as compost
feedstock or in another organic waste method (for example, anaerobic digester)
may be mixed with the following types of waste materials:
         (a)   Food waste;
         (b)   Yard waste; or
         (c)   Other approved wastes (e.g., agricultural material,
biodegradable products and paper, clean wood, fruits and vegetables, plant
matter).
      2.   Non-compostable Mixed Waste: Cannabis waste to be disposed in a
landfill or by another disposal method may be mixed with the following types of
waste materials:
         (a)   Paper waste;
         (b)   Cardboard waste;
         (c)   Plastic waste;
         (d)   Soil; or
         (e)   Other approved wastes (e.g., non-recyclable plastic, broken
glass, leather).
   (D)   Cannabis waste rendered unusable following the methods described in
this Section can be disposed. Disposal of the cannabis waste rendered unusable
may be delivered to a permitted solid waste facility for final disposition.
Examples of acceptable permitted solid waste facilities include:
      1.   Compostable Mixed Waste: Compost, anaerobic digester or other
facility with approval of the jurisdictional health department.
      2.   Non-compostable Mixed Waste: Landfill, incinerator or other facility
with approval of the jurisdictional health department. (Ord. 20-1630, 4-2-2020)
9-21-8: POSSESSION OF ADULT USE CANNABIS IN A MOTOR VEHICLE:
   (A)   No driver may use cannabis within the passenger area of any motor
vehicle upon a highway in the Village.
   (B)   No driver may possess cannabis within any area of any motor vehicle
upon a highway in this State except in a sealed, odor-proof, child-resistant
cannabis container.
   (C)   No passenger may possess cannabis within any passenger area of any
motor vehicle upon a highway in mis State except in a sealed, odor-proof,
child-resistant cannabis container. (Ord. 20-1630, 4-2-2020)
9-21-9: PREEMPTION:
   (A)   This Chapter should not be construed to regulate or license the
activities described in the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, except as
otherwise provided in the Act.
   (B)   This chapter should not be construed to regulate the activities
described in paragraphs (1), (2), or (3) of section 55-25 of the Cannabis
Regulation and Tax Act in a manner more restrictive than the regulation of
those activities by the State under the Act.
   (C)   In the event of a conflict between this Chapter and the Act and its
administrative rules, the Act and its rules will prevail. (Ord. 20-1630, 4-2-
2020)
9-21-10: SCHEDULE OF FINES; PENALTIES:
Proceedings shall be instituted against the violator on the Village's
administrative adjudications pursuant to the terms set forth in Title 1,
Chapter 21 of this code.
The fines and penalties for any person who violates any of the terms of this
Chapter shall be imposed as follows:

9-21-11: DRUG PARAPHERNALIA:
   (A)   Unlawful Use or Possession of Drug Paraphernalia. A person who
knowingly possesses an item of drug paraphernalia with the intent to use it in
ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing a controlled substance into the
human body, or in preparing a controlled substance for that use, is liable for
the penalties provided by this Section.
   (B)   Advertising Drug Paraphernalia. It is unlawful for any person to place
in any newspaper, magazine, handbill or other publication any advertisement
knowing, or under circumstances where one reasonably should know, that the
purpose of the advertisement, in whole or in part, is to promote the sale of
objects designed or intended for use as drug paraphernalia.
   (C)   Sale of Delivery of a Synthetic Alternative Drug. It is unlawful for
any person to sell, offer tor sale, publicly display for sale or attempt to
sell, give, deliver, or barter any product containing a synthetic alternative
drug.
   (D)   Possession of a Synthetic Alternative Drug. It is unlawful for any
person to knowingly possess or deliver a product containing a synthetic
alternative drug with the intent of using the product for ingestion,
consumption, inhaling, or intravenous use. In determining intent under this
section, a trier of fact may take into consideration, among other things: the
proximity of the product to drug paraphernalia; the presence of the product on
or within drug paraphernalia; the proximity of the product to a different
controlled substance; and whether or not the individual in possession of the
product is exhibiting physical effects commonly associated with being under the
influence of a controlled substance.
   (E)   Use of a Synthetic Alternative Drug. It is unlawful for any person to
be under the influence of a product containing a synthetic alternative drug.
   (F)   Manufacture of Synthetic Alternative Drug. It shall be unlawful for
any person to manufacture or assemble the ingredients with the intent to
manufacture, a product containing a synthetic alternative drug. In determining
intent under this section, a trier of fact may take into consideration, among
other tilings: the proximity of the product or ingredients to drug
paraphernalia; the presence of the product or ingredients on or within drug
paraphernalia; the proximity of the product or ingredients to a different
controlled substance.
   (G)   Penalties. Except as authorized by law, it shall be a violation of
this chapter for any person knowingly to possess any drug paraphernalia with
the intent to use it to ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce cannabis and/or a
controlled substance as defined by Illinois Iowa into the human body. Any
person found to be guilty of violating this section shall be fined not less
than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense. Each day any violation of any provision of this
section shall occur or continues to occur shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 20-1630, 4-2-2020)
CHAPTER 22
TRUANCY
SECTION:
9-22-1: Definitions
9-22-2: Prohibition Of Chronic Truancy
9-22-3: Supportive Services
9-22-4: Parental Responsibility
9-22-5: Excused Absences
9-22-6: Administrative Adjudication
9-22-1: DEFINITIONS:
That the following words shall have the following meanings and/or definition:
CHRONIC TRUANCY: Any chronic truant minor who has been absent on more than one
occasion during a school year without cause or acceptable excuse.
CHRONIC TRUANT MINOR: A truant minor to whom supportive services, including
prevention, diagnostic, intervention and remedial services, alternative
programs and other school and community resources, have been provided and have
failed to result in the cessation of habitual or ongoing truant behavior, or
have been offered and refused.
MINOR: A child who is seventeen (17) years of age or younger.
SCHOOL: Either a public or private educational institution fully accredited or
certified by the Illinois Department of Education.
TRUANT MINOR: A minor in any school accredited or certified by the Illinois
Department of Education, located within the Village, who is absent without
cause or an acceptable excuse from such attendance for a school day or portion
thereof. (Ord. 16-1510, 7-7-2016)
9-22-2: PROHIBITION OF CHRONIC TRUANCY:
It shall be unlawful for a minor enrolled in any school in Bedford Park and
subject to compulsory attendance requirements of the Illinois School Code to
engage in chronic truancy. A chronic truant minor child shall be identified to
the Bedford Park Police Department by the minor's school, along with any and
all information, as permitted by law, detailing absences from school. (Ord. 16-
1510, 7-7-2016)
9-22-3: SUPPORTIVE SERVICES:
Prior to a minor being cited under this chapter for chronic truancy, the school
must have provided supportive services, including prevention diagnostic,
intervention and remedial services, alternative programs and other school and
community resources that have failed to result in the cessation of habitual or
ongoing truant behavior, or have been offered to the student and refused. (Ord.
16-1510, 7-7-2016)
9-22-4: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
It shall be unlawful for any parent, guardian, or person having custody or
control of a minor enrolled in any school located in the Village to cause,
permit or encourage a minor to become a chronic truant minor or engage in
chronic truancy. (Ord. 16-1510, 7-7-2016)
9-22-5: EXCUSED ABSENCES:
If a parent, guardian or person having legal custody and control over a minor
presents in writing to school officials within twenty four (24) hours after an
occurrence or such other deadline as established by the school, any of the
following reasons for an absence, there is a rebuttable presumption that it is
a legitimate and acceptable excuse:
   (A)   Illness (if illness persists more than 5 days, a doctor's report will
be required detailing the nature of the illness and the projected return date
of the student);
   (B)   Observance of a religious holiday;
   (C)   Death in the family;
   (D)   Family emergency;
   (E)   Any situation beyond the control of the minor as determined by the
student's school officials; or
   (F)   Such other circumstances which cause reasonable concern to the parent
for the safety or health of the minor. (Ord. 16-1510, 7-7-2016)
9-22-6: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION:
A citation issued for any violation herein may be processed through the
administrative process as provided in this Code. (Ord. 16-1510, 7-7-2016)

10-12-26: Boats And Related Vehicles
10-12-1: PARKING PROHIBITED IN SPECIFIED PLACES:
   (A)   Parking Prohibited: No person shall park a vehicle, except when
necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the
directions of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the
following places:
      1.   On a sidewalk;
      2.   In front of a public or private driveway;
      3.   Within an intersection;
      4.   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant;
      5.   On a crosswalk;
      6.   Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection;
      7.   Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing beacon,
stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway in the
industrial, retail and/or commercial sections of the village; and
Within six feet (6') upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign or
traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway in the residential
section of the village;
      8.   On the medial strip of a highway;
      9.   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad grade
crossing;
      10.   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire
station and on the side of street opposite the entrance to any fire station
within seventy five feet (75') of said entrance when properly posted;
      11.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
such parking would obstruct traffic;
      12.   On the roadway side of any vehicle parked at the edge or curb of a
street;
      13.   Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or
within a highway tunnel;
      14.   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
   (B)   Moving Parked Vehicles: No person other than a police officer, as
provided in section
10-12-2 of this chapter, shall move a vehicle into any such prohibited area or
away from a curb such distance as is unlawful or start or cause to be started
the motor of any other vehicle, or shift, change, or move the levers, brake,
starting device, gears, or other mechanism of a parked motor vehicle to a
position other than that in which it was left by the owner or driver thereof,
or attempt to do so.
   (C)   Parking Restrictions On Residential Streets: The following parking
restrictions shall apply to residential streets:
      1.   Statute Reference: All words and phrases used in this section shall,
for the purpose of this section, have the meanings respectively ascribed to
them in the Illinois vehicle code 1 ;
      2.   Restrictions: No automobile, bus (commuter van), motor home, mini-
motor home or van, camper, recreational vehicle, school bus, truck, truck
camper, or other motor vehicle of the second division as defined in the
Illinois vehicle code 2  shall be parked on any residential street between the
hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M., unless the
following conditions are complied with:
         (a)   The vehicle is registered to a resident within the village, or
the vehicle meets all of the Village vehicle license requirements set forth in
section 5-8-2 of the Village code.
         (b)   The vehicle is less than eight thousand (8,000) pounds in total
weight and as defined by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-815(a), this will
include any B license plate vehicles weighing eight thousand (8,000) pounds or
less under the foregoing provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-815
(a); said weight must be certified by the Bedford Park police department after
being weighed on a certified scale.
         (c)   The vehicle is less than eight thousand (8,000) pounds, licensed
pursuant to the lowest class of recreational type vehicles pursuant to 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-815(b), and certified as having a total weight
of less than eight thousand (8,000) pounds as certified by the Bedford Park
police department after being weighed on a certified scale;
         (d)   The appropriate vehicle registration tag is purchased from the
village and is displayed on the lower right hand side of the front windshield
of the vehicle.
         (e)   The public works department, when authorized by the president
and board of trustees, shall cause signs to be posted in all areas where
parking is limited or prohibited, indicating such limitation or prohibition;
      3.   Penalty: Any person who is found to be in violation of this
subsection (C) shall be fined not less than thirty dollars ($30.00) nor more
than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per offense.
   (D)   Parking Restrictions For Commercial Vehicles: The following parking
restrictions shall apply to residential streets:
      1.   Commercial Motor Vehicles: "Commercial motor vehicles" are vehicles
which are used primarily for business and industrial purposes which shall
include, but are not limited to, vehicles displaying commercial printing, logos
or lettering.
      2.   Prohibited Parking: It shall be unlawful for any person to park any
commercial vehicle of any kind, or bus, between the hours of six o'clock (6:00)
P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on public streets or roads within the
residential district of the municipality, provided that it shall not be a
violation of this subsection (D) to park any such vehicle for the purpose of
performing emergency repair or maintenance work on any public utility facility,
sewer mains and the appurtenances thereto, water mains and the appurtenances
thereto, or on any private property requiring such emergency repair or
maintenance work, or for the purpose of saving life, limb or property,
including responding to a service call, or for fighting fire.
      3.   Penalty: Any person who is found to be in violation of this
subsection (D) shall be fined not less than thirty dollars ($30.00), nor more
than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per offense.
      4.   Exemption: Residents of the village who drive a commercial vehicle
to and from work on a regular basis can be issued a village vehicle license and
be allowed to park on village streets overnight if they meet all other village
vehicle license requirements (License Application
5-8-2). This exception only applies to passenger cars, sport utility vehicles
(SUV), vans, or pick-up trucks. Trucks requiring a registration plate greater
than a Class B Illinois registration (greater than 8,000 pounds), are not
eligible for this exemption. All signs, decals, lettering, logos, and placards
displaying the company's name shall be removed from the vehicle when parking
the vehicle overnight on village streets or the vehicle will be in violation of
this section.
   (E)   Fees And Penalties: The following fees and penalties shall apply for
registration or violation of this section:
      1.   The fee for the vehicle registration tag referred to in subsection
(C)2(d) of this section is five dollars ($5.00) per annum.
      2.   There shall be no fee for issuance of a special parking permit.
      3.   For each violation the registered owner shall be fined not less than
thirty dollars ($30.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each
day of violation.
   (F)   Fire Lanes:
      1.   Parking Of Motor Vehicles In Fire Lanes: The operator of a vehicle
shall not at any time park such vehicle or otherwise obstruct any designated
fire lane located within the village.
      2.   Enforcement: The police department shall enforce this section
through the issuance of citations and/or towing of vehicles that are in
violation of this section.
      3.   Penalties: Any person violating this section may be fined not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and
shall be subject to said vehicle being towed from the fire lane. (Ord. 559, 9-
5-1968; amd. Ord. 728, 5-5-1983; Ord. 91-857, 10-17-1991; Ord. 92-880, 11-5-
1992; Ord. 95-963, 10-20-1995; Ord. 95-964, 10-20-1995; Ord. 00-1070, 11-17-
2000; Ord. 00-1076, 12-13-2000; Ord. 09-1315, 12-17-2009; Ord. 11-1348, 1-20-
2011; Ord. 20-1624, 3-2-2020; Ord. 20-1626, 3-2-2020)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.
2 2. 625 ILCS 5/1-146, 5/1-217.
10-12-2: OFFICERS AUTHORIZED TO REMOVE ILLEGALLY STOPPED VEHICLES:
   (A)   Whenever any police officer finds a vehicle standing upon a highway in
violation of any of the foregoing provisions of this chapter, such officer is
hereby authorized to move such vehicle, or require the driver or other person
in charge of the vehicle to move the same, to a position off the paved or
improved or main traveled part of such highway.
   (B)   Whenever any police officer finds a vehicle unattended upon any bridge
or causeway where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic, such
officer is hereby authorized to provide for the removal of such vehicle to the
nearest garage or other place of safety.
   (C)   Whenever any police officer finds an abandoned or disabled vehicle
standing upon the paved or main traveled part of a highway, which vehicle is or
may be expected to interrupt the free flow of traffic on said highway or
interference with the maintenance of said highway, the police officer shall
have authority to move the vehicle to a position off the paved or improved or
main traveled part of such highway. (Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
10-12-3: IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES:
The police department and all members thereof are hereby authorized to remove
and tow away or have removed and towed away by commercial towing service, any
car or other vehicle illegally parked in any place where such parked vehicle
creates or constitutes a traffic hazard, blocks the use of a fire hydrant, or
obstructs or may obstruct the movement of any emergency vehicle. (Ord. 599, 9-
5-1968)
10-12-4: STREET CLEANING; PARKING PROHIBITION:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any public street or portion
thereof in the village at any time when such street is being cleaned. Signs
indicating that a street or portion thereof is being cleaned shall be posted
before the cleaning of the street, and shall be removed after the cleaning of
the street is finished. (Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
The minimum penalty for a violation of this section shall be thirty dollars
($30.00). (Ord. 09-1315, 12-17-2009)
10-12-5: ONE HOUR TIME LIMIT:
Except on Sundays or holidays, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle for
more than one hour in any consecutive period of time between the hours of eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M., in any area designated by
provisions of this code as restricted parking area. (Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
The minimum penalty for a violation of this section shall be thirty dollars
($30.00). (Ord. 09-1315, 12-17-2009)
10-12-6: VEHICLES FOR SALE; VEHICLE MERCHANDISING:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of
displaying it for sale on a commercial basis, or to park any vehicle upon any
street, from which merchandise is peddled or sold. (Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
The minimum penalty for a violation of this section shall be thirty dollars
($30.00). (Ord. 09-1315, 12-17-2009)
10-12-7: ALLEYS:
   (A)   No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or
under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet (10') of the
width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person
shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to
block the driveway entrance to any abutting property.
   (B)   No unattended vehicle which obstructs traffic shall be parked in the
alleys in the residential areas of the village. (Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
   (C)   The minimum penalty for a violation of this section shall be thirty
dollars ($30.00). (Ord. 09-1315, 12-17-2009)
10-12-8: CAB AND BUS STAND USE EXCLUSIVE:
No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in any area designated
by provisions of this code as a cab stand; and no vehicle other than a bus
shall be parked in a place so designated as a bus loading zone. (Ord. 599, 9-5-
1968)
10-12-9: PARKING MOTOR VEHICLES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any private property without
the consent of the owner of the property. Cars so parked shall be ordered towed
away on order of any police officer and shall be stored on any village property
or in a public garage or parking lot and shall be restored to the owner or
operator thereof after payment of the expense incurred by the village in
removing and storing such vehicles. (Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
10-12-10: SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS TO DESIGNATE CURB LOADING ZONES:
The superintendent of public works is hereby authorized to determine the
location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and
maintain appropriate signs indicating the same and stating the hours during
which the provisions of this chapter are applicable. (Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
10-12-11: PERMITS FOR CURB LOADING ZONES:
The superintendent of public works shall not hereafter designate or sign any
curb loading zone upon special request of any person unless such person makes
application for a permit for such zone and for two (2) signs to indicate the
ends of each such zones. The superintendent of public works upon granting a
permit and issuing such signs shall collect from the applicant and deposit in
the village treasury a service fee covering all costs incurred by reason
thereof and may by general regulations impose conditions upon the use of such
signs and for reimbursement of the village for the value thereof in the event
of their loss or damage and their return in the event of misuse or upon
expiration of permit. Every such permit shall expire at the end of one year.
(Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
10-12-12: STANDING IN PASSENGER CURB LOADING ZONE:
No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of
time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any
place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations
applicable to such curb loading zone are effective, and then only for a period
not to exceed three (3) minutes. (Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
10-12-13: STANDING IN FREIGHT CURB LOADING ZONE:
No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of
time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pick up and
loading of materials in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during
the hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. In no
case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed thirty (30)
minutes. (Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
10-12-14: SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS TO DESIGNATE PUBLIC CARRIER STOPS AND
STANDS:
The superintendent of public works is hereby authorized and required to
establish taxicab stands and stands for the other passenger carrying motor
vehicles on such public streets in such places and in such number as he shall
determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and
every such taxicab stand or other stand shall be designated by appropriate
signs. (Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
10-12-15: STOPPING, STANDING, PARKING OF BUSES, TAXICABS REGULATED:
   (A)   The operator of a bus shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any
street at any place other than an authorized bus stop.
   (B)   The operator of a bus shall not stop such vehicle upon any street at
any place for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or their baggage
other than at an authorized bus stop, except in case of an emergency.
   (C)   The operator of a bus shall enter a bus stop in such a manner that the
bus when stopped to load or unload passengers or baggage shall be in a position
with the right front wheel of such vehicle not further than eighteen inches
(18") from the curb and the bus approximately parallel to the curb so as not to
unduly impede the movement of other vehicular traffic.
   (D)   The operator of a taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle upon
any street at any place other than in a taxicab stand so designated as provided
herein. This provision shall not prevent the operator of a taxicab from
temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations
at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the expeditious
loading or unloading of passengers. (Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
   (E)   The minimum penalty for a violation of this section shall be thirty
dollars ($30.00). (Ord. 09-1315, 12-17-2009)
10-12-16: RESTRICTED USE OF BUS AND TAXICAB STANDS:
No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop,
or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been
officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a
passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while
actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not
interfere with any bus, or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such
zone. (Ord. 599, 9-5-1968)
10-12-17: PARKING PROHIBITED AT ALL TIMES ON CERTAIN STREETS; EXCEPTIONS:
   (A)   There shall be no parking on any street in the area bounded by Cicero
Avenue on the east, Harlem Avenue on the west, 65th Street on the north and
77th Street on the south, except that thirty (30) minute parking shall be
permitted for vehicles of the second division on the following streets:
Austin Avenue from 65th Street to 66th Place on the east side of the street
only.
Laramie Avenue from 65th Street to 66th Place on the east side of the street
only.
Melvina Avenue from 65th Street to 66th Place on the east side of the street
only.
Menard Avenue from 65th Street to 66th Street on the east side of the street
only.
Natchez Avenue in the 6500 block on the west side of the street only.
Oak Park Avenue from 65th Street to 66th Place on the east side of the street
only.
Old Harlem Avenue from 65th Street to 66th Place on the west side of the street
only.
Parking shall be permitted for vehicles of the second division on the west side
of New England Avenue, between 65th Street and 66th Street, between the hours
of eight thirty o'clock (8:30) A.M. and three thirty o'clock (3:30) P.M. (Ord.
579, 1970)
   (B)   In the area bounded by 65th Street on the north, 67th Place on the
south, 76th Avenue on the east, and Archer Avenue on west, parking shall be
prohibited on those streets described in schedule II, section
10-16-2 of this title.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any semitrailer, or other freight carrying
device, or garbage or trash containers to be parked or dropped on any street in
the village.
   (D)   No vehicle shall be so parked on any street where parking is permitted
as to block or obstruct any loading dock area of any person or other business
establishment. (Ord. 559, 9-5-1968)
   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked a
motor vehicle on Cicero Avenue from 65th Street to 67th Street. (Ord. 722, 9-
16-1982)
Any person, company, partnership, or other entity violating subsection (A),
(B), (D) or (E) of this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per offense.
Any person, company, partnership, or other entity violating subsection (C) of
this section shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per offense.
A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each and every day during
which a violation continues or exists. (Ord. 03-1138, 4-17-2003)
   (F)   Nonresidential parking along 65th Place and 66th Place:
      1.   Unlawful Parking On 65th Place: It shall be unlawful for any
nonresident of the village to park his or her vehicle, either attended or
unattended, along 65th Place from the Archer Avenue alley up to and including
78th Avenue, unless said nonresident has been issued a guest parking permit.
      2.   Guest Parking Permit For 65th Place: Each residential household
located along 65th Place from the Archer Avenue alley up to and including 78th
Avenue shall receive four (4) guest parking permits to be issued only to the
guests of the residents. The resident shall be the holder of and responsible
for the use and misuse of the guest parking permit.
      3.   Unlawful Parking On 66th Place: It shall be unlawful for any
nonresident of the village to park his or her vehicle, either attended or
unattended, along 66th Place, unless said nonresident has been issued a guest
parking permit.
      4.   Guest Parking Permit For 66th Place: Each residential household
located on 66th Place shall receive four (4) guest parking permits to be issued
only to guests of the residents. The resident shall be the holder of and
responsible for the use and misuse of the guest parking permit.
      5.   Limitations On Authority Of Permit: A guest parking permit shall not
authorize the standing or parking of any vehicle in such places and during such
times as the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles is prohibited and shall
not excuse the observance of any traffic regulations other than the parking
limit enforced along the aforesaid streets.
      6.   Penalties: Any person convicted of violation of this subsection
shall be guilty of an offense against the village and shall be fined not less
than thirty dollars ($30.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
      7.   Posting Of Signs: The public works department or any other person
authorized by the president and board of trustees shall cause signs to be
posted along 65th Place and 66th Place indicating that parking for nonresidents
is prohibited subject to the terms of this subsection. (Ord. 90-822, 7-19-1990)
10-12-18: STARTING PARKED VEHICLE:
No person shall start a vehicle which is stopped, standing or parked unless and
until such movement can be made with reasonable safety. (Ord. 559, 9-5-1968)
10-12-19: WHEN COPY OF CITATION SHALL BE DEEMED A LAWFUL COMPLAINT:
In the event the form of citation includes information and is sworn to as
required under the general laws of this state in respect to a complaint
charging commission of the offense alleged in said citation to have been
committed, then such citation when filed with a court having jurisdiction shall
be deemed to be a lawful complaint for the purpose of prosecution under this
chapter. (Ord. 559, 9-5-1968)
10-12-20: CITATION ON ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLE:
Whenever any motor vehicle without driver is found parked or stopped in
violation of any of the restrictions imposed by provisions of this code or by
state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number
and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify
its user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a citation, on a form
provided by the village, for the driver to answer to the charge against him
within ten (10) days during the hours and at a place specified in the citation.
(Ord. 559, 9-5-1968)
10-12-21: PRESUMPTION IN REFERENCE TO ILLEGAL PARKING:
   (A)   In any prosecution charging a violation of any law or regulation
governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular
vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such law or
regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was
at the time of such parking the registered owner of such vehicle, shall
constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of
the vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point, and
for the time during which, such violation occurred.
   (B)   The foregoing stated presumption shall apply only when the procedure
as prescribed in section
10-12-19 of this chapter has been followed. (Ord. 559, 9-5-1968)
10-12-22: WHEN WARRANT TO BE ISSUED:
In the event any person fails to comply with a citation given to such person or
attached to a vehicle or fails to make appearance pursuant to a summons
directing an appearance in court, or if any person fails or refuses to deposit
bail as required and within the time permitted by provisions of this code, the
police officer who observed the offense shall secure and issue a warrant for
his arrest. (Ord. 559, 9-5-1968)
10-12-23: PARKING DURING AND AFTER SNOWFALL:
   (A)   Parking Restricted: It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on a
public street within the residential section of the village between the hours
of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to twelve o'clock (12:00) noon after a snowfall of
two (2) or more inches, unless the snow has been plowed or otherwise removed
from the street. Further, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any
public street in any other section of the village at any time after a snowfall
of two (2) or more inches, unless the snow has been plowed or otherwise
removed. Signs reflecting these restrictions shall be installed in areas so
designated by the village of Bedford Park public works supervisor. (Ord. 09-
1289, 1-20-2009)
   (B)   Removal Of Illegally Parked Vehicle: In order to help assure that all
streets can be adequately plowed during and after snowfalls of two inches (2")
or more, the chief of police is hereby authorized to have removed from any
village street any vehicle which obstructs the operation of snow removal
equipment and the owner or operator shall pay the reasonable cost of removal of
said vehicle.
   (C)   Clearing Snow From Private Land: It shall be unlawful to clear snow
from any private land, lot or roadway and deposit the snow on any public
street, alley or sidewalk in the village.
   (D)   Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section
shall be fined not less than fifteen dollars ($15.00) nor more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) for each offense. (Ord. 690, 10-18-1979)
10-12-24: PARKING FEES:
(Rep. by Ord. 95-966, 10-20-1995)
10-12-25: MANNER OF PARKING; PARKING IN AREAS RESERVED FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS:
   (A)   Manner Of Parking: No person shall park a motor vehicle in any
designated parking space in such a manner that such motor vehicle protrudes
over and into any other parking space immediately contiguous to it so as to
prevent the use of the latter space by another motor vehicle.
   (B)   Handicapped Parking: No person shall park a motor vehicle in a parking
space which is designated and marked for the use of handicapped persons only,
unless such vehicle is operated by a handicapped person.
   (C)   Restricted Areas: No person shall park a motor vehicle in any area
within the foregoing parking lot in which parking is prohibited. A restricted
area shall be plainly marked with no parking signs in such a manner as to be
clearly seen by the public.
   (D)   Enforcement By The Police Department: The police department shall
enforce this section through the issuance of citations and the towing of
vehicles that are in violation of any of the provisions of this section. (Ord.
87-788, 11-5-1987, eff. 1-1-1988)
   (E)   Penalties: The minimum penalty for a violation of this section shall
be thirty dollars ($30.00). (Ord. 09-1315, 12-17-2009)
10-12-26: BOATS AND RELATED VEHICLES:
   (A)   Definitions:
MOTORBOAT: Any vessel propelled by machinery which is the principal source of
propulsion.
OWNER: A person, other than a lienholder, having title to a vessel, motorboat
or sailboat.
SAILBOAT: Any watercraft propelled by sail or canvas.
VESSEL: Every description of a watercraft used or capable of being used as a
means of transportation on water and/or which may be mounted upon wheels and
capable of being transported from place to place.
   (B)   Parking Of Vessels, Motorboats And Watercraft On Village Streets: It
shall be expressly prohibited to park, maintain, store or repair any vessel,
motorboat and/or watercraft on any street or alley within the village.
   (C)   Parking Of Vessels, Motorboats And Watercraft On Residential Property:
It shall be unlawful to park, maintain, store or repair any vessel, motorboat
and/or watercraft on a residential lot unless it is securely parked on a
surface to be located in the rear section of the lot with the entire surface
thereof being graded and covered with either blacktopping or concrete.
Furthermore, the owner of said vessel, motorboat and/or watercraft must be a
resident of the village.
   (D)   Penalties: Any person who is found to be in violation of any provision
of this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. (Ord. 91-856, 10-17-1991,
eff. 5-1-1992)
CHAPTER 13
(Rep. by Ord. 742, 6-21-1984)

CHAPTER 15
FINES AND FORFEITURES
SECTION:
10-15-1: Police Officers To Enforce Title

10-15-1: POLICE OFFICERS TO ENFORCE TITLE:
The village police shall patrol the highways and make arrests for violation of
the provisions of this title. (Ord. 559, 9-5-1968)
10-15-2: PENALTIES FOR MISDEMEANOR:
   (A)   It is a misdemeanor for any person to violate any of the provisions of
this title.
   (B)   Every person convicted of a misdemeanor for a violation of any of the
provisions of this title for which another penalty is not provided shall for
the first conviction thereof be punished by a fine of not less than five
dollars ($5.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00); for a second such
conviction within one year thereafter such person shall be punished by a fine
of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than two hundred dollars
($200.00); upon a third or subsequent conviction within one year after the
first conviction, such person shall be punished by a fine of not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than three hundred dollars ($300.00). (Ord.
559, 9-5-1968)
10-15-3: DISPOSITION OF FINES AND FORFEITURES:
   (A)   All fines or forfeitures collected upon conviction or upon the
forfeiture of bail of an person charged with a violation of any of the
provisions of this title shall be paid to the village treasurer and deposited
in the general fund.
   (B)   Failure, refusal or neglect on the part of any judicial or other
officer or employee receiving or having custody of any such fine or forfeiture
either before or after a deposit with the proper official shall constitute
misconduct in office and shall be grounds for removal therefrom. (Ord. 559, 9-
5-1968)

10-17-1: ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE:
Chapter 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 (as adopted in 1996 and

code, is hereby adopted by reference by the village to be used by the duly
